column2: Francis C. Reed, a specialist in corporate law and partner in the law firm of Hughes, Hubbard Reed, 1 Wall Street, died yesterday at his home in Llewellyn Park, West Orange, N. J. His age was 70. Mr. Reed graduated from Yale College and Harvard Law

Clayton Shutts closed down his Texaco station on Nick Stoner Road for the last nine days of 1973 and four days last month. He had run out of gas, and when he runs out of gas, so does Caroga Lake. Mr. Shutts runs the only Clayton Shutts using a measuring stick to check his supply of gasoline at Caroga Lake

Adolph Gottlieb, a founder of the New York School of abstract expressionism and a major figure in American art for more than 30 years, died yesterday in Beth Israel Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived and worked in studios at 380 West Broadway and in East Hampton, L.I. Adolph Gottlieb with works in his studio at East Hampton, L.I., in 1965

The rarity on Erik Hillman's piano recital program Sunday night at Carnegie Recital Hall was Schumann's "Bunte Blltter" (Op. 99). This is a collection of 14 salon pieces composed between 1836 and 1849, and they aren't often performed these days.

Willis Reed, hoping to return to the line-up in a week, worked out yesterday with the team at Pace. He continued to confine himself to running exercises and a bit of shooting.... Tom Riker and Dick Barnett, the assistant coach, missed the drill because of flu. Danny Whelan, the trainer, ran the practice in Barnett's place.

The president of a Queens school board said yesterday that his district had been in formed it would not be eligible or special Federal grants unless it provided ethnic data about teachers and other staff members.

In approving the Administration's bill to restore the death penalty, the Senate Judiciary Committee has succumbed to President Nixon's appeal thus to attack crime "without pity." The Supreme Court argues, on the contrary, that the death penalty constitutes cruel and unusual punishment in violation of the Eighth Amendment.

George Gallowhur, who in the nineteen-twenties in the Austrian Alps developed Skol suntan lotion, and later founded the Skol Company in New York, died Friday in the Miami Heart Institute. He was 69 years old and lived here and in Reading, Vt.

As the nation's 3-year-olds moved toward the Kentucky Derby on May 4 it became obvious at Gulfstream Park today that Woody Stephens, the trainer, will be at Churchill Downs with aces back to back. Judger, left, with Laffit Pincay Jr. up, winning the Florida Derby at Gulfstream Park yesterday. In second place was Cannonade, right, ridden by Pete Anderson. Buck's Bid, with Ruben Hernandez aboard, finished third.

Several senior Republican members of the House Judiciary Committee, who have taken the position that a President may be impeached only for serious violations of criminal laws, said today that they would regard conspiring to obstruct justice as such a serious violation.

MILLER COUNTY, Ga.--Hard by meandering, Spring Creek in fields that would soon be planted to peanuts or corn, we searched for signs of nomadic hunters who had been there thousands of years before the time of Christ.
University students clashed with the police in Madrid and Barcelona today after demonstrating against the execution of a young Catalonian anarchist.

About 2,000 Republicans applauded Senator Jacob K. Javits's 18 years in the Senate last night, contributed at least $250,000 to his re-election campaign and cornparison-shopped four Presidential possibilities who spoke at the Javits fundraising dinner. Senator Jacob K. Javits, left, and Vice President Ford signing autographs at dinner honoring the Senator held at the New York Hilton last night.
Rear Adm. William F. Rea 3d has been nominated by President Nixon to head the Coast Guard's Atlantic Area and Third District commands here, with the rank of vice admiral. Rear Adm. William F. Rea
Perhaps it was the impact 'of Yonkers Raceway's opening night that moved Herve Filion to dispense some French- Canadian philosophy tonight: Herve Filion Ed Parker

Herbert S. Denenberg, the Pennsylvania Commissioner of Insurance, announced today his candidacy for the Democratic nomination to the United States Senate, setting the stage for what may become one of this state's classic primary elections.

The curse of wealth is a very real thing. Why, even having a discretionary income is full of problems. Most of us, for example, can watch one of those swell commercials for the Lincoln. Continental that compares it with the other luxury car,

Cyprus is not a habitual source of good news. The Greek-Turkish clash on this Mediterranean island is rivaled only by the nearby Arab-Israeli dispute as a burial ground for peace plans that aborted, compromise formulas that lost their promise, and would-be peacemakers who went home in disillusionment.

Predicting continued heavy growth in the unionization of college faculties, the umbrella education agency for the states warns a new report that unless laws are written quickly to cover the special nature of collective bargaining on the campus, "the very roots of higher education may be brutally turn up."

There is an unassuming gentility in the playing of Janis Laurs, a young Australian cellist (of Latvian descent), that helped parts of his debut program Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Recital Hall but hindered others.
The buyers of commodities for future delivery moved to the sidelines yesterday, and prices of most key raw materials declined.

Leaflets dropped over Addis Ababa today said that some military units would "take action" unless Emperor Haile Selassie made sweeping political, economic and social changes, but it was not immediately clear how large the forces involved were. Armed police patrolling streets of Addis Ababa, capital of Ethiopia, yesterday

American aviation experts joined French and Turkish teams today in investigating whether the Turkish jetliner that crashed near Paris yesterday killing all 346 persons aboard could have been blown up by a bomb or brought down by mechanical failure.

The day began muggy and gray yesterday, but the sun broke through by 3 P.M., pushing temperatures to a record high of 70 degrees at 3:45. It was a day for shirtsleeve ice skating in Central Park and thoughts about the equinox.
A third major college basketball fixing scandal is not likely, according to Junius. Kellogg, the courageous:player who exposed the first big betting coup in the sport 23 years ago. Junius Kellogg
University students clashed with the police in Madrid and Barcelona today after demonstrating against the execution of a young Catalonian anarchist.

Chief Judge John J. Sirica today set a hearing for Wednesday to hear arguments "by all Interested counsel" on what is to be done with a sealed grand jury report believed to bear on President Nixon's possible role in the Watergate cover-up.
A mistrial was declared for Joseph Brasco and his case was severed from that of his nephew, Representative Frank J. Brasco, in Federal Court here yesterday.
More than a quarter of the four million people of Niger are dying of starvation, a Norwegian Red Cross official said today.
Railroad labor regards the Department of Transportation's recent proposals for restructuring the Penn Central and six other major bankrupt railroads in the Northeast and Midwest as "useless."

Birgit Nilsson fell yesterday and dislocated her shoulder during a dress rehearsal of "Gotterdammerung" at the Metropolitan Opera House. The accident, which stunned the cast, left in doubt the Birgit Nilsson just before she fell during a rehearsal of "Gotterdammerung" at the Metropolitan Opera.

Edward Heath, his party defeated last week by Britain's voters, tonight gave up his effort to hold onto power, and Harold Wilson took over as Prime Minister. Harold Wilson leaving his home to visit Queen Elizabeth Edward Heath on his way to resign as Prime Minister

The Coca-Cola Company continued an unbroken sales and earnings record last year with the fourth-quarter also at a record. At the same time, J. Paul Austin, chairman, announced yesterday that directors raised the quarterly dividend to 50 3/4 cents from 47 1/2 cents a share, payable April 1 to shareholders of record March 14.

If Defense Secretary James R. Schlesinger has his way, the Navy is building the last of the billion-dollar aircraft carriers that have become the pride of the fleet. For the future, Mr. Schlesinger has directed the Navy to

At the Circle Repertory Theater, quality is getting to be customary. First there was Lanford Wilson's "The Hot I Baltimore," then Mark Medoff's "When You Comin' Back, Red Ryder?" and now James Irwin's "The Sea Horse," which opened Sunday at the Circle, 2307 Broadway, at 83d Street.

Governor Wilson and leaders of organized labor in the state exchanged warm compliments today as the union leaders, in town to lobby for their legislative programs, made it clear that the Governor hardly needed to lobby for their support.
Local film critics, who have seldom been tempted of late to apply the term of "masterpiece" to a French movie, are nearly unanimous in their description of "La combe, Lucien"

A generation ago New Y6rk and Philadelphia dominated the world of American bridge. A few players from the Midwest and California were knocking at the door, but it seemed unlikely that they would be admitted to the East Coast coterie that provided America's world championship representatives.

Renewed warnings against the overuse of antibiotics -and the toll this practice can take on health and pocketbook - have been issued in a series of commentaries published in the current issue of the Journal of the American Medical Association.
The Interior Department announced today that it had accepted a $117.5-million bid from a consortium headed by the Atlantic Richfield Company to mine oil shale in western Colorado.

When Daryl Montoya hit the New York circuit as a jockey last fall, he was an unknown quantity to most fans here. True, he had performed creditably at Liberty Bell in Philadelphia, but his achievements there were Daryl Montoya

The Norwegian National Ballet made the first appearance in its fairly long United States tour Saturday night at the Walt Whitman Hall of Brooklyn College. As a cardcarrying Scandinavian lover, I bid it official welcome. As a simple friend of Scandinavia-I ask it why? Was this journey necessary?

Premier Golda Meir reversed herself today and agreedunder pressure from her Labor party colleagues-to try to form a new coalition cabinet in the next 48 hours. Premier Golda Meir, helped by bodyguard, arriving at President Ephraim Katzir's house in Jerusalem. He announced later she would continue trying to form cabinet.

The lawyer for the Mark Rothko Foundation yesterday joined the retinue of lawyers trying to break down the account of one of the late painter's executors that he had opposed a contract for the sale and consignment of all of Mr. Rothko's paintings to Marlboroueh Gallery.
Brazil opened a $232 -million bridge across Rio de Janeiro's Guanabara Bay today. It was described as the "largest structural complex" in. bridge-building history. The New York Times/March 5, 1974
Proposed measures that bear critically on the future of the Southwest and on the United States' relations with Mexico have reached the stage of Congressional hearings in Washington.

A public-relations specialist, testifying in the Federal fraud trial of Nelson G. Gross, said today that more than $44,000 in political contributions was illegally funneled through her company to finance the successful gubernatorial campaign of William T. Cahill in 1969.
A general representing the opposition appears to have scored a clear victory over two other military candidates in Guatemala'S presidential election

John C. Phillips, vice president in charge of corporate planning for Ina Corporation, a holding company for insurance and real estate, died Saturday in Paoli Memorial Hospital. He was 60 years old and lived in Philadelphia.

The Cryovac division of W. R. Grace Co., announced yesterday that it would increase its price by a range of 15 per cent to 20 per cent for all laminated packaging films for meat, cheese and other products, beginning April 1. Prices for certain ground-beef packaging films will be increased by 8 per cent.

The American school superintendent, long the benevolent ruler whose word was law, has become a harried, embattled figure of waning authority for whom the ledger book has grown as vital as the textbook. Squeezed by financial constraints, facing directives from courts and legislatures,

Edward Heath, his party defeated last week by Britain's voters, tonight gave up his effort to hold onto power, and Harold Wilson took over as Prime Minister. Edward Heath on his way to resign as Prime Minister
Prices on the American Stock Exchange and the over-thecounter market closed mixed yesterday in slackened trading on both markets. The Amex market value Index closed up 0.17 to 97.32.
1974, by Triangle Publlcations Inc. (The Daily Racing Form) Monday, March 4. Seventh day. Weather cloudy, track fast.

New York State's odd-even gasoline sales program ran into trouble again yesterday. 'About 100 handicapped persons in wheelchairs and on crutches gathered in the middle of the Avenue of the Americas at 55th Street, causing a three-and-a-half-hour traffic jam at midday until they won an exemption from the program.

The Federal Trade Commission said today that two large mail-order houses, Montgomery Ward and Spiegel, may have treated their customers unfairly by suing for unpaid bills in courts sometimes situated up to 1,000 miles from where the customers lived.
Keep your fingers crossed, Ranger fans, tomorrow night's the night' when the club just might catch the Montreal Canadiens and tie them for second place in the National Hockey About League East.

The Chase Manhattan Group today renamed its Austrian subsidiary, Oesterreichische Kommerzialbank, A.G. It will now be known as Chase Manhattan Bank (Austria), A.G. Chase owns 74.5 per cent of the bank.
Bankers were cautious yesterday in reacting to proposals made over the weekend for extensive reform to banking institutions in New York State.
We have received from a friend, Carl Sontheimer of Greenwich, Conn., a fascinating extract from an old manual called "La Cuisine Pratique," published by the Cordon Bleu in Paris in 1903.

Roy A. Medvedev, the dissident Marxist historian, declared today that the forced exile of Aleksandr I. Soizhenitsyn represented "a moral defeat for those in power who were neither willing nor able to answer his accusation"

A day after UIf Sundqvist celebrated his 27th birthday, he was sworn in as Finland's Minister of Education. Now that he has turned 29, he still considers himself a radical Social Democrat in political principle but says that he has been changed by ministerial experience. Ulf Sundqvist

If the Arab oil producers lift their embargo on the United States, as now seems possible, this move would have little effect on world oil prices unless it were accompanied by the restoration of Arab production cutbacks.

The index for help-wanted advertising declined in January for the third consecutive month, the Conference Board said yesterday. The index measures the volume of classified advertising in help-wanted columns in 52 newspapers across the nation. The Conference Board a private business research organization, said that historically a gain in the index often precedes a decline in the unemployment rate.

The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials rose to 239 compared to 231 from the week ended Feb. 19, 1974. The index compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics stood at 146.1 on Feb. 27, 1973.

The relations between the United States and France have taken a nasty turn. It is not primarily that their policies are different, which is understandable and even natural, but that they are beginning to personalize their differences, and blame them on Henry Kissinger or Michel Jobert or Georges Pompidou.

The International Red Cross said today that 65 Israeli prisoners held by Syria were in good condition. Michel Convere, an official of the organization, said that he presented a report yesterday to Foreign Minister Abba Eban based on Red Cross visits to the prisoners Friday.

Sol Hurok, one of the world's foremost impresarios, died yesterday afternoon of a massive heart attack at the age of 85. He had had lunch with Andres Segovia, the guitarist and close friend who was among the many distinguished artists whose appearances here he had sponsored,
Responding to doubles of one no-trump opening bids is a murky area in which there are two schools of thought. The majority nearly always bids. The minority,
The board studying the pay of Britain's striking coal miners has proposed raises of about 35 per cent, more than double what Edward Heath had offered before resigning as Prime Minister.
The Jersey Centtl- Power and Light Company, which is New Jersey's second largest utility company, asked state officials yesterday for authority to increase its rates an average of 23.5 Per cent.

A man who worked as a mail room clerk at the National BoUlevard Bank of Chicago was arrested by the Federal Bureau of Investigation yesterda, and charged with embezzling $185,000 in United States Treasury bills.

Former executives and employes of the Equity Funding Corporation will go on trial here Oct. 1. The Government charges that the concern created thousands of fictitious insurance policies that were sold at a profit to other companies.

Jarl Halleman, managing director of the publishing company holding first Finnish rights to "The Gulag Archipelago 1918-1956," by the Russian exile Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, said in Helsinki that "the board of directors decided unanimously not to publish the book."
At least 22 Americans are believed to have been among the 346 persons who died Sunday in the Turkish jetliner crash near Paris, the United States Embassy said today.
Coal miners striking in protest against a state fuelallocation program forced officials today to modify it,

The city yesterday rejected the high bid on the cannibalized old ferryboat Gold Star Mother. Purchase Commissioner Robert I. Cohen said that East-West Merchants and Traders, of 10 East 40th Street, the high bidder on the 37-year-old craft, which once ran between Manhattan and Staten Island had "defaulted" on its $77,500 offer.

New Jersey officials asked today that the Federal Communication-Commission find a way to assure better television service for the state, even if it meant moving one or two New York stations to New Jersey.
The Internal Revenue Service said last night it would give the Silvercup bread company in Long Island City, Queens, more time to settle its $1.5million back-tax bill.
During the gasoline shortage, New York State legislators have been getting a special supply from a state agency on Sundays, when most service stations are closed to the public.

The State Department complained today that the ninenation European Economic Community had failed to consult the United States in advance of its offer of long-term economic and technical cooperation to the Arab countries yesterday.

In an age when nationalistic antagonisms are fierce over much of the globe and racial hostilities show few signs of diminishing, human society has ground for hope in the patient, steady effort of contemporary Christians to resolve ancient controversies and to achieve reconciliation.

Several hundred Model Cities workers and representatives of private antipoverty agencies demonstrated at City Hall yesterday to protest the imminent cutback of 3,871 federally-financed jobs in Harlem, the South Bronx and the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn.
Six members of the Brooklyn Museum's governing committee have been named to a committee to find a permanent director for the museum.

Announcement of a one million dollar matching grant to the Metropolitan Opera from a greatly enriched National Endowment for the Arts marks a stunning breakthrough in public support for cultural activities in this country. To the Met, caught in what its board chairman has described as a "life and death" financial crisis, this transfusion of funds far exceeding any previous Governmental assistance offers a new lease on life.

Harold Goldstein, former chairman of Goldstein, Samuelson, Inc., bankrupt commodity option company was sentenced today to 18 months in jail on three counts of mail fraud by the United States District Court here.

Mel Utley and Ed Searcy each scored 25 points as St. John's defeated St. Francis last night, 82-66, in the 61st game of a basketball rivalry that started in 1907. The game was played at Alumni Hall in Jamaica.
Oscar R. Wilensky, a Republican State Senator from 1939 to 1942 and former majority leader of the Assembly, died today in Passaic General Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived here.
Mel Farr, a seven-year running back with the Detroit Lions, was traded today to the Houston Oilers for an undisclosed draft choice.

The state parole system, introduced in 1876 as a means of softening the harshness of prison, was attacked yesterday by a citizens' group as "oppressive and arbitrary," "a tragic failure" and "beyond reform."

WATERSHIP DOWN. By Richard Adams. 429 pages. Illustrated with maps. Macmillan. $6.95. Straight faces, please, and no tittering from the back of the room. Because the subject today is rabbits-yes, bunny rabbits-and what I have to say about them is wholly serious.

Mention "tennis mother" and the picture usually portrayed is that of a fussy, overprotective woman determined to let nothing stand in the way of her youngster's success. Some tennis mothers can be helpfulto a point. Others are known to leave psychological scars on their offspring, or to work on them so much that they become burnt-out cases on the court after a few years.
The meeting of Arab oil ministers to be held in Libya Sunday holds out strong prospects for a relaxation of Arab oil restrictions, including the embargo
Topseeded Ilie Nastase of Rumania whipped Kim Warwick of Australia, 6-1, 6-2, in the opening round of the $35,000 Coliseum Mall tennis tournament tonight.

DENVER -- Just as critics of nuclear tests thought they were winning, the Atomic Energy Commission has revitalized plans to expand research and testing of underground nuclear stimulation blasts to extract natural gas and shale oil in the Rocky Mountains.

The Kerr-McGee Chemical Corporation monopolized trade in ammonium perchlorate, a key ingredient in solid rocket propellent, and illegally priced the chemical in violation of antitrust laws from 1966 to 1970, a Federal judge has ruled.

Prices paid for paintings by Mark Rothko, the abstract expressionist, during his lifetime by Mary Lasker, Edward Albee and Dr. Franz Meyer were cited yesterday in Surrogate's Court by lawyers defending a contract made by the executors selling or consigning all of his paintings to Marlborough Gallery after his death by suicide Feb. 25, 1970.
There once was a great soprano who, in the last days of her career was singing at the Vienna Opera, and not singing very well any more.

The Government started yesterday to get to the core of its case against John N. Mitchell and Maurice H. Stans, with the first testimony linking former Attorney General Mitchell to Robert L. Vesco, the financier who is now a fugitive.

President Ahmed Sekou Toure today urged underdeveloped countries that produce bauxite'-the base material for aluminum--to develop capacity for producing aluminum itself and thereby increase their incomes at least 15 times.

Otto Graham, one-time ace quarterback with the Cleveland Browns and athletic director at the United States Coast Guard Academy since 1970, was named yesterday as the New London, Conn., institution's head football coach, succeeding Tad Schroeder.
Doctors Hospital, a voluntary institution on the upper East Side, has discontinued its obstetrics department because of what an official called "low utilization" and a large deficit.

The general attorney for the Grand Union Corporation -testified today that Nelson G. Gross, the former state Republican chairman, was the source of an account concocted to disguise a $5,000 contribution to former Gov.

Transportation Secretary Claude S. Brinegar said today that he was "flatly opposed" to a House-Senate conference bill on urban mass transit and had urged President Nixon to veto the legislation, which appeared all but doomed today in a parliamentary quagmire in the House.

White House lawyers are preparing a two-pronged defense against the implication in last Friday's grand jury indictments that President Nixon may not have opposed hush money payments to the Watergate defendants.

Stax Records and Charles 0. Finley said today they had almost completed an agreement for Finley to sell his Memphis Tams of the American Basketball Association to the black-soul music company. Finley's reported asking price was $1-million. The Tams have the worst record in pro basketball.

Faculty tenure, the system that protects the jobs of professors, came under intense scrutiny at an all-day meeting here yesterday devoted to examining the role of college and university trustees in setting academic policy.

The House Judiciary Committee directed its lawyers today to obtain a sealed grand jury report on President Nixon's possible, role in the Watergate cover-up and to determine by Thursday if the White House would supply evidence for use in an impeachment inquiry.
The Exxon Corporation yesterday announced the nomination of Martha Peterson, president of Barnard College, to its board of directors.

Stax Records and Charles O. Finley said today they had almost completed an agreement for Finley to sell his Memphis Tams of the American Basketball Association to the black-soul music company. Finley's reported asking price was $1-million. The Tams have the worst record in pro basketball. Larry Shaw, Stax vice president, said at company headquarters here: "We have finally resolved the differences.

Emperor Haile selassie, confronted by continued unrest and increasing demands for sweeping change, announced tonight that he had agreed to a constitutional convention to create a new system of elected democratic government.

The Ogden Corporation said yesterday that its agreement with the El Paso Natural Gas Company for, the construction of three ships to carry natural gas by Ogden's Avondale Shipyard subsidiary was no longer binding. Ogden added that, since the Federal Power Commission had not issued certificates for El Paso's second Algerian liquefied natural gas project, the pricing for 1978 and 1979 deliveryy of the ships was no longer firm.

Jack Kelly has been appointed vice president and general manager of radio station WHN by its parent corporation, Storer Broadcasting. He was previously vice president and executive officer of Storer Television Sales, station representatives.

WASHINGTON, March 5--The State Department complained today that the nine-nation European Economic Community had failed to consult the United States in advance of its offer of long-term economic and technical cooperation to the Arab countries yesterday.
Thomas A. Luken, a 48-yearold Democrat, eked out a narrow victory tonight in a special election in Ohio's First Congressional District-an election in which Watergate played a role.
DuPont Glore Forgan confirmed yesterday that it had closed five of Its brokerage offices in Europe. The firm said offices in Amsterdam, Frankfurt, Lausanne,
Twenty per cent of service stations have been found, in a national random survey, to be without gasoline, the American Automobile Association said today.

The House of Representatives has now joined the Senate in recognizing the need for Federal standards to govern the private pension plans that cover thirty million workers, and to prevent expected benefits from proving illusory to workers on retirement.

Dean Burch, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, who was to have leftW on March 15 to become counselor to President Nixon, yesterday moved up the timetable and instead will take his new post, which has Cabinet rank, in the next day or two.
Americans have always had a love affair with sugar, despite the admonitions of family dentists. Lately, the sweet tooth has paid off for owners of sugar stocks.
Shortages of textile fibers have created problems for the textile industry, James D. Finley, chairman of J. P. Stevens Co., Inc., said at the company's annual meeting here yesterday.

Iranian and Iraqi border forces exchanged artillery fire today for the second day, and Iraq said three of her men were killed and 12 wounded.
After last night's victory over Seattle, the Knicks and five sports writers were given medication to combat a possible exposure to meningitis.

Foreign Secretary, 61. . .Only one of four ministers not to have gone to Oxford but has been visiting fellow there. . .Father a chief petty officer in Royal Navy. . .Left school at 17 and began work as income-tax inspector. .

The soft sounds of what is now believed to be the oldest song in the world were played here today at the University of California. "This has revolutionized the whole concept of the origin of Western music," Richard L. Crocker, professor of music history at Berkeley, said today.
Lou Piniella was the first kid on his block to have a water cooler from a baseball park. "I figured I might as well take it home," the new Yankee said today. "I paid for it. In fact,
Ruben Olivares of Mexico survived a 10th-round knockdown and went on to win a split decision from Irish Art Hafey in 12 rounds to retain his North American featherweight boxing title last night.
A bank manager wielding a broomstick foiled a holdup yesterday at the Chemical Bank branch at 201 Park Avenue South, at 17th Street, and held two robbers at bay until the police arrived.
Thirty-seven patients and more than 50 outpatients of Harlem Hospital Center were evacuated about noon yesterday from a building on 136th Street between Lenox and Fifth
Mybor Beame said yesterday that he would support City Council legislation to repeal one set of rent increases scheduled in many of the one million rent-controlled apartments here. At the same time,

Steven R. Saunders, deputy supervisor of the Town of Oyster Bay, who has been subpoenaed to appear before a Nassau County grand Jury investigating allegations of wrongdoing in the town, submitted his resignation today.

The Securities and Exchange Commission charged in Federal court today that investors were defrauded of $9-million through mutual-fund manipulations and disappropriation of funds by officers of the Seaboard Corporation of Los Angeles, a mutual c fund management concern, and various brokerage firms.

Nineteen persons were charged In indictments unsealed yesterday in the Federal District Court in Brooklyn with the theft of more than 7,000 blank airline tickets - thefts that wer said to have resulted in a loss to carriers of more than $S2million.

The Senate Banking Committee unanimously approved today a -bill that calls for a common tape and quotatior-. system and an integration of all securities markets into a centralized system.
Two new defendants were named yesterday in an indictment involving the attempted ambush murder of two police officers in Queens last year.

Responding to doubles of one no-trump opening bids is a murky area in which there are two schools of thought. The majority nearly always bids. The minority, but a minority that includes nearly all the top-ranked players, nearly always passes.
ITHACA, N.Y., March 5--Cornell, the defending hockey champion in the Eastern College Athletic Conference, beat St. Lawrence, 5-3, tonight in the first round of the conference tournament.

WHITEHOUSE, Yukon Territory -- Seventy-five years after the rush to find gold along the Klondike River called this vast, wild land to the world's attention it is restless again-this time with a yearning for self-government.

The Assembly was asked today to end the "virtual enslavement' of thousands of household workers by allowing maids and oth er domestic employes to form unions and bargain collectively for better working conditions.
The current fall-winter issue of Parnassus, the twice-yearly magazine devoted solely to reviews of poetry and edited by Herbert Leibowitz, will be published March 15.

Faculty tenure, the system that protects the jobs of professors, came under intense scrutiny at an all-day meeting here yesterday devoted to examining the role of college and university trustees in setting academic policy.

Joseph Doria picks up an apple, evaluates the intensity of its color, studies its contours, contemplates its stem, rubs its skin--and issues an instant verdict on its flavor, texture and perishability.

Top Democratic leaders have agreed to try to put together a Democratic state ticket representing various ethnic and religous groups before the Democratic State Committee's endorsement meeting in mid-June, in an effort to reduce the number of candidates in the Democratic primary.
Peter Paul Schell, who was Minister of the Interior of Hungry when the Nazis took over in 1943, died at his home here on Sunday. He was 75 years old and lived at 71 Myrtle Avenue.
Roger W. Flood, who retired in 1970 as a member of the New York City Housing Authority, died Sunday at Sydenham Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived at 21 Stuyvesant Oval.
Although angered by stiffer penalties threatened by the State Racing and Wagering Board for infractions, drivers at Yonkers Raceway decided last night shortly before post-time to compete.

SOROKI, U.S.S.R.,-In tidy rows of barrackslike buildings outside this northern Moldavian town, 54,000 pigs a year go from birth to the slaughterhouse-evidence of a transformation that could change the face of Soviet agriculture.

Mrs. Harriet Weed Hubbell, author of books for children and the widow of Delmer F. Hubbell, an investment counselor who wrote for newspapers on economics and politics, died of cancer Monday in Santa Fe, N. M., where she had been living.

Chris Evert and Laurie Fleming, Fort Lauderdale, Fla., products who trained and roomed together on the pro tennis circuit, displayed similar form in costing through first-round matches at the Maureen Connolly Brinker tournament today.

The State Welfare Inspector General, George F. Berlinger, estimated yesterday that more than $7.6-million had been saved statewide as a result of the ending or reduction of welfare grants in 3,047 cases Investigated by his office.

Former Gov. William T. Cahill, reflecting on his four years in office, portrayed himself this evening as a political leader who had failed to galvanize public support for many of his programs and had become a victim of the legislative opponents who fought them.
The Food and Drug Administration recalled from United States markets today all chocoate products made by a Canadian concern because of suspected salmonella bacteria contamination.

Nearly 200 objects of fine and decorative arts and pieces of Jewelry-all donated-will be auctioned or sold through sealed bids on March 19 to help finance renovations of the Interior of the Carnegie mansion on Fifth Avenue, now the cooper-Hewitt Museum of DeCorative Arts and Design.

SAN FRANCISCO--Louise Thoresen has "a new life" now. She's a changed woman, she says. She's unmarried, unattached and lives quietly with her 11-year-old son in a small white house five blocks from the Greek Revival mansion she used to share with her husband.
West Germany and the Soviet Union agreed today to seek opportunities to set up joint companies for operating in third countries with mixed Soviet-German capital, management and production.
The Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith asserted yesterday that American Jews were becoming increasingly concerned over a new kind of anti-Semitism expressed by individuals and Institutions.
A bankruptcy judge has approved a request by U.S. Financial, Inc., to sell Mosser Construction, Inc., of Ohio to four Mosser employes.

Gold bugs-members of that widely scattered group that John Maynard Keynes more decorously referred to as "the champions of gold"-gathered from all over the world this past weekend at Arden House in Harriman, N. Y., the baronial estate of E. H. Harriman, the 19th-century financier and railroad tycoon.

President Nixon has rejected the idea of public financing of campaigns for Federal office and will ask Congress on Friday to limit individual campaign contributions and bar direct donations by big labor or big business, a White House official said today.

HOUSTON-Just down the road from the Astrodome, this city's celebrated sports stadium, is a Texaco gas station. It does not have the square, boxy look of most gas stations; instead, it is round and has a low domelust like the Astrodome's.

The Army Corps of Engineers has awarded a $109.7-million contract to the Arundel Corporation and two other companies for the construction of the new Melones Dam on the Stanislaus River, east of San Francisco, Arundel announced yesterday.
The Government of President Juan Maria Bordaberry today shut the left-wing weekly magazine Marcha for 10 editions for publishing a short story frowned on by the authorities.
The special Watergate prosecutor, Leon Jaworski, expects at least a dozen more major indictments, according to a letter sent to Chief Judge John J. Sirica two months ago.
Wall posters in Chinese factories are denouncing once again the "evil tendency" to offer overtime payments and other material incentives to workers to stimulate higher production.
The formation of a Labor Government with Harold Wilson as Prime Minister sent the pound and stock prices sharply higher today in British markets.
Amid charges by the main op position party of fraud, Guatemala's army -backed Government announced tonight the Victory of its candidate in the Presidential election Sunday.
Brutus, his 160-pound great Dane, for a walk last Saturday night. Planning to be gone, for only half an hour or so, the 13-year-old boy wore only a denim jacket, jeans and a T-shirt.

Golden Opportunity, in the form of the Montreal Canadciens, presents itself tonight at 7:35 when the New York Rangers take the ice at Madison Square Gatden With a victory, the Rangers can tie Montreal for second place.
The New York Philharmonic and the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center will join forces for the first time to present two week-long "Mini-Festivals" during the 1974-1975 season.

WASHINGTON, March 5--The National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced today a reorganization in which Dr. Rocco Petrone, former director of the Apollo program, will be responsible for all of the space agency's research and development programs.
Hialeah Park, hoping for the best and fearing the worst, took a dose of the worst today as it opened a 49-day meeting with a crowd of only 12,359 and a mutuel handle of $1,440,579.

State Senator Anthony Imperiale, Independent of Essex County, officially entered the race for Mayor in Newark yesterday by filing petitions bearing more than 10,000 signatures with the City Clerk. So far only he and the incumbent, Kenneth A. Gibson, have filed petitions. The filing deadline for the May 14 election is March 28.

A 31-year-old man who violated his parole by coming to live in New York from Alabama two years ago was set free yesterday in Criminal Court in Queens after'being arrested on an extradition warrant two weeks ago.- . .

Governor Wilson and scores of representatives of labor, industry and government condemned a Federal proposal to eliminate 34 per cent, or about 1,875 miles, of railroad trackage in the state and warned that it would have a severe impact on the state's economy. "These lines serve over 200 communities in this state," Governor Wilson said.

Any number of parents, including the "single" variety rho see their children only on weekends, are finding the riverside Table Tennis parlor run by Marty Reisman good or an hour's entertainment-more it the children get interested in the sport.

The Government started yesterday to get to the core of its case against John N. Mitchell and Maurice H. Stans, with the first testimony linking former Attorney General Mitchell to Robert L. Vesco, the financier who is now a fugitive.
Premier Gold Meir announced today that she would complete the formation of a new coalition tomorrow and that it would include Moshe Dayan as Defense Minister.
A $250,000 grant to the Center for Understanding Media, in New York, for the filming of two American short stories was announced today by the National Endowment for the Humanities.
A man carrying a shotgun hijacked a truck loaded with meat and poultry today as it was being taken to a food distribution center in the program to secure the release of Patricia Hearst.
Perhaps the first reference to pit crews is found in the Bible: "Whoso diggeth a pit shall fall therein" (Proverbs, 28:27).

New Jersey officials asked today that the Federal Communications Commission find a way to assure better television service for the state, even if it meant moving one or two New York stations to New Jersey.
The chairman of the Public Service Commission warned today of a possible doubling of electric utility rates in New York State in the next decade, based on environmental considerations alone.

Paul R. Screvane became president of the Offtrack Betting Corporation yesterday. The former City Council president and Sanitation Department commissioner was elected by the corporation's five-member board.
The new City Manager of Yonkers, Clifford W. O'Key, today announced-much to the surprise of the Mayor, who hired him-that his staff meetings would be open to the press.

President Nixon appeared today to be headed for a possible confrontation with Congress over his tax returns. The possible confrontation concerns a likely attempt by the Joint Committee on Internal Revenue Taxation to find out just how much Mr. Nixon personally knew about several claims on his tax returns, from 1969 onward, that saved him hundreds of thousands of dollars in Federal income taxes.
The Seattle SuperSonics were not super from the foul line in the final six minutes of their game against the Knicks last night at Madison Square Garden. In fact, they were foul.

The first week in March is Town Meeting time in much of New England. In the little towns on the farmlands and coastlines of Maine and Massachusetts, and along the rivers and mountain valleys of New Hampshire and Vermont, the citizens --as they have done since Colonial times--come together to vote on their taxes, town regulations and other issues of mutual concern.

Birgit Nilsson, who is recuperating from a shoulder dislocation suffered during a dress rehearsal of "Gotterdammerung" on Monday at the Metropolitan Opera House, said yesterday from her bed in Roosevelt Hospital that she was "coming along."

The Senate rejected today an attempt to repeal wage and price controls. The proposal, which was a rider to a bill that would set a $2.20-an-hour minimum wage for 56 million American workers. was defeated, 66 to 28.

Resentment of a United States law that is blocking an $18-million sale of Canadian locomotives to Cuba has stirred the Parliament here, with opposition members demanding that Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau's Government take steps to assure that the pending deal goes through in spite of opposition by Washington.

Otto Graham, one-time ace quarterback with the Cleveland Browns and athletic director at the United States Coast Guard Academy since 1970, was named yesterday as the New London, Conn., institution's head football coach, succeeding Tad Schroeder.

Thomas Dunn, who used to give New Yorkers some provocative programs with his Festival Orchestra before moving to Boston seven years ago to direct the Handel and Hayden Society there, returned to a local concert stage for the first time to lead a performance of Bach's "Passion Accordring to St. John" in Alice Tully Hall on Monday night.
The Federal Trade Commission announced today that a large regional shopping center and two of its major tenants had agreed not to enforce

Despite defense objections, a former assistant district attorney and a detective both testified yesterday in the case of Henry S. Brown, on trial in the murder of Police Officers Gregory P. Foster and Rocco W. Laurie.
The National Football League Players Association described today as "totally inadequate" benefits under the pension fund for widows of former players and for totally disabled former players.

Mayor Beame said yesterday he would support City Council legislation to repeal one set of rent increases in the city's rent-controlled apartments. At the same time, he also urged the Council to approve a second set of increases.

Ed Garvey, the lawyer who runs the Professional Football Players' Union, was quoted the other evening by one of those people who make a living by reading the scores of games on television. The item was something to do with gains the players hope to make in collective bargaining with the owners. The character on the air jeered.

"We've got a job to do," said Harold Wilson as he stood once again on the threshold of 10 Downing Street as Britain's Prime Minister. "We can only do that job as one people." If Mr. Wilson gears his actions to his own maxim his minority Labor Government may not merely survive for a considerable period but may serve a hardpressed country well in one of its worst economic crises since Wnrld War II.
For hours before Maria Callas's electrifying return to the concert stage here last night, telephones at Carnegie Hall had been ringing without letup.

Emperor Haile Selas. sie, confronted by continued unrest and increasing demands for sweeping change, announced tonight that he had agreed to a constitutional convention to create a new system of elected democratic government.

Brazilt-Awakening Giant, by Philip Raine, introduction by Lincoln Gordon (Public Affairs Press, Washington, $7). Concerning Death: A Practical Guide for Living, edited by Earl A. Grollman (Beacon Press, Boston, $7.50: paperbound, $3.95).
Ohio's former Governor, James A. Rhodes, testified today before the Federal grand jury investigating the May 4, 1970, killing of four Kent State University students by National Guard troops.
Six prisoners died during a jail riot in a Hermosillo prison yesterday, while at another Sonora state prison, in Nogales, one prisoner was killed during a mass escape.

The average issue of Playboy during the second half of last year had about 500,000 less circulation than the average issue in the second half of 1972. It was the first such loss In Playboy's fabuious 20 years.
Mrs. Rebecca Grun Hershberg, a retired teacher at the Traphagen School of Design, and the wife of Henry Hershberg, a retired school principal, died yesterday in the Riverdale Nursing Home.

Nora Post's oboe recital Monday night at Town Hall was by no means an ordinary event. t First of all, there was Miss Post's adventuresome program, t which called upon her to perform a Baroque group in the first half on a reconstruction of an early 18th-century German two-keyed oboe, and then to return in the second half for a Contemporary group with a modern oboe.

After a heated debate until the early morning hours, the Argentine Senate gave its approval today to President Juan D. Peron's request that he be allowed to appoint a federal official to replace the deposed left-wing Peronist governor of Cordoba.

More money to rehabilitate Central Park was demanded yesterday by Percy E. Sutton, the Manhattan Borough President, and a delegation of City Council members from Manhattan at a news conference on the front steps of City Hall.

The Netherlands, already subject to an Arab oil embargo, would rather extradite two captured Arab hijackers to Britain than try them here and run the risk of raising new Arab antagonism, informed sources said here today.
The Sun Oil Company announced yesterday that it had raised its prices for residual fuel oil by $1.55 a barrel, effective immediately. The oil is used primarily by industry.

The Soviet Communist party leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev, today received a personal letter from President Nixon and spent an hour and 45 minutes discussing international issues and SovietAmerican relations with Ambassador Walter J. stoessel Jr.
Prospective jurors return today to state Supreme court here for possible duty in the trial of five persons accused in the ambush slaying of two police officers at a Harlem housing project in 1971.
GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on the Peaceful Uses of Outer Space, working group on remote sensing of the earth by satellites10:30 A.M.

LONDON, March 5--The board studying the pay of Britain's striking coal miners has proposed raises of about 35 per cent, more than double what Edward Heath had offered before resigning as Prime Minister.

The con-troversial $266-million Park a Plaza redevelopment plan for the section of downtown Boston known as Park Square re- r ceived conditional approval today from Lewis S.W. Crampton, f the Massachusetts Community e Affairs Commissioner.

By 10 A.M. tomorrow, Judge John J. Sirica's courtroom will be filled with lawyers eager to speak definitively about what the judge should do with the secret report that the Watergate grand jury gavehim last week for forwarding to the House impeachment inquiry.
Corporate bond prices showed selective, modest improvement yesterday. Government issues remained mixed, A busy tax-exempt market showed good first-day response to a heavy calendar.
Manufacturers' new orders took a huge jump of $4.12. billion in January to a record after a decline in December, the Commerce Department reported today.
The startling discovery of the Hurrian cuneiform tablet containing a cult love song pushes back the frontier of notated music well over a thousand years.

Robert D. Timm, chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, conditionally endorsed yesterday. the concept of providing Federal subsidies to United States international airlines because of high jet-fuel costs.
The nation's 1,000 largest manufacturers set aside a total of $11.35-billion for improvement of plant and equipment in the fourth quarter of 1973, the Conference Board reported yesterday.
Senator John L. McClellan, Democrat of Arkansas, said today that the Senate Defense Appropriations Subcommittee would try to cut $3.5-billion from next year's record $85.6billion defense budget.

Transportation Secretary Claude S. Brinegar said today that he was "flatly opposed" to a House-Senate conference bill on urban mass transit and had urged President Nixon to veto the legislation, which appeared all but doomed today in a parliamentary quagmire in the House.
President Nixon said today he would-be forced to veto a pending education bill because certain provisions on grants funding "would create a bureaucratic nightmare."
''There has been a great shake-up among some of the Nixon old guard," The Times said on page one, and it told of 'the old guard's fall from grace and power.
Premier Golda Meir announced today that she would complete the formation of a new coalition tomorrow and that it would include Moshe Dayan as Defense Minister.
A state law outlawing "private lewdness" was indirectly challenged today by the State Supreme Court.

Chris Evert and Laurie Fleming, Fort Lauderdale, Fla., products who trained and roomed together on the pro tennis circuit, displayed similar form in coasting through first-round matches at the Maureen Connolly Brinker tournament today.

SYRACUSE-No one seems to know whether the oil crisis is real or contrived. But one thing is clear: Americans are paying more and more money for less and less gas, acquired under increasingly difficult, distasteful, and even dangerous circumstances.

Lawyers for Dale N. Anderson began their defense of the Baltimore County Executive today after gaining dismissal of three more charges. The chargees ere dropped after the prosecution concluded its case.

The Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, flew to Damascus today after a five-day visit to Egypt that was apparently designed to show Moscow's determination to reassert its influence in the area.

At 12:30 A.M. on Feb. 6, the 35year-old radical editor of a muckraking Arabic weekly was dropped off by friends outside his East Jerusalem apartment.
Thomas A. Luken, a 48-yearold Democrat, eked out a narrow victory tonight in a special election in Ohio's First Congressional District-an election in which Watergate played a role.

To the Editor: The staff study prepared for the House committee on impeachment has been made public. The Constitution states the President may be impeached for "high crimes and misdemeanors." The study does not attempt to define impeachable offense, but it would include actions which might represent "grave misconduct, constitutional wrongs that subvert the structure of the Government or undermine the integrity of the office and even the Constitution."
Reports from Washington of a plot to assassinate Secretary of State Kissinger during his visit to Damascus last week were denied by official sources here today.
The stock market came alive yesterday, registering its biggest advance in two months in heavy trading as prices were spurred by prospects of an early end of the Arab oil embargo.

A wave of terrorist bombs hit Belfast and three other Northern Ireland cities today. Five persons were injured when three bombs exploded in downtown Belfast during the evening rush hour, setting three stores on fire.

Jan Hoffmann of East Germany, carving figures with the precision of a computer, took a slender lead over two Soviet Union skaters after the men's compulsory program in the world figure skating championships today and left the star American skater, Gordon McKellen, with only an outside chance for the title.
Players of the Zaire national football team were asked to dine in their hotel rooms after a little gastronomic upset, the Middle East News Agency reported here.

Federal Judge Jack B. Weinstein announced yesterday that he would appoint a master to help formulate plans among government agencies to increase racial integration at Mark Twain Junior High School in Coney Island.

How thou art changed! I scarce endure The radiance of thy beauty. Some good change Is working in the elements, which suffer Thy presence thus unveiled. Percy Bysshe Shelley. "Prometheus Unbound"
In the most active trading in almost two months, prices on the American Stock Exchange rose yesterday. Similar conditions prevailed in the over-thecounter market.
Mayor Beame played pitchman yesterday in a hard sell to the radio and television industry, asking it to devote "large segments of air time" to promote the positive side of the city.

The bears continued to dominate the commodity futures markets yesterday as once again almost every basic raw material was bid down in price. In most cases, notably in the grain and precious metals pits, prices closed at their daily permissible lows or not far above them.

The Federal Government charged yesterday that Dr. W. Kenneth Riland, an osteopathic physician here, had secretly "funneled" fees for treating President Nixon and former Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller into private savings accounts to avoid listing them as income.
Dr. Helen Gill Viljoen, who retired in 1965 as professor of English at Queens College, died on Monday at her home in Flushing, Queens. She was 75 years old and lived at 167-10 Crocheron Avenue.

Robert W. Duggan, dis trit -attorney of Allegheny County, was found shot to death in - a field at his home early today, hours before a Federal grind jury in nearby Pittsburgh indicted him for income tax fraud.

Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz saic today that reform proposals for a statewide election commission and partial public financing of campaigns might require time-consuming constitutional amendments.

A group of Long Island and university officials flew over the South Shores early this morning and dropped thousands of specially, marked cards from their helicopters in a project designed to dissuade the Federal Government and oil companies from engaging in offshore oil exploration.

A financial agent named as a co-conspirator in the corruption conspiracy indictment of Representative Frank J. Brasco testified in Federal Court yesterday that tile Brooklyn Congressman had discussed with him the possibility of obtaining a loan for a "sham" trucking company that was to be run secretly by a reputed Mafia captain.

Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist Party leader, has disclosed that Soviet agriculture suffered large losses of grain during last year's record harvest because of inadequate storage and transport facilities.

Sol Hurok, one of the world's foremost impresarios, died yesterday afternoon of a massive heart attack at the age of 85. He had had lunch with Andres Segovia, the guitarist and close friend who was among the many distinguished artists whose appearances here he had sponsored,
The startling discovery of the Hurrian cuneiform tablet containing a cult love song pushes back the frontier .of notated music well over a thousand years.

The medical staff of Boston's largest Roman Catholic hospital, St. Elizabeth's, has recommended that the hospital should boycott Upjohn Company products when possible because of the company's production of a drug that is used to induce abortions.
It was an absolutely frustrating way to lose a game but the New York Islanders managed it. bowing to the Pittsburgh Penguins, 2-1, in the Nassau Coliseum tonight.

I am over 60 and most distressed, not only by failing vision, missing teeth, barnacles on the spine, aching joints, gray hair and wrinkles, but because every effort is being made to separate and isolate me from a portion of my life and the rest of the living.

City officials understandably stressed the importance of Federal funds to help save the 35-cent transit fare when testifying before a Senate transportation subcommittee hearing here the other day. But the experience of the subcommittee's chairman, Senator Lloyd Bentsen, Democrat of Texas, points up that cost isn't the only consideration affecting ridership on the city's subway system.
A painting of President Nixon posing against a stone wall, reported missing from Mr. Nixon's old law school at Duke University yesterday morning, was found undamaged this afternoon.
The United States Ambassador, Daniel P. Moynihan, was sharply attacked today by an Indian newspaper closely linked to the ruling Congress party and Prime Minister Indira Gandhi.

In an effort to supplement a skimpy Public Broadcasting Service programing schedule, Channel 13 has returned to the past and found that it works. Beginning tonight, the station will rerun the 25-part series called "Pablo Casals Master

The $4-billion Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York said yesterday that a suit filed against the company, its real estate investment trust, Mony Mortgage Investors and the trust's 10 trustees has been dismissed by the Appellate Division of the New York Supreme Court.
The Federal Government will take II of its own narcotics agents to trial here tommorrow, charging them with violating the constitutional rights of innocent persons.
The 28-year-old former coach of a Mamaroneck football team in the Pop Warner League has been indicted on 52 counts bf sexual abuse and sodomy, District Attorney Carl A. Vergari announced today.

Criminal-Justice officials yesterday hailed the convictions last week of four fur union officials for having accepted payoffs. They called it a big gain in the long and mostly futile effort to crack labor racketeering in the garment industry.

The official board studying the pay of Britain's striking coal miners has proposed that they get raises of about 35 per cent, more than twice the offer that caused the dispute. Sources who have seen the Pay Board report disclosed its findings as Prime Minister Wilson announced his new Labor Cabinet and moved to end the three-week strike.
Louis Franklin Power Sr., father of Associate Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr. of the Supreme Court, died yesterday at his home. He was 94 years old.
The Anti-Defamation League of B'nai Brith asserted yesterday that American Jews were becoming increasingly concerned over a new kind of anti Semitism expressed by individuals and institutions.

During the final days of his 18-year exile, Juan Domingo Peron's trump card was his ability to convince most Argentines that only his movement had the strength and substance to end the violent political divisions among them and give their potentially rich country a fresh start,...

The House Judiciary Committee directed its lawyers today to obtain a sealed grand jury report on President Nixon's possible role in the Watergate cover-up and to determine by Thursday if the White House would supply evidence for use in an impeachment inquiry.
Rita Hunter rushed about getting .costumes pinned, fitted and-sewn at the last minute yesterday for a performance- she hoped she would never have to sing.

Britain's new Labor Government and leaders of the striking coal miners agreed on a wage settlement that gives the strikers virtually everything they had demanded. The workers are expected to return to their jobs early next week and Prime Minister Wilson will move to end the three-day work week that has crippled most of British industry for more than two months.

Top Administration officials said today that the Government had begun re-examining its policy toward France in view of what it regards as the French policy of trying to separate the European Common Market from the United States.
Clinton T. Lovatt, president since the mid-nineteen-forties of the Rockland Real Estate Company, died today in Good Samaritan Hospital. He was 68 years old.
Players of great ability may fail to win public acclaim for a variety of reasons. From choice or necessity they may compete at the club and local level rather than travel to major tournaments.

The drawing tendencies of bishops of opposite color have traditionally been overrated. One of the main reasons for this has been the evaluation of them in terms of material, without sufficient regard for positional factors.
Premier Golda Meir announced the formation of a new coalition Cabinet tonight, ending nine weeks of domestic political stalemate in Israel.

Mayor Beame said last night that craft-union problems at the Rheingold brewery in Brooklyn had been resolved and that he was optimistic that Rheingold was going to stay in business here under the management of Chock Full O'Nuts.

Mario M. Cuomo withheld for "political" reasons two dramatic facts from his 1972 compromise report on the Forest Hills housing project: that a number of blacks were opposed to it and that the controversy touched off a serious increase in the vacancy rate in Forest Hills apartments.

Virginia Wade of Britain moved into the second round of the Maureen Connolly Brinker women's tennis tournament today with a 7-5, 6-1 victory over Kristy Pigeon of Danville, Calif. Miss Pigeon made five double-faults in the first set.

Prices on the American Stock Exchange rose to their highest level in more thai three months yesterday although volume dipped slightly. Advances also were scored in the over-theequter market as volume fell somewhat.

The leading candidate for the presidency of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, Joseph V. Terenzio, has formally withdrawn his name from the list of contenders, causing a search committee to begin again its seven-month-old effort to find a man for the job.
The Agriculture Department's year-old plan to use farmers' income tax returns as a source of mailing lists for statistical surveys is currently "inoperative," a top department official said today.

The sudden flooding of a portion of Central Park shortly after 11 o'clock last night trapped at least five persons in their automobiles on the park's 96th Street transverse. They were rescued by two policemen and an auxiliary police sergeant.
The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company registered a 13.4 per cent rise in sales to $18.1billion last year, Richard R. Shinn president and chief executive officer, reported yesterday.

The two young Arabs who hijacked a British airliner to Amsterdam and set it on fire say that the arms and explosives for the operation were hidden in the plane by ac complices before they boarded police officials here said today.

Prime Minister John Vorster had discussions today with the black leaders of South Africa's eight tribal "homelands"-the first time that such an official meeting had taken place between blacks and whites in this country.
A congressional subcommittee that has been studying the nation's prison system says the American people would insist on improving it if they knew more about it.
Bond market prices showed improvement yesterday. The tax-exempt 'sector was the most active and, for the second consecutive day, gave good first-day response to a fairly heavy flow, of new offerings.

The same insensitivity to energy and environmental urgencies that marks the Administration's approach to urban mass transit characterizes its proposals for wholesale abandonment of rail trackage in the Northeast and Midwest.
The Soviet authorities disclosed today that they were rejecting the application of Newsweek to send a new correspondent here.

Gov. Francis W. Sargent of Massachusetts, a Republican, said today that the country would be better off if President Nixon turned his office over to Vice President Ford. Other Republican executives here for the National Governors Conference were clearly tempted to agree.
President Nixon vetoed the emergency energy bill today, and the Senate sustained the rejection in a vote taken within hours of his action.
Nathan Lemler was found guilty today of 20 of 21 counts of grand larceny for having bilked 19 families out of $256,000 by making false promises to place their children in medical or dental schools.

Top Administration officials said today that the Government had begun re-examining its policy toward France in view of what it regards as the French policy of trying to separate the European Common Market from the United States.
A bill that would prohibit government agencies and departments from asking a job applicant whether he had ever been arrested passed the Assembly and was sent to the Senate today.

Although watching television remains the country's most popular evening pastime, going to the movies or theater, listening to the radio and staying home with the family have shown marked increases in popularity, according to the Gallup Poll.

Theodore Stamos, an abstract-expressionist painter, was questioned yesterday about the sale of works by his friend the late Mark Rothko in Surrogate's Court, where Mr. Rothko's daughter, Kate, seeks dismissal of Mr. Stamos and two other executors named by her father.
A Filipino rebel leader and two of his aides, found guilty by a military court of kidnapping and murder, have been sentenced to death by firing squad, the police said today.

Tim Walker, a Rhode Island schoolboy who competed in the United StatesSoviet Union track meet last weekend, set a national intercholastic record for the high jump tonight at 6 feet 111/2 inches.

Jacksonville University yesterday became the 12th basketball team for the 16-team field in the 37th annual National Invitation Tournament, scheduled for Madison Square Garden March 16 to 24. The announcement was made by Peter A. Carlesimo, director of athletics at Fordham University and chairman of the N.I.T. selection committee.

Long Island University posted an 84-73 basketball victory over Iona College last night at the winner's court in Brooklyn in the season finale for both teams.

A Government witness testified yesterday that he had been told that Maurice H. Stans had asked Robert L. Vesco, a financier undergoing a Federal investigation, to make his $200,000 contribution to President Nixon's re-election campaign in cash.

If the political mood in Madrid has turned sour after a brief period of hope, it has in some ways followed the lead of this capital's main rival, Barcelona, where skepticism about promised political change has been rife and hope at best cautious.

City Councilman Louis M. Turco, the controversial political leader of the city's East Ward, resigned today, tearfully declaring that he had failed as a public official and that he had ?let down the thousands of people" who had supported him.
An 8-year.old boy walking home from elementary school with a companion in Dix Hills, L. I., was enticed into a car and kidnapped yesterday afternoon by three persons, the police reported.
The House Rules Committee in effect killed the House-Senate conference bill on urban mass transit today, an action that, the bill's sponsors said, virtually doomed New York City's 35cent fare.

The General Motors Corporation announced yesterday that it would increase its output of transit buses by 40 per cent beginning next week. Production of buses will be expanded from 35 units to 50 units a week in addition to the construction of 10 intercity models.
Major national health groups proposed today creation of an American blood commission to establish an efficient, all-volunteer national blood donor system by the end of next year.
Richard (Digger) Phelps, who lifted Notre Dame basketball from mediocrity to high national ranking, was named coach of the year yesterday by United Press International.

Celerino Sanchez finally arrived in Fort Lauderdale from Mexico, but still hasn't agreed to terms for 1974. The difference of opinion stems from the little playing time the third baseman had last season. The measles epidemic in New Jersey, already described as the worst in more than a decade, appears to be spreading, according to state and local health officials. Counties reporting the most serious spread of the disease are Bergen, Essex and Passaic. Health officials say they are unable to give an adequate reason for the sudden rise. Since last September, they said, 1,524 cases of measles have been recorded.

John Calzadilla, an 8-yearold boy who was kidnapped on Wednesday a block from his Suffolk County home, was recovered safely early this morning at a New Jersey motel after his father paid a ransom of an undisclosed amount.

The South Vietnamese Government accused the Vietcong today of terrorist acts, including the tossing of two hand grenades into a pagoda filled with refugees from the war. The Saigon command said 11 persons had been killed and 30 wounded in the pagoda.

West German officials and diplomats are saying that they feel the American criticism of the European Common Market's offer of cooperation to the Arab world has put them in the position of having to choose between France and the United States.
A high school girl was attacked and bitten by a pack of stray dogs in Flatbush the other day, victim of a growing menace in many parts of a city that now has an estimated 150,000 dogs running wild.

A substantial reduction in the level of carbon monoxide pollution in Manhattan has been one of the positive aspects of the gasoline shortage, the city's Environmental Protection Administration said yesterday.

Justice William J. Brennan of the United States Supreme Court has upheld the New Jersey Department of Education in its protracted battle with the New Jersey Education Association by refusing to stop the department from releasing statewide testing scores of public-school students.

Steve Caulkins started with an eagle and a birdie and made the turn in 32, but he shot 38 on the back nine.... Orville Moody attributed his 67, his second sub-70 round this season, to recovery of his putting touch. He putts cross-handed.....Sam Snead, whose straw hat is a trademark, said golfers would profit by wearing hats because they shade the eves "and make them last a bit longer."

Luigl Cherubini (1760-1842) was one of the most famous composers of his day and was held in the highest esteem by none less than Beethoven. Four Roman Catholic cardinals testified before a Senate subcommittee today that the Constitution should be amended to prohibit abortion. The prelates also refused to endorse a Constitutional amendment that would overturn last year's Supreme Court decision legalizing abortion because it contains a provision that would permit abortion in a medical emergency when the life of the mother is threatened.

SNAPPERS Photography is probably the most prolific art in the land, and if you don't believe it, saunter into the Kodak Photo Gallery, 1133 Avenue of the Americas, at 43d Street (262-6170). It will take some time to go through this glowing profusion of 720 finalist photos in the 1973 Kodak International Newspaper Snapshot Awards, the elite of more than 250,000 entries by amateur lensmen and women in contests run by 95 newspapers last summer.
DALLAS--These are some random observations after a trip to west Texas (part of it icebound) and which may or may not be instructive about our times.

Rick Barry poured in 31 points, the last 2 on a 20-foot jump shot at the buzzer, lifting the Golden State Warriors to a 97-95 National Basketball Association victory over the Milwaukee Bucks tonight. Barry scored 9 points in the last 3 minutes 5 seconds to rally the Warriors from an 87-84 deficit.
A man driving on Route 123 the other day slowed as he passed the New Canaan Field Club and then asked his companion: "What were' those women doing in that cage?"

The General Motors Corporation announced today that construction of two new auto assembly plants in Oklahoma City and Memphis would be delayed because of the slump in new-car sales. G.M. has nine plants closed this week with 50,000 workers furloughed.

President Nixon's statement last night that he learned last March 21 that hush money had been paid to the Watergate burglars raised new questions today about his actions after learning of the cover-up.

A White House aide, J. Fred Buzhardt Jr., acknowledged today that the Defense Department had objected to the Nixon Administration's decision to indict and try Dr. Daniel Ellsberg following publication of the Pentagon papers in June. 1971.

Following are excerpts from Secretary of State Kissinger's opening statement today to the Senate Finance Committee: Let me now turn to a more detailed discussion of one particularly vexing aspect of our trade strategy: the normalization of commercial relations with the Soviet Union.

For many moons now, this country has had an institution loosely called "the night out with the boys," but, of course, no boys are involved. It is that night of the week when a group of husbands get together to bowl, drink beer, play cards, shoot the breeze or whatever, while their wives stay home with the kids.
Jan Hoffmann of East Germany crowned 12 years of dedication tonight with a near-perfect performance to win the men's title at the 1974 world figure skating championships.
The Securities and Exchange Commission filed suit today against Avis, Inc., the car rental concern, charging it misrepresented the source of its profits in the first quarter of last year.
The State Transportation Department plans a $670-million capital program for highways for the year beginning April 1, including $223-million for interstate highway projects.

Secretary of State Kissinger told a Senate committee today that he would recommend a veto of the Nixon Administration's own trade bill if Congress refused to grant trade concessions to the Soviet Union because of its restrictions on the free emigration of Jews and others.

The Board of Estimate yesterday approved payment of $52,300 for 523 sets of a reference work that had been ordered orally by a Brooklyn College department head for distribution to disadvantaged students.

Assemblyman Robert C. Wertz of Commack, L. I., asserted today that the administration of the state's program of discharging mental patients had broken down. As a result, he said, "in the vast majority of cases -- 90 per cent of the time -- a former patient has never been seen."

International airlines-which have raised fares between the United States and Europe by more than 16 per cent within the last year, and have approved an increasee of 7 per cent more starting next month--are considering still another rise because of higher fuel costs.

The long-sought wreck of the U.S.S. Monitor, the Union vessel in history's first duel between ironclads, during the Civil War, has been found on the bottom of the Atlantic off Cape Hatteras, N. C., an oceanographic researcher at Duke University reported today.

The parents of John Caizadilla waited for word today from the kidnappers of their 8-yearold son, as agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and 60 Suffolk County policemen pressed their search without any apparent hard leads. Police officers outside the home of the kidnapped boy, , in Dix Hills, L. I.
The Center for Analysis of Public Issues, an independent public interest research organization, today announced that it was seeking public contributions to keep operating.

The week-long decline in commodity prices ended yesterday in a burst of buying that sent most bids to limit or nearlimit highs. With many small speculators driven from the markets by the recent sell-off, brokers reported new buying interest from trade and professional sources. "One day doesn't make a trend," one broker pointed out, "but I think the fundamental pressures of inflation and supply-demand are once again behind prices."

A day after settling the coal miners' strike, Britain's new Labor party Government announced that the three-day work week would end at midnight tonight. The move came amid indications that other unions were beginning to press for new contracts in view of the 35 per cent wage increase granted the miners.

Mayor Edward Hanna of Utica said yesterday that he was directing all city department heads not to talk to reporters of the city's two newspapers because of what he termed their "inaccurate, irresponsible and lopsided reporting out of City Hall."
LONDON, March 7 -- The three-day work week imposed on most of British industry because of the nationwide coalmine strike will end at midnight tomorrow under a Government directive issued today.
Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko's diplomatic shuttle race with Secretary of State Kissinger is being widely read here as evi. dence of Moscow's concern over how to main.

The American business community has been accused of narrow self-interest following the publication of a survey by the American Chamber of Commerce in Australia, The report concluded that the climate for investment had deteriorated and said the Government was out of tune with the problems and needs of business.
Milton F. Meissner, 60, former president of five major Investors Overseas Services mutual funds, has been released from custody in Luxembourg on $50,000 bail, his lawyer's office reported today.
Manhattan College, with its bid to the National Invitation Tournament already secured, scored an 81-76 victory over Fordham before 12,739 fans in Madison Square Garden last night.

All Bill Boylan could hope for this college basketball season was to finish with a winning record. No one could blame him for his modest goal because Boylan's team, Monmoulh College, wasn't performing like a basketball unit.
John L. Sullivan of Olympia, Wash., has a famous name and like the Boston Strong Boy of yesteryear, the present John L. has the credentials to back it up-22 fights, 22 victories.
