Streaking-the new spring rite of sprinting in the nude, preferably before a big gawking audience--was praised, put down and generally laid bare yesterday in a series of interviews with psychiatrists, sociologists and other educated guessers, including some streakers.

The Fort Worth National Corporation, Texas' sixth largest bank holding company with $1.25-billion in assets, has received approval from the Federal Reserve Board to acquire the Southern National Bank of Houston.

New York State and New Jersey have been allocated less gasoline for each day of March than they received in February, even though the nation's inventories of gasoline have risen to the highest level in almost two years.

Plans for public offerings of equity securities by both Occidental Petroleum Corporation and the Hooker Chemical Corporation, to be registered under the Securities Act of 1933, were announced yesterday. Fourthranked North Carolina defeated Wake Forest, 76-62, and fifth-ranked Maryland whipped Duke, 85-66, today in the quarterfinals of the Atlantic Coast Conference basketball tournament.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation said today that the Internal Revenue Service, which yesterday revoked a 1969 tax ruling facilitating the take-over of the Hartford Fire Insurance Company in 1970, had asserted that there were flaws in the proceedings leading to the merger.

State aid for the education of handicapped children-which many parents feared was in jeopardy after a ruling by the State Education Commissioner last fallwill not be cut and may, in fact, be increased sharply in the next fiscal year, legislative officials said today.

Wielding a shotgun and a pistol, a former mental patient with a criminal record marched an employee of a gun store through the center of town this afternoon and then, inside a church and surrounded by policemen, shot himself to death in the head, the police said.

Representative Olin E. Teague, chairman of the House Science and Astronautics Committee, has been awarded the Goddard Memorial Trophy by the National Space Club for his contributions to the United States space effort.

The Senate's veto of the pay increase President Nixon had recommended for Congressmen is an act of political cowardice more than of self-abnegation. The cost of living has soared by nearly a third since the lawmakers got their last salary boost in 1969, plainly entitling them to more money now.
Secretary General Waldheim, back from an inspection of drought-stricken areas of West Africa, said today that thousands were dying and "the worst is definitely not over."

United States industry has raised slightly its planned investment in plant and equipment this year, compared with projections of three months ago, despite energy and other problems, the Commerce Department reported today.

Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., Democrat of New Jersey, today introduced a bill that would give the Securities and Exchange Commission authority to prohibit securities listed on national exchanges from being traded over-the-counter in the third market.
The Bank of France called in police today to deal with more than 1,000 strikers here as another strike at the big Credit Lyonnais Bank delayed a major loan to the Government.

The defense in the murder trial of Clark Squire rested its case today after presenting only one witness. Before the defense rested, it obtained a dismissal from Judge John E. Bachman in Middlesex County Court of one of the murder counts against Mr. Squire, a 36-year-old alleged black militant who is accused of having killed a state trooper during a shootout on the New Jersey Turnpike near here last May.

Continuing fair and unseasonably warm weather is forecast for the Metropolitan New York area and most of the Northeast again today, It will continue to be quite warm from the south Atlantic Coast States to the southern Plains States.
Diplomata here look upon the change in government in Britain this week as raising the prospect of further stagnation for the already troubled European Common Market.

Broadway-Hale Stores, Inc., the West Coast retail chain that owns Bergdorf Goodman and Neiman-Marcus, announced an agreement here yesterday to purchase 24 million shares, or 20 per cent, of the common stock of the House of Fraser, Ltd., Glasgow, for $78-million in cash.

Senator Jacob E. Javits has blocked the reappointment of Kieran O'Doherty, vice chairman of the Conservative party, to a $36,000 patronage post as a member of the United States Foreign Claims Settlement Commission.

The Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation was charged with 40 counts of criminally negligent homicide yesterday as a result of the explosion at its Bloomfield, S.I., liquidnatural-gas tank last writer that killed 40 workmen.
The Spanish Government reportedly has threatened to break the accord that has governed Spain's traditionally close relations with the Roman Catholic Church.

After the first Clinton-Taft basketball game this season, it was apparent that, with a little luck in the draw, the two teams could play for the Public Schools Athletic League title. Tomorrow at noon at St. John's Alumni Hall in Queens the Bronx schools play for that crown.

Tonight the Columbia Broadcasting System has two "special" hours on tap: "Really, Raquel," an "identity trip" with Raquel Welch, at 9 o'clock; and "Shanghai," a C.B.S.-Reports portrait of that city; at 10 o'clock. The world team championship to be played in Venice in May is likely to be a contest on three levels. At the top level, and likely to fight for the world title in the final playoff, will be Italy and North America.

North Vietnam today gave partial identifications of 12 dead American prisoners whose bodies were flown to Thailand yesterday.
The formation of a rape squad headed by a woman within the Nassau County District Attorney's office was announced today by the prosecutor William Cahn.
A group of 742 former insurgents swore loyalty to President Lon Nol's Government today in the largest defection of anti-Government forces since the Cambodian war began in April, 1970.

A former French foreign minister, Maurice Schumann, was elected to the French Academy yesterday, succeeding the late Ambassador Wladimir Dormesson. Mr. Schumann gained national fame during World War II, as spokesman for the Free French on radio programs beamed nightly from London to France.

Toby Henry, leader of the rent strike at the Stella Wright housing project that lasted four years, said today that the tenants' decision to resume rent payments was in anticipation of the Newark Housing Authority's plan to end operation of the project next month.
Leslie Hunt of Australia defeated Wendy Overton of New York, 4-6, 7-5, 7-5, in second-round play of the Maureen Connally Brinker women's tennis tournament today.

President Nixon, in an apparent attempt to limit the scope of the impeachment inquiry, has refused to give the House Judiciary Committee tape recordings or documents that do not bear directly on the Watergate cover-up, the committee disclosed today.

Vincent D. McDonnell, chairman of the State Mediation Board, was named yesterday by Mayor Beame as a member of the city's Board of Collective Bargaining. He will still retain his chairmanship on the state board.

The commander of the United Nations force in the Middle East today celebrated the successful Egyptian and Israeli troop pullback along the Suez Canal front by praising both sides for "their unfailing understanding and cooperation."

Newspaper deliverymen at The Daily News walked off their jobs last night in protest against work-schedule changes for 11 truck drivers. Most deliveries of today's editions of The News were halted.

The 18 sequestered jurors serving in the John N. Mitchell-Maurice H. Stans trial eat dinner at well-known restaurants. Each has a room of his own at a good midtown hotel. And this weekend or next they may go out on the town, to see a movie or a play.

An official of The New York th Times warned Typographical Union No. 6 yesterday that if there was any interruption or interference with normal employment or production operations of the newspaper, The rimes intended to take the matter to court.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation campaigned for nearly four years to harass and disrupt black militant organizations and their leaders, according to secret agency files disclosed today.

Six more members of Governor a Byrne's cabinet disclosed their financial status in statements released today by the Governot's office. Cabinet members are to make a financial statement at the beginning of each year they serve in office. Mr. Byrne previously put his own net worth at $240,000.

The nation's money supply -- the total volume of balances in checking accounts plus currency in the hands of the public -- declined sharply in the week ended Wednesday, ending three weeks of explosive growth.
Juha Mieto of Finland became the second ski runner to successfully defend his crown in the 15-kilometer event today in the annual Holmenkollen Nordic ski games.
A colonial drummer boy, Independence Hall and a Liberty Bell-Moon combination were announced today as choices for designs for the nation's 1976 bicentennial coins.
Tiruvallur Thattai Krishnamachari, former finance minister of India and a close associate of the late Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru, died today of kidney failure.

Doar, special counsel on impeachment, was not made public because it contained specific references to items of evidence.

Miness. Rabbi Joseph P. Sternstein of Roslyn Heights and Rabbi Andrew J. Robbins of New Hyde Park performed the ceremony.

The Police Department's Oranized Crime Control Bureau has begun an investigation into the role of professional gamblers and, possibly, organized crime in the running of "Las Vegas Nites" in Brooklyn, a spokesman said yesterday.

The shortage of gasoline has only had a slight effect on chain-store sales, a survey of leading companies in the field showed yesterday. February volume was ahead of the level of sales in February, 1973, but the gains were not as large as those registered in January.

The shift of a conference of Arab oil ministers to Cairo from Tripoli, Libya, was made at Egyptian request, informed sources said today. Whether the shift was politically motivated was not immediately clear.
A high official of the State Department of Transportation said today it "may be prudent" to cancel a $20,000 grant for a study by the University of Pennsylvania of land use.

Jerome V. Keating, who retired as a national news copy editor for The New York Times in 1962, died yesterday in Queens General Hospital, after a short illness. He was 87 years old and lived at 88-10 178th Street, Jamaica.

William A. H. Williams and his wife, Betty Ruth, were indicted today by a Federal grand jury on charges related to the abduction of J. Reginald Murphy, editor of the editorial page of The Atlanta Constitution.

The gasoline shortage, even if it weren't real, could well take the "mo" (for motor and money) out of the motel business. That's why a few of the major chains have initiated programs-or are planning them-to get travelers traveling.
More than a year after agreeing to establish relations, East and West Germany finally came to an accord today on establishing permanent diplomatic missions in each ether's capitals.

Ethiopian workers began a general strike today, increasing pressure on Emperor Haile Selassie and the new Cabinet of Premier Endalkachew Makonnen to give or at least promise economic and social changes in the shortest possible time.
A group of Democratic Governors contended today that they and their close associates were being systematically "harassed" by Federal police agencies and the Republican party.

To the Editor: You missed the point in your Feb. 17 editorial on "Planning City Growth," questioning the California court decision which invalidated the Petaluma "no growth" ordinance. The issue is not whether controlled development is better than uncontrolled growth but whether each community, individually, can establish growth ceilings, given the obvious need for some over-all provision for growth.

Thomas W. Danby, circulation director of The New York Post from 1956 to 1958 and later for several years executive director of the New York Metropolitan Newspapers Association, died yesterday at his home, 66 Orleans Road. His age was 80.

Reaction ranging from dismay to pleasure marked the responses yesterday of Governors and energy officials in the tristate region to the announcement of March gasoline allocations by the Federal Energy Office in Washington.

Most women who take needlepoint seriously have long since filled their own places with pillows, chair seats, footstools, telephone book covers, rugs, benches, straps for luggage racks and bell pulls - even when there aren't any bells.

The Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railroad said yesterday it had made a preliminary application to the newly formed United States Railway Association for a $100-million loan. The loan, if made, would be granted by the Government agency under Section 211 of the Regional Rail Reorganization Act of 1973, signed into law by President Nixon on Jan. 2.

A key prosecution witness in the contribution-tax fraud trial of Nelson G. Gross was pictured by the defense attorney today as a corporate wheeler-dealer who used Mr. Gross rather than being victimized by him.
Curtis Hayden, a Princeton junior, and Hess Yntema, a Harvard sophomore, set meet records tonight as Princeton took a 31-point lead after the first day of the Eastern swimming 'championships.

Prices fell yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-the-counter market in lighter trading. The Amex market value index fell 0.55 to 98.43. Price declines topped advances by 380 to 325, while 317 issues were unchanged.

When Bill Virdon arrived in the Yankees' spring training camp, he brought with him a number of drills the players weren't accustomed to under their previous leader, Ralph Houk. Virdon sent his team through one of those drills today, a drill that could be called a name of bazooka baseball.

The Democratic state chairman, Joseph F. Crangle, is encouraging party leaders to consider a woman to run against Senator Jacob K. The state House of Representatives turned down tonight Aristotle Oassis' bid to build a $600-million oil refinery in the face of overwhelming local opposition. W. R. Grace Co. ended last year with "exceptionally vigorous" fourth quarter sales and earnings lifting the annual net income by 29 per cent. In reporting the record results yesterday, J. Peter Grace, chairman, attributed the increase largely to the company's chemically-based products and services.

Aqueduct, Belmont and Saratoga race tracks will open their doors for the first time to a wide variety of entertainment events after each of their racing meetings ends.

PUNTA GORDA, Fla. -- Palm fronds streamed and ruffled in a vigorous north wind and the temperature was in the high 30's when we converged at the Punta Gorda Isles Marina shortly after dawn to decide whether to go fishing.
Following are texts of two indictments handed up today by the Watergate grand jury, one citing six persons for conspiracy and the other citing for refusing to testify before a House subcommittee.

Six persons, including John D. Ehrlichman and Charles W. Colson, who were once among President Nixon's most trusted aides, were indicted today for the 1971 break-in at the office of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg's former psychiatrist.

The Charles de Gaulle Airport, which will be the biggest in Europe and one of the biggest in the world, went on public view today. Its initial incoming flight, from New York, is scheduled to touch down Wednesday.

Prices fell yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-the-counter market in lighter trading. The Amex market value index fell 0.55 to 98.43. Price declines topped advances by 380 to 325, while 317 issues were unchanged.
A 27-year-old Verona policeman was shot to death early today with his own revolver here in what the Essex County Prosecutor's office described as "some sort of Russian roulette game."
President Nixon, in an apparent attempt to limit the scope of the impeachment inquiry, has refused to give the House Judiciary Committee tape

Repairmen dug deep yesterday to find the ancient water main that erupted Wednesday night in Central Park and caused extensive damage to some parts of the park, flooded a large area of the nearby East Side and trapped five cars on the 96th Street transverse under as much as nine feet of water.

John L. Sullivan came into Madison Square Garden last night with an illustrious name and a reputation to match the legendary John L., the Boston strongboy. But he left the Garden, Where he was making his first appearance, with the first defeat of his 23-bout career.

SCHOOLING All sorts of school benefits, with entertainment, -this weekend. At New York University's Loeb Student Center, Washington Square South and La Guardia Place, tomorrow at 8: Alan Arkin, Jack Gilford ("The Sunshine Boys"), Paul Dooley ("Raisin"), the Paper Bag Players, Michael's Pub Jazz Band, the Untouchables. All for the Village Community School's fifth Village Lights Show, , M.C. Admission, $10 to $50 (9823843).

The Ford Motor Company said today that 16,000 workers at four assembly plant and seven parts and manufacturing plants face one-and two-week layoffs this month because of the continued cutback in big-car production.

(UPI)-Rick Barry scored 28 points and Jim Barnett 26 as the Golden State Warriors defeated the Philadelphia 76ers, 106-96, tonight and remained on top of the National Basketball Association's Pacific Division.
The United States Embassy in Tel Aviv has notified Washington that pork has risen to a "rather astonishing" 30 per cent of Israeli meat production. The agricultural attache, in a report on livestock.

International Premier Golda Meir of Israel charged that Syria had planned military action earlier this week to recapture the enclave of Syrian territory that Israel seized during the October war. Mrs. Meir said that Israel had immediately asked "foreign governments" to do what they could to avoid a new outbreak of fighting.

James W. McCord Jr., the convicted Watergate conspirator. has accused President Nixon of having "fatally infected" his trial proceedings early last year by suppressing and concealing evidence of the Watergate cover-up.

The price of gold and the dollar lost some ground today on most foreign markets. Gold had been higher at the outset, but dropped sharply in many places later. By late afternoon in London gold had lost $6.50 an ounce to $164 and in Zurich gold closed at $166 an ounce, down $4 during the day.
If ever a team,' its town and fans were laying for the New York Rangers, it is the Montreal Cahadiens. Humiliated by last Wednesday's 9-2 shellacking, mocked by their hot-headed fans.
In his transcendental career in the National Basketball Association, Kareem Abdul.Jabbar has played in only one winning regularseason game at Madison Square Garden.

PARIS-The young French revolutionary theorist, Regis Debray, has been refused a U.S. visitor's visa under the 1952 Immigration and Nationality Act' passed by Congress during the peak of McCarthyist red-baiting.

Ted Gleason, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, said today that his union would cooperate with management in every way possible to assure the success of a facility--now being built here --to handle frozen imported meats.
The body of a 20-year-old Staten Island woman, her throat slashed, apparently by a burglar that she found in her home, was discovered yesterday morning by her husband.

After failing to reach agreement on a contract, Gabe Paul sent a letter to Sparky Lyle, notifying him that he had invoked the renewal option clause. It means that if Lyle reports to the Yankees, he would play for a salary designated by the club until he signs a 1974 contract. It can be anything from 80 per cent of last year's salary on up.

BASEBALL Yankees vs. Baltimore Orioles, preseason, at Fort Lauderdale. (Radio--WMCA, 1:30 P.M.) BASKETBALL Knicks vs. Milwaukee Bucks, at Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street, 8 P.M. (Television -- Channel 10 (cable), 8 P.M.) (Radi--WNBC. 7:55 P.M.)
Qn the eve of their first exhibition game, the New York Mets were pronounced physically fit today by the men who spent all last summer mending them: the team doctors.
Monika Kaserer and AnneMarie Proell of Austria finished one, two in a giant slalom today and wound up two, one in the final standing for the. World Cup of Alpine skiing.

KOMPONG THOM, Cambodia - Two strange sights greet the visitor to this cutoff province capital 75 miles north of Phnom Penh. First, as the plane ap proaches for a The Talk landing, one sees of long, green strips Kompong stretching out Thom like signals on the brown earth.

Dr. Betsy Ancker-Johnson, who as Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Science and Technology supervises the Patent Office, was herself granted a patent Patents this week. She retains no perof the sonal interest in Week Patent 3,795,803, as it is assigned to the Boeing Company, Seattle, her former employer. The application was filed in 1972, and President Nixon nominated her for office the following year.

The Federal Energy Office administrator here, Gerald J. Turetsky, said yesterday that he had sufficient evidence to warrant civil and possible criminal complaints against several large oil companies for allegedly "lying" and "cheating" about gasoline supplies here in the last two months.

The New York Giants, who are searching for speed and winning material, may have uncovered a champion in Larance Jones, their 15thround draft choice, who won the National Collegiate indoor 440-yard dash title tonight.

--A Middlesex County court jury late this afternoon began deliberating a verdict in the murder trial of Clark E. Squire a reputed member of the Black Liberation Army. At 9:30 P.M., after delibrating four hours without reaching a verdict, the jury was ordered retired until 9 A.M tomorrow.

Thirteen Algerian journalists and 3 radio reporters covering President Houari Boumediene's tour of Asian capitals died today when their special plane crashed at Hanoi's military airfield, the Algerian news agency announced here tonight.
The semiofficial Cairo newspaper Al Ahram said tonight that Arab oil ministers would decide at a meeting here on Sunday to lift the embargo against the export of oil to the United States.

Motorists can look forward to the best weekend in more than a month, the Automobile Club of New York said yesterday, after its surveys showed that more gasoline stations would be open and operating longer hours than they had been.

International Premier Golda Meir of Israel charged that Syria had planned military action earlier this week to recapture the enclave of Syrian territory that Israel seized during the October war. Mrs. Meir said that Israel had immediately asked "foreign governments" to do what they could to avoid a new outbreak of fighting.

-The Justice Department contended today that Congress would interfere with President Nixon's powers if it granted amnesty for Vietnam war deserters and draft evaders.

Arab oil-producing nations are more interested in hightechnology investment in their. own countries than in large-scale investment in the United States, according to Alfred F. Miossi, an executive vice president of the Continental Bank of Chicago.

The Turkish jumbo jet that crashed near Paris Sunday, killing a record total of 346 persons, apparently had not had its rear cargo door completely modified in accord with safety recommendations of the manufacturer, sources close to the inquiry said yesterday.
8-Elon G. Borton, former president and general manager of the Advertising Federation of America, died here Tuesday at a nursing home. He was 85 years old.

Jerome J. Lande, a labor arbitrator and a member of the Republican State Committee, died of a heart attack yesterday in his office at 292 Madison Avenue. He was 66 years old and lived at 315 Riverside Drive.

Commissioner Joseph A. Hoffman of the State Department of Labor and Industry today promised state action to assure a banner summer vacation season at the New Jersey shore despite the gasoline shortage.

White House staff members staged a farewell for Mrs. Nixon today as she and President Nixon left for a Florida weekend. It was also the first leg of a Latin-American trip for Mrs. Nixon as the President's ambassador.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation announced last night the arrest of two brothers from New Jersey in connection with the kidnapping of 8-yearold John Calzadilla of Dix Hills, L. I.

ABLOWICH-Robert. Beloved husband of Miriam. Devoled father of Irene Gilbert. Dear brother of Joe. Services Sunday, 11 A.M. at Gutterman's "Lincoln Square Chapels," Broadway at 66 St. ABRAMOFF-Natanel. Beloved husband of Dora, devoted father of Daniel, Michel, Elaine, Edith Goldman and Evelyn Frankel. Loving brother of Sonia, Frleda and Miriam, adored grandfather.

A Middlesex County grand jury indicted three former Madison Township officials yesterday on charges of attempting to influence other local officials into voting approval of several major real-estate subdivisions.

The Atlanta Flames beat the Minnesota North Stars 3-1, tonight for their third straight victory and climbed back into third place in the West Division of the National Hockey League. The victory put Atlanta 1 point ahead of the idle Los Angeles Kings.

James W. McCord Jr., the convicted Watergate conspirator. has accused President Nixon of having "fatally infected" his trial proceedings early last year by suppressing and concealing evidence of the Watergate cover-up.

President Nixon's press secretary accused newsmen today of "too much dwelling on Watergate" during a White House news conference Wednesday night, and said he hoped for more balance in the questioning as the President met the press more often in the months ahead.

The conviction of any corporation, or any of its officers or directors, for making an illegal political campaign contribution is a material fact that should be disclosed to the public and its stockholders, the Securities and Exchange Commission's division of corporate finance said today.

President Nixon proposed today to lead the cleanup of political campaigns. In a message to Congress and in a radio speech to the nation, he recommended more detailed financial disclosures, some limits on what individual contributors could give, a severe curb on the flow of cash in campaigns and some rules against "dirty tricks."
WASHINGTON-What happens when a hippopotamus thinks he ought to run like a greyhound? Quite simply, he makes mistakes. For years, Congress has been criticized for acting too slowly.

The early morning raid at Shawnee, Pa., last week was carried out with the military precision of an action against a fortified enemy outpost. The jovial fellow in a tricorne hat, breeches and buckled shoes, balancing a mug of beer on his chubby knees-that's Toby, a character of such enduring appeal in ceramic jugs that he has been modeled by British and American potters for about 250 years.

Mrs. Helen Owen Carey, the wife of Representative Hugh L. Carey, Democrat of Brooklyn, died of cencer last night at Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 49 years old. Edward Day Thurston Jr., a retired mechanical engineer who had been a consulting engineer with Columbia University, the Gulf Oil Company and other concerns, died Wednesday at his home here. His age was 91.

The administrative assistant to Representative Frank J. Brasco said here yesterday at Mr. Brasco's conspiracy-corruption trial that Mr. Brasco adopted a hands-off policy toward a trucking company after learning it was controlled by a reputed Mafia captain.

Thirteen-year-old Robert Thornton said, "I was thinkof taking the classes, but my friends aren't and I never got around to it. The first week we looked in the windows and one of us made funny noises. I didn't like that. I don't think anybody should make funny noises at them. If they want to learn those dances, O.K., let them do it."
There is a basic Jewish tradition: "Everything can teach us the love of God and the service of God." In this spirit, let us now ask, what are the religious implications of the New York Mets?

Yogi Berra considered the fact that Las Vegas oddsmakers had installed the Cincinnati Reds and Pittsburg Pirates as the favorites in the National League, and he didn't argue. "I suppose they are the favorites," he said. "They've got the hitting."

The former president of the Triple S Blue Stamp Company testified today that Nelson G. Gross advised him to disguise a $5,000 contribution to former Gov. W liam T. Cahill's 1969 campaign and later to lie about it to a Federal grand jury.
David Thompson scored 37 points and led topranked North Carolina State to an 87-86 victory over Virginia in the semifinals of the Atlantic Coast Conference basketball tournament tonight.

Charges of fraud and other vionations of Federal securities laws were brought today against the Republic Life Insurance Company of Dallas; the Realty Equities Corporation of New York; two accounting firms and 11 individuals.

The temptation to identify an artist's entire life's work with the most extreme and specialized aspect of his development was especially strong in the case of Ad Reinhardt. In the decade preceding his death in 1967, Reinhardt had perfected a mode of abstract painting that seemed, at first glance at least, committed to a radical invisibility.
The OaKiana A S owner, Charles 0. Finley, released his former manager, Dick Williams, from his contract, tonight, permitting him to join any club except the New York Yankees.

The 36th annual National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament, which begins tomorrow at six sites from New York City to Pocatello, Idaho, may have in action as few as two of the nation's five top-ranked teams and certainly will not have more than three.

Picasso would have been delighted. The single restaurant in all France to be elevated to three stars this year in the just-published 1974 Michelin,Guide was one of the great artist's favorites. The Hostellerie Moulin de Mougins lies nestled in a flowery hollow just down a twisting country road from the villa where he died last April in the hills back of the French Riviera.

One long chapter of the Vietnam war ended today with the release of the last prisoners who were officially listed as captured before the ceasefire of January, 1973. Culminating four weeks of exchanges, the South Vietnamese Government announced that it had flown 121 prisoners to Loc Ninh, a Vietcong administrative capital 75 miles north of Saigon.
Who is this Jerry Heard? He is a talented golfer with a bubbly, carefree manner, full of a confidence that was enhanced by a tour victory less than a week ago.
Prices on the American Stock Exchangee and the over-thecounter market bounded back yesterday after having fallen on Thursday. The Amex market value index rose 0.81 to 99.24.

The outer lane on the lower level of the Queensboro Bridge traffic for emergency repairs will be closed to Queens-bound for three days, the Traffic Department announced yesterday. The Consolidated Edison Company closed the bridge at 7 A.M. yesterday to repair faulty power cables under the roadway.

The town of Vosne-Romanee in the center of the Cote de Nuits, has often been called the pearl in the Burgundian necklace because so many great wines originate there. The greatest of these, almost without exception, is RomaneeConti. Alexis Lichine calls the 41/2-acre Romande-Conti vineyard. "the most precious in the world," and the price of the wine reflects that assessment. Recent quotes for the 1970 were around $60 a bottle.
Edward M. Syring Jr., chief economist for the Marine Midland Banks, has taken a look at profit prospects of the business community, and what he finds is that the past is not prologue.

(AP) - Michael Ferguson of Australia carded a second straight three-under-par 69 and took a one-stroke lead today after two rounds of the Malaysian open. Tied for second were Wally Kuchar of Edgewater, Fla., and Graham Marsh of Australia.

Graham A. Martin, the United States Ambassador in South Vietnam, has complained to the State Department that an article in New York Times on continued American involvement in Vietnam "contains numerous inaccuracies and halftruths."
Negotiators reached agreement today on a formula to end a brief general strike that had severely affected transportation, food and tourist industries in this East African nation.
More than 2,600 mourners filled Carnegie Hall yesterday to attend the brief, simple funeral of Sol Hurok, the 85-year-old impresario who died of a heart attack Tuesday.

Vice President Ford said today that he did not believe there would be further Watergate "bombshells." "I know of no more bombshells," he said. "I don't think there will be any."
The United States will soon anounce a relaxation of travel restrictions for Soviet diplomats in this country to match similar Steps taken by Moscow last month. State Department officials report.

The production-cutback aspect of the Arab "oil weapon" has been almost totally effective, the Exxon Corporation indicated yesterday. Using data from industry and trade sources, Exxon estimated that the output of crude oil by the Arab countries of the Persian Gulf and Libyaexcluding Iraq, which did not participate- was cut by 4.3 million barrels a day, or 25 per cent, between September and November.
The 96th street transverse in Central Park was reopened to traffic at 7 o'clock last night, the police reported. It had been closed since Wednesday night after a water-main break.

Representative predicted today that a Congressional report next month on President Nixon's income tax payments would increase pressure for him to resign. For that and other reasons, he said, he believes "very strongly" that Mr. Nixon will resign.
The head of the nation's second-largest aluminum producer said earlier this week that the primary aluminum price should be allowed to reach the 35-cent-a-pound level.

Clifford Ann Creed, who hasn't won a tournament since 1967, battled high winds and rain for a oneunder-par 72 today and took the first-round lead in a $100,000 women's professional golf event.

The effort of Mayor Beame and other ranking officials to check the dismaying decline of jobs in New York City has produced one impressive victory and seems on its way to another. A thousand jobs in the Rheingold brewery in Brooklyn have been saved through a takeover arrangement worked out by the city with Chock Full O'Nuts-a welcome, if somewhat strange, case of beer floating on coffee.

A new Brooklyn schoolzoning plan that establishes that by 1977 each academic high school in the borough must have an enrollment at least 30 per cent black and Puerto Rican was announced yesterday by Chancellor Irving Anker.

William J. Fellner came to New York yesterday and tried to shoot down both the optimists and the pessimists among his economist peers. The economy, said Mr. Fellner, a member of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, is not likely to collapse into recession this year; nor is the month of March necessarily the end of the current slowdown.

ROME, March 8-Alberto Rabagliati, a singer who brought American swing to Italy in the nineteen-thirties and lately made a nostalgic comeback to the pop-music scene here, died today of cerebral thrombosis. He was 67 years old.
Some of Canada's best-known novelists, poets and critics gathered in the high school of this agreeable Lake Erie community today for a proud and exuberant celebration of Canadian literature.

President Nixon, voicing concern over the fresh wave of kidnapping, has ordered Attorney General William B. Saxbe to press for reinstitution of the death penalty in cases where a kidnapping victim is killed, a White House official said today.

Separate studies by a group at Boston University Medical Center and a team from Britain's Medical Research Council have strengthened speculation that aspirin may play a role in preventing heart attacks.

Dr. Wilson Marcy Powell, professor emeritus of physics at the University of California here, died last Saturday at the age of 70.

Admission charges at Britain's public museums and galleries are expected to be abolished next month. The new Labor party Government's Minister for the Arts, Hugh Jenkins, said today that abolition was his first priority in his new post.

About a half dozen years after it started, the Metropolitan Opera has finally brought its new "Ring" cycle to a close. Last night "Gotterdammerung" was staged, and it followed, more or less, the lines of the previous three operas of the Wagner cycle.

For the last several weeks, John Edwards, a 35-year-old planner, has been supervising the construction of his new offices-5,000 square feet of space at 150 West 127th Street in Harlem. That job, he says, is fun.
The New York Philharmonic is running a kind of youth festival in its subscription concerts this weekend, and the results, as sampled at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday night, are engaging.

R. R. Timpany, the trustee of the bankrupt Central Railroad of New Jersey, has told the Federal District Court in Newark that the carrier "can not be reorganized within a reasonable time" under Section 77 of the Federal Bankruptcy laws.

The opening session of the spring educational conference of the United Federation of Teachers heard Schools Chancellor Irving Anker make an appeal for public' debate on the crisis of de facto segregation in urban schools throughout the North.

South Africa took a 2-0 lead against Chile in the South American zone final of the Davis Cup tennis series today on singles victories by Cliff Drysdale and Bob Hewitt in the opening of the elimination round.
A New York policeman was fatally shot early today while wrestling with a holdupman outside a tavern in Jamaica, Queens. He was the first policeman slain this year.

The Mobil Oil Corporation pleaded guilty in First District Court here today to a charge by the Nassau County Office of Consumer Affairs that a company-owned station in Baldwin had sold gasoline contaminated with fuel oil.

Bernard Relin, a public-relations executive who became chairman and president of the Rheingold Corporation and a director and executive of several other major corporations, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 59 years old and lived at 720 Park Avenue.

Mount Vernon High School defeated Poughkeepsie, 92-75, to win the Class AAA open championship and Peekskill edged Oakwood, 59-58, to capture the Class B-C open at the state Section 1 basketball tournament tonight at the Westchester County Center.

Yugoslav housewives and working women, who must normally put up with one of the most unabashedly male-oriented societies in the world, observed Women's Day today by coaxing their husbands to take them out of lunch.
The Westinghouse Electric Corporation announced yesterday that reduced sales had forced it to furlough 500 employes at seven of its lamp manufacturing plants, including three in New Jersey.

udge Sonia Morgan of the Essex County Court was nominated today by Governor Byrne to become the first woman in New Jersey to serve as a Superior Court judge. Judge Morgan was appointed to the Essex County court in 1972 by Gov. William T. Cahill.

Tom Nelson, a co-captain of the Maryland-Eastern Shore basketball team, which competes next week in the National Invitational Tournament, was charged today with ripping down copper drain pipes at the school and selling them for scrap Nelson.

Daniel Barenbolm, the 31year-old Israeli-born pianist and conductor, will succeed Sir Georg Solti as chief conductor of France's top symphony orchestra, the Orchestre de Paris. The appointment was announced yesterday by the new Minister of Culture, Alain Peyrefitte.

But the real question is: has Mr. Nixon so acted that he has in fact greatly weakened the office of the Presidency? Mrs. Katharine Kelly Reaegeld; a former fashion editor and writer who was the wife of Joseph A. Redegeld, a retired financial executive of the International Telephone and Telegraph Company, died today in Lawrence Hospital, Bronxville. She lived at 6 Norwood Road.

Samuel Segal, a well-known criminal lawyer who also tried maritime negligence cases, died Saturday of a heart ailment in Beekman Downtown Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived at 200 Central Park South. His office was at 11 Broadway.

President Nixon suggested in June, 1969, that members of his staff be given access to the tax returns of former Presidents so he could learn what deductions his predecessors had taken, according to an internal White House memorandum now in the hands of Congressional investigators.

Clark E. Squire, a 35-yearold black militant, was found guilty today of first-degree murder by a Middlesex County court jury in the killing of a New Jersey state trooper in a shootout on the New Jersey Turnpike near here last May 2.

Dr. samuel J. Mason, a proressor at Massachusetts Institute of Technology who developed experimental reading systems for the blind, died yesterday at Massachusetts General Hospital. He was 53 years old.

?? Officials in Peking who deal with Americaln businessmen have been going out of their way to assure them that the revivalistic "revolutionary storm" now being promoted in China will not be allowed to damage the country's burgeoning trade with the United States.
The gasoline shortage has created many changes in the way Americans shop, even in areas where the pinch is relatively light.

Bernard Danenberg, the Madison Avenue art dealer, says he and his wife are "collecting collections." Not paintings and sculptures-that's nothing unusual among dealers - but tools, mechanical banks and pottery, the sort of offbeat collectibles that have increasing popular appeal of late.

The Consolidated Edison Company yesterday disclosed that its 2.9 million electricity customers would be charged an additional 3.5 per cent for increased fuel costs this month, bringing the average residential customer's bill to $20.65.

A Vatican official arrived here today for talks with church leaders as the Government considered a statement by Spanish bishops over a controversial sermon. The sermon, circulated by the Bishop of Bilbao, the Most Rev, Antonio Anoveros Ataun called for wider freedom for Basques.

Emperor Haile Selassie said today that while the monarchy was a durable institution needed to hold Ethiopia together, its once overWhelming political power was not "eternal" and could be varied according to the "requirements and exigencies of the time."

Secretary of State Kissinger Said today that the biggest foreign policy problem now confronting the United States was to get the cooperation of its allies. Referring to disagreements With France and other West European countries, Mr. Kissinger. told a meeting of wives of Congressmen at the State Department:
Domenico Monaco of Italy won a unanimous decision over Pedro Guzman of Puerto Rice last night in a 10-round junior-light weight bout at Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum.
A Protestant member of the Irish Senate was seized late today by a dozen armed men who burst into a farmhouse near Northern Ireland where the Senator was visiting, the police reported.
The first-round pairings for the National Invitation Tournament: SATURDAY Afternoon-Manhattan (188) vs. Maryland Eastern Shore (26-1), 2 P.M., and North Carolina (22-5) vs. Purdue (17-9), 4 P.M.

Secretary of State Kissinger will be subpoenaed to testify for Charles W. Colson and John D. Ehrlichman in their trials on charges involving the breakIn at the office of Dr. Daniel J. Ellsberg's former psychiatrist, sources close to the two men said today.

Sales and earnings of Gulf Western Industries, Inc., were the highest for any quarter or half year in its history although profit gains were smaller, according to the company's report yesterday for the three and six months ended Jan. 31.

" For Jewish kids of my generation, the two great golden doors were City College and the 92d Street 'Y,'" Sam Levenson, the 62-year-old writer-humorist, said the other day. He was talking about the Young Men's-Young Women's Hebrew Association (combined during World War II) and the 100th birthday it will begin celebrating this month.
Mrs. Richard M. Nixon arrived here today to lead the United States delegation at the inauguration tomorrow of Carlos Andres Perez as President of Venezuela.
The New York Giants gained two assistant coaches yesterday but lost a linebacker to the World Football League, John Douglas.

Sales and earnings of Gulf Western Industries, Inc., were the highest for any quarter or half year in its history although profit gains were smaller, according to the company's report yesterday for the three and six months ended Jan. 31.

The numbers of cars on metropolitan area roads is steadily increasing as commuters and weekend drivers take advantage of the sufficient supply of gasoline available early in the month, statistics on toll roads, bridge and tunnel travel showed yesterday. However traffic is still below the levels that prevailed before the onset of the gasoline shortage last year.
Investigative officials said to day that an attempt had been made at the Mercer County Jail in Trenton to poison a prisoner who had been a key witness for the state in a robberykidnapping case.

First things first. Bigger can be better. The Chelsea Theater's production of Leonard Bernstein's "Candide," which has just moved from the Chelsea premises at the Brooklyn Academy of Music to the Broadway Theater proves this abundantly.

Declaring that people are now more open to nonviolence than at any time since her husband's death six years ago, at Mrs. Coretta Scott King yester- le day announced a two-day con- at ference to try to utilize the civil rights coalitions of the nineteen-sixties in working on problems of the seventies.
SCAPINO, by Mollere; The Young Vic at the Brooklyn Acadmy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, 8. THE KILLDEER, a play by Jay Broad; at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, 7:30.
A Trenton Mich. family of five died yesterday when their light plane crashed and burned in a southwest Virginia residential area. The plane grazed a house, but no residents were injured.

After a year and a half of studying wholesale corruption in the Philadelphia police force, the Pennsylvania Crime Commission has reached conclusions even more dismaying than those the Knapp Commission drew from its 1972 investigation into police graft in New York City.

Mrs. Florence Glickstein Meister, retired teacher of music in the city schools and wife of Dr. Morris Meister, retired principal of the Bronx High School of Science and former president of the Bronx Community College, died Sunday at the Hospital for Joint Diseases. Her age was 73 and she lived at 315 Riverside Drive.

Federal Judge Leland C. Nielsen in San Diego has approved the sale of the Westgate-California Corporation's 37.5 per cent interest in the Golcanda Corporation to the National Propane Corporation for $9.8-million. National Propane is 89 per cent-owned by the DWG Corporation of Miami.
The nation's largest dairy cooperative wants the White House to turn over tapes and papers relating to dairy farmer contributions in 1971 and 1972, according to documents released today.
Vice President Ford said today that he was still convinced that President Nixon was not involved in Watergate or its cover-up "but time will tell."

Noel Leslie, a retired character actor, who played some 400 roles since he made his debut in "Richard III" at the London Coliseum in his native England, died Sunday in French and Polyclinic Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived at 246 East 23d Street.

If the White House has its way, the Clean Air Act is to be emasculated and the National Environmental Policy Act reduced to a shell-all on the spurious grounds of dealing with the energy crisis. Russell E. Train, administrator of the National Environmental Protection Agency, views the amendments that the President's Office of Management and Budget is reported to be preparing as not only unnecessary but capable of doing "substantial harm."

The Government of Iraq, acting just before the expiration of a deadline set four years ago, proclaimed local self-rule today for the restive Kurdish minority in the mountainous northern region of the country, but on terms far short of the Kurds' demands.
Opponents of a new state law requiring the public disclosure of all funds spent in attempts to influence legislation here succeeded today in preventing the law from taking effect this Friday.

The Uris Buildings Corporation, which since last fall has been trying to dispose of its 50 per cent interests in the New York Hilton and Washington Hilton hotels and the Hilton Inn at Rye, in Westchester County, said yesterday it had entered into definitive agreements for the sale of those interests for $38.5-million to the Prudential Insurance Companv of America.

Gov. Dale Bumpers announced today that he would oppose Senator J. W. Fulbright in the Democratic primary May 28. This will be the most serious challenge to Mr. Fulbright since he entered the Senate in 1945. Arkansas observers predict a close race.

The deterioration of relations between the United States and its European allies must be halted; but at times recently it has seemed that no government or statesman was even willing to try. The caustic exchanges across the Atlantic after the European Economic Community's proposal of long-term economic, technical and cultural cooperation with the Arab world illustrates the point.
Four Atlanta pitchers combined to pitch a no-hitter against the Yankees today. Now for the significant news.

Mrs, Eleanor Millar Lee, who retired 15 years ago as head of the girls' health education department at Andrew Jackson High School, Cambria Heights, Queens, and earlier taught at Jamaica and Textile High Schools, died today in the Sands Point Nursing Home. She was 78 years old and lived here.

The Japanese Government announced today that Mr. Onoda would draw a pension of $610 a year on the basis of 31 years and 3 months of service. The former lieutenant's father, 86-year-old Tanejiro Onoda, and his mother, Tamae, 88, donned new outfits and made the 350-mile trip from their home in Kainan to Tokyo.
Randolph A. Hearst said today that he would attempt to meet the latest demands of his daughter's kidnapers and promised a detailed response within 24 to 48 hours.

Willis Reed has decided to postpone his return to the team until next week in Phoenix at the last stop of a four-game road trip. Reed will work out with the club on Tuesday, March 19, and hopes to play the following night against the Suns. "I've decided I can make more progress working here by myself than by traveling with the team," he said yesterday after practice at Madison Square Garden.

The Los Angeles County District Attorney, Joseph Busch, agreed today to seek dismissal of burglary and conspiracy charges against John D. Ehrlichman and two others arising from the break-in at the office of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg's former psychiatrist.

Roblntech, Inc., said yesterday it had singed contracts with the Western Electric Co., Inc., and various Bell Telephone systems to supply more than $65-million in polyvinyl chloride underground communication conduit and accessories beginning April 1. The contracts are the largest ever negotiated for PVC conduit, according to Robintech.

President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt conferred today with the Oil Ministers of Saudi Arabia and Abu Dhabi on the prospects for relaxing export restrictions, including the embargo against the United States, during a meeting of nine Arab countries to be held Wednesday in Tripoli, Libya.
Olav J. S. aeBrun, Iormerly president of the Egyptian Lacquer Manufacturing Company for 27 years, died yesterday at Westerly (R.I.) Hospital. He was 86 years old and lived in North Stonington, Conn.

When Juan Domingo Peron rose to power in Argentina three decades ago as an army colonel imbued with the ideals of Mussolini's Italy, he relied above all on his appeal to a politically weak but rapidly expanding industrial labor force.

Sunday Pony Hunter Chamlonship--Chanpion, Libby McKinney's Escort, 10 points; reserve, Millbrook Farm's Ardmore Carbon, 7. Limit Working Hunter Championship--ChemPion, Barbara Force's Silver Splash, 6 points; reserve, tie between Karl Redl's Frivolous Sal `and Mrs. H. . Bilby's Credit Card, 5 each.

Second-seeded Kentucky State downed Erskine, S. C., 82-69, and Washburn of Topeka, Kan., upset ninthseeded Fisconsin-Eau Claire, 67-50, in opening-round games of the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics basketball tournament tonight.

LOOK AND LAFF The brand-new Nicholls Gallery, on the fifth floor of 1014 Madison Avenue, near 78th Street (472-0211), has an exhibition that's laughable. Small wonder, the art consists of the original drawings by the people who do covers and cartoons for the New Yorker magazine.

Israel Packel, the Attorney General of Pennsylvania, said today he would appoint a special state prosecutor to investigate and prosecute those responsible for corruption within the Philadelphia Police Department.

The Nixon Administration is considering a negative income tax to replace direct welfare cash payments to the needy, Caspar W. Weinberger, the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare said today.

About 80 union leaders and b 25 city officials attended a a labor reception at Gracie Mansion last night as guests of n Mayor Beame. Waiters circulated through the crowd with platters of e canapes.

The latest in a series of urgent consultations between city and state officials and Presidential aides ended in City Hall yesterday with the usual vague White House promises of support for mass transit-but nothing you could nail a 35-cent fare to.
Harold Wilson at 58 no longer quite fits the role of daring young man on the political trapeze, but anyone judging him solely on his performance of last week would never suspect it.

Novelties abounded at Alice Tully Hall late Sunday afternoon in a long program by the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center. Have you, for instance, ever encountered Haydn's "London" Trios for two flutes and cello (there are four of them), or Wlenlawski's Etudes-Caprices for two violins (there are eight)?

A New York quintet headed by Sam Stayman and including Victor Mitchell, Jim Cayne, Matt Granovetter and Joel Stuart won the Grand National Team Championship for the New York district in the early hours of yesterday morning.

For no apparent reason, the stock market rebounded yesterday from opening and closed on the upside at 888.45. This was a gain of 10.40 in the Dow-Jones industrial average and marked the highest point that the market indicator had reached since last Nov. 13, when it closed at 891.03.
Both the Soviet Union and China, apparently spurred by the world energy shortage, have been gearing up for major offshore oil and gas drilling and production programs in the Pacific basin.

Leon Jaworski, the Watergate special prosecutor, advised the Federal grand jury investigating the Watergate break-in and cover-up that it would not be "responsible conduct" to move to indict President Nixon, according to a spokesman for the office.
The state of emergency in Britain, declared nearly four months ago because of growing economic problems, was formally ended tonight.
At the dedication of its new 50-story, curve-fronted headquarters opposite Bryant Park last week, W. R. Grace Co. presented guests with transistor radios in the shape of the building.
The fate of the city's 35cent transit fare has become snarled in so many considertions besides outright economics that the outlook on what may happen seems to be changing almost daily.

Consumers who have been trying to stretch their food budgets by adding more potatoes to their meals received some dliquieting news yesterday. Prices of all Maine potato deliveries were bid the daily limit of 50 cents a hundred pounds on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The limit was reached within minutes of the opening and stuck there all day.

An investigating judge said today that he was planning to have the controversial Euphronios vase in the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York examined by a team of Italian archeologists and scientists.

Federal Judge Leland C. Nielsen in San Diego has approved the sale of the Westgate-California Corporation's 37.5 per cent interest in the Golcanda Corporation to the National Propane Corporation for $9.8-million. National Propane is 89 per cent-owned by the DWG Corporation of Miami.
An insurance agency whose principal stockholders are leaders of the Automobile Club of New York has agreed to increase payments to the club as a result of a member's suit.

A Federal grand jury in Brooklyn is investigating reports that James D. Robertson, the former chief assistant district attorney in Queens, was involved in manipulating narcotics cases while he was in office, according to sources close to the case.

United States and Belgian officials have worked out a set of guidelines for the 12-nation oil-policy group that was established at the conference of major oil-consuming countries in Washington last month.
Dr. James F. Collins, who had been under fire as superintendent of the Nassau County Medical Center, announced his retirement today.
While college sports recruiters pour it on this month scholars ponder the disparity between athletic adulation and academic neglect.
He played basketball in China and the Soviet Union last summer but Kevin Stacom is now about to play basketball where the atmosphere will be really hostile-in Raleigh, N. C.

A committee of the Federal Reserve Board has proposed that foreign banks operate branches in only one state. If enacted into law, the proposal would put foreign banks on the same footing as American banks, which are limited to one state.

A 70-year-old woman, Mrs. Anna Haiss, of 34-59 Eastchester Avenue, the Bronx, was found last night lying on her apartment floor, badly beaten about the head, the victim of an apparent robbery attempt, the police reported.

I will leave to others the question of whether or not the current fuel shortage is real or contrived. Nevertheless, It initially gave the appearance of being real and, hence, provided us with an interesting dress rehearsal of how we will behave when the oil finally does run out.

The jury in the trial of John N. Mitchell and Maurice H. Stans heard a letter read yesterday that depicted Robert L. Vesco as being so frantic about a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation into his financial empire that he warned the President's brother, F. Donald Nixon, that if the inquiry were not stopped there would be international and national repercussions.

Laugh a little, cry a little. In show-biz the formula is unbeatable, and tonight the Columbia Broadcasting System comes up with some impressive ingredients. The laughs begin at 8:30 on "Paradise," written by and starring Renee Taylor and Joe Bologna. The tears follow at 9:30 in a 90-minute "G.E. Theater" production called "Tell Me Where It Hurts."

Among the mysteries confounding analysts of Chinese affairs in recent days is what has happened to a radical leftist magazine whose stridently worded attacks on Confucius last fall set off the current ideological campaign sweeping China.
Ivor Richard, a former Labor member of Parliament who was defeated in the recent general election in Britain, has been appointed to succeed Sir Donald Maltland as Ambassador to the United Nations.
When a collector buys a contemporary work of art, then sells it at a profit, should the artist who created it get a royalty payment?
Cardinal Cooke and scores of clergymen and public officials attended yesterday a mass of the resurrection for Mrs. Helen Owen Carey, wife of Representative Hugh L. Carey of Brooklyn.

The young lions among Japan's conservative politicians are restless. One of them, Hajime Ishii, sat in his office behind the capitol the other day and said: "We have a great sense of crisis. If things keep on going the way they are now, the Liberal-Democratic party is doomed."

Venezuela's new President has declared that his energy policy will be aimed at early state control of the oil industry but he pledges to fulfill commitments to keep up the present level of supply to the United States.

The state and its municipalities called yesterday tor a delay of at least two years in setting up a regional network of solid-waste-disposal systems. State and local officials said at a public hearing in Trenton that, in general, they favored a proposed statewide Solid Waste Management Act but needed more time to comply with the law.
The Daily News obtained a temporary restraining order yesterday enjoining members of the typographical union from interfering with operations through work stoppages or other job actions.

Returning to my desk after a trip to Georgia and Florida where I slayed a wild hog, a dozen quail, two largemouth bass, five mangrove snappers, one jack crevalle, four dozen oysters, three azaleas and two yellow jasmines, I found a packet of letters awaiting me, most of which deplored the act of hunting as manifested in a recent Wood, Field and Stream column on pursuing snowshoe rabbits in the Adirondacks.

In an effort to improve the training of the growing ranks of young Americans in Mexico learning to become doctors, professors from medical schools throughout the United States are journeying south of the border to give lectures and demonstrations for the American students.

The Sun Oil Company announced yesterday that it had raised its prices for residual fuel oil grades, f.o.b. Toledo and delivered Detroit, by 4 cents a gallon. The new prices range from 25.75 cents a gallon to 28.9 cents.

announced today that he would not be a candidate for re-election this year. "After much thought I have decided to seek a new and different challenge," the 46-yearold Republican said, reading from a brief statement.

President Nixon suggested in June, 1969, that members of his staff be given access to the tax returns of former Presidents so he could learn what deductions his predecessors had taken, according to an internal White House memorandum now in the hands of Congressional investigators.

In a rare split, the Republicandominated Nassau County Board of Supervisors voted today to urge the House Judiciary Committee "to act expeditiously" in presenting its findings to the House of Representatives to determine whether impeachment proceeding should be brought against President Nixon.

To celebrate 20 years of making money in his delicatessen, Abe Lebewohl went all out to lose some yesterday. He cut the prices to what they were when he opened his Second Avenue Delicatessen, at the corner of 10th Street, on March 11, 1954.

Major paper companies yesterday applauded the relaxation of Federal price controls on their industry, and several of them promptly announced price increases.
The prosecution said today that the main evidence in the trial here of Robert D. Petrarca on charges of committing a double murder in Upper Montclair last May 14 would be the defendant's confession.

A conference on East-West trade here was told yesterday to expect cyclical fluctuations in commerce between the Communist countries and the West, particularly between the two principal trading partners, the United States and the Soviet Union.

Federal officials and members of Congress have for the last three months been quietly investigating possible antitrust violations by business executives who simultaneously sit on the boards of directors of several oil companies.

A Cabinet level study of whether the state should take over the administration of local welfare systems has concluded in effect that the action on the issue should be put off indefinitely. The study's findings reflect the change in Governors and new pressures from the Federal Government.
The New Jersey Republican State Committee appointed Conover Spencer as its executive director here today, teaming him once again with Webster B. Todd, the party's state chairman.

Research-Cottrell, Inc., said yesterday that it had been awarded a contract of about $15-million by the Arizona Public Service Company for the installation of two proprietary sulphur dioxide wet fly ash removal systems.

Lieut. Col. Fobert L. Stirm, 39 years old, a former prisoner of war in Vietnam, and his wife, Loretta, were divorced yesterday. Each parent was awarded the custody of two of their four children.
Prices rose for the third straight session yesterday on the American Stock Exchange but were mixed in the overthe-counter market in moderate trading.
The International Paper Companyy said yesterday that in antitrust suit brought against it by the Atlantic Gumned Paper Corporation alleging violation of antitrust laws had seen discontinued.

12-Judge Robert Muir Jr. of the Morris County Superior Court today approved a settlement under which Edwin J. Sayres waived his right to serye as executor of the will of Geraldine Rockefeller Dodge in favor of the Fidelity Union Trust Company of Newark.

The North Vietnamese ambassador to Laos, Le Van Hien, will return to Vientiane tomorrow after an absence of nine years, the Foreign Ministry announced today, prompting speculation that the new Laotian coalition government would be formed soon.
A security alert confined Portuguese armed forces to their barracks from Saturday to today, according to an official Government spokesman. The alert was lifted today.
A Government witness testified yesterday under crossexamination that "never at any time" did he ask John N. Mitchell to "fix" a case for Robert L. Vesco, the financier, who is now a fugitive.

Alexander Field Chisholm, a banker and oil executive who played a major role in the development of Leontyne Price as a soprano of the Metropolitan Opera, died yesterday of a stroke at Spohn Hospital, Corpus Christi. Tex. He was 74

ABRAMSON-Jennle, beloved wife of the late Joseph E., devoted mother of Samuel, David, and the late Diana Goldie, darling grandmother of Joel, Rebecca, Radine and Ellis Jay, loving great grandmother of Rachel. Services Thursday, 9:30 A.M. at "The Riverside," 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. Shiva will be at 81 East Cedar Lane, Teaneck, N.J.

Two mild earthquakes rumbled through downtown Los Angeles early today, apparently causing no damage and attracting little attention from a sleeping city. A spokesman for the Seismological Laboratory at California Institute of Technology at Pasadena said the first quake registered 3.0 on the Richter scale, the second 2.5.

Item: In the last six months of 1973, according to White House counsel, the Government spent nearly $300,000 for lawyers and legal services to prepare President Nixon's Watergate defense. Item: The bill to create a Federal Legal Services Corporation to provide funds for people too poor to afford a lawyer in civil cases has been vetoed once by Mr. Nixon -and faces tough sledding in Congressional conference.

Fifty-four years after another Prince of Wales paid a similar call, Prince Charles of England will visit Southern California this week with the crew of the H.M.S. Jupiter, a Royal Navy frigate.

Musicians of the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra have charged the management of w the orchestra with "neglect and mismanagement," and asked that a fiscal agent be appointed to direct the financial affairs of. the organization.
The finance chairman of Helmsley-Spear, the real estate management firm, was named yesterday as the unsalaried chairman of the city's proposed convention center.

The Watergate grand jury concluded that a disputed hush money payment to the attorney for E. Howard Hunt Jr. was made on the evening of March 21, less than 12 hours after a White House meeting involving President Nixon, sources close to the investigation said today.

The Justice Department agreed yesterday to surrender "a truckload" of documents pertaining to the Federal Bureau of Investigation's role in gathering intelligence on the Black Panther party before a 1969 raid that left two Panther leaders dead.
The S.S. Kresge Company, which owns and operates KMart stores, said today that tighter security measures were being implemented in an effort to discourage kidnapping of the company's executives.

Chuck Davis is currently devoting all his dance and choregraphic energies to presenting ?olk dances derived from Afrian forms, and doing it very veil. "The Watcher (Religion K 5)," his latest dance in this style, was given at Clark Center Monday evening.
The military mutiny that began two weeks ago is continuing in the Ethiopian Air Force, informed sources reported today. The airmen are said to be demanding the ouster of 21 officers.
The Spencer Memorial Church in Brooklyn Heights, known for its innovative and often controversial services under its pastor, the Rev. William Glenesk, has closed.

" An American Millionaire," the Murray Schisgal comedy now in previews at the Circle in the Square/Joseph E. Levine Theater on Broadway, has postponed its press opening schedruled for Monday. "Thieves," the Herb Gardner play, has postponed its March 21 opening at the Broadhurst Theater. The play is now being shown in Boston.

The Justice Department obtained a consent decree yesterday in which two electrical union locals and two contractors groups in Newark agreed to expand job opportunities for black workers. In Washington, Attorney General William B. Saxbe said the decree had been filed in United States District Court in Newark.

Theodoros Stamos, the abstract expressionist painter named as one of three executors by the late Mark Rothko, testified yesterday in Surrogate's Court that he had left his former agent to become a client of Marlborough Gallery because he was impressed with the way the gallery had handled Mr. Rothko's paintings following his death.

Drivers at Yonkers Raceway last night acquiescedfor the time being, at least -to the State Racing and Wagering Board's insistence on stiffer penalties for harness racing infractions.

Dr Jerome Jacob Bergida, an otolaryngologist, died Monday in Loyola Hospital, Brookfield, Ill., while visiting in that state. He was 67 years old and lived and practiced at 1615 Dorchester Road in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn since World War II.

Continued disappointing resuits at the New York division of R. H. Macy Co. limited earnings to a gain of 2.3 percent in the Christmas buying period of its second fiscal quarter, ended Feb. 2.
The presidents of four major drug companies defended their salls practices today, saying tha these provided education for doctors as well as promotion for the companies' products.
Wayne cashman broke a scoreless tie late in the second period tonight as the Boston Bruins defeated the Buffalo Sabres, 4-0, in a National Hockey League game.
A three-alarm fire in Brooklyn's Park Slope section yesterday afternoon destroyed one four-story apartment building and heavily damaged a second, leaving 49 persons homeless.

President Nixon assured King Hussein of Jordan today that the United States would continue to use its influence to bring about agreements between Israel and her Arab neighbors--including Jordan-even if the oil embargo is not lifted tomorrow at a meeting of oil-producing nations.

The New England Contemporary Ensemble lived up to the "contemporary" in its name with its program Monday night at Town Hall. Of the four pieces on the bill, two were first performances and two were first New York performances. Three of them were composed in 1974 and the fourth, from 1966, sounded quite new enough.
Bills that would penalize medical schools in the state that did not admit New Yorkers on a preferential basis were introduced today by a bipartisan coalition of 52 Senators and Assemblymen.
There were errors in a chart and article dealing with the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation in The New York Times Monday. A corrective article appears on Page 55.
The House Ways and Means Committee voted today to do something about reducing the depletion allowance that producers of oil and natural gas use to reduce their income taxes.

Much of the nation's hope for an adequate supply of food a reasonable prices in the coming year rides on the railroads, an a decision in the next few day on a big increase in rail car to move fertilizer will be critical, officials of the Departmen of Agriculture said today.
Dr. Bedford Shelmire Jr., a mild-mannered Texas dermatologist, wrote a popular book on skin care last year, but it didn't say it all.

Of all the big college football days in the Deep South, and there are many, few are bigger or more highly dramatized than the second Saturday in December. It is Signing Day, a day like no other.
Spokesmen for motorists and service station operators urged today that drivers be permitted to fill their gasoline tanks to discourage long waiting lines at service stations.
In the political uncertainty left in Connecticut by Gov. Thomas J. Meskill's decision not to seek re-election, the General Assembly appeared today headed on a more independent course.

The key prosecution witness in the trial of Nelson C. Gross testified during cross-examination today that the former Republican state chairman had, asked him for a $25,000 cash, donation to former Gov. William T. Cahill's 1969 campaign,
UAL, Inc., reported yesterday that its subsidiary, United Air Lines, had a $1.3-million loss in February. In the year-earlier month the airline, biggest in the industry, had a loss of $6.6-million.

The Golden Gate Bridge has been declared the top man-made tourist attraction in the United States by the Commerce Department, which had conducted a poll of the travel industry. The bridge was followed by Mt. Rushmore, the Houston Astrodome, the Statue of Liberty,

NYACK, N. Y.--Inside the 45,000-square - foot factory, Haitian women and men sit side by side in a ratio of roughly 4 to 1. Working under lights that give off an eerie bluish tint, they are able to see the tiny dots (formed by chalk and kerosene) that mark the spots where sequins, nailheads or rhinestones must be punched.

In 1953, William Bradford Huie began writing a book about an American soldier executed in. 1945 for desertion, the first such case of military execution since the Civil War. The book, published in 1954; was called "The Execution of Private Slovik."

Iraq has given her Kurdish minority 15 days in which to accept the Government's new lan for autonomy in the northern part of the country. The Government statement was interpreted by Arab diplomats here as a warning that if Gen. Mustafa al-Barzani and hi` Kurdish Democratic party continued to reject the plan after 15 days, the Government's cooperation with them would be terminated.

Controller Harrison J. Goldin said that the city would save $2.1-million in interest payments on the sale yesterday of $362-million in short-term notes, mostly because of the recent upgrading of the city's credit rating.
South Vietnamese military negotiators boycotted a scheduled meeting with the Vietcong today to protest the shelling of a Government school in the Mekong Delta Saturday.
Two mild earthquakes rumbled through downtown Los Angeles early today, apparently causing no damage and attracting little attention from a sleeping city.

George D. Sax, a banker who is credited with a number of innovations, among them drivein banking, died today of heart disease in the Miami Heart Institute. He was 69 years old.

The police issued a nationwide alarm yesterday for a 22year-old paroled convict who is wanted for questioning in the murder Saturday of a policeman during the holdup of a bar in Queens.

A prosecution witness testified that two attempts had been made to hypnotize Robert Petrarca six weeks before Mr. Petrarca allegedly made four separate confessions to the May 14 murders of two Upper Montclair women. The testimony by Anthony R. Mautrone, an assistant Essex Couny prosecutor, came during a hearing to determine if the alleged confessions can be admitted as evidence at the Newark trial of Mr. Petrarca.

The Jamaica Water Supply Company, which supplies water to 650,000 people in southern Queens and southwestern Nassau County, announced yesterday that it would apply next Monday to the Public Service Commission for a $3,977,000 annual rate increase.

The combination of the Soviet Union urging the Arabs not to lift the oil embargo and President Nixon's request for stand-by authority for gasoline rationing made for an uncertain stock market yesterday. While the Dow-Jones industrial average slipped 1.33 to close at 887.12, advances outnumbered declines by 755 to 636. There were 385 issues unchanged. Volume dipped to 17,250,000 shares from 18,470,000 on Monday.
The New York State delegation, so often divided and conquered on the floor of the House of Representatives, stood united today on an aid-to-education measure and still went down to defeat.

The United States Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit overturned today a Federal judge's disbarment order involving the local United States Attorney, four of his assistants and an Attorney for the Internal Revenue Service.

Controller Harrison J. Goldin said that the city would save $2.1-million in interest payments on the sale yesterday of $362-million in short-term notes, mostly because of the recent upgrading of the city's credit rating.

The Long Island Lighting Company today announced that its 836,000 customers in Nassau and Suffolk Counties and the Rockaway Peninsula in Queens would be charged an additional 19'per cent for increased fuel costs this month.

International Prime Minister Wilson announced to Parliament that he intended to renegotiate the terms of Britain's Common Market membership and to submit the results to a popular vote. This was the strongest note in what otherwise was a carefully modulated Labor Government program submitted to a Parliament that had the seats - but clearly lacked the intention - at this stage - to defeat the new Prime Minister. [1:1.]

Hume Cronyn and Jessica Tandy have been acting, together and apart, for more than 40 years. They are the longest running team on Broadway-currently co-starring with Anne Baxter in "Noel Coward in Two Keys."

PHILADELPHIA, March 12 (AP) Jack Kelly, former president of the Amateur Athletic Union, was awarded the Philadelphia franchise in the fledgling World Football League today. The city councilman and former Olympic oarsman is the brother of Princess Grace of Monaco.

United States corporations that are heavily engaged in East-West trade were reported yesterday to be putting pressure on the White House to resolve promptly the current impasse over Export-Import Bank loans to the Soviet Union and three East European countries.
