The plight of Valery Panov, former leading dancer of Leningrad's Kirov ballet, and his wife, Galina, was dramatized yesterday on the occasion of his 35th birthday, at a birthday party held at Plaza Square, opposite the Plaza Hotel.

Chief Justice Richard J. Hughes of Suprem Court announced today the promotion of James R. Heaney to deputy administrative director of the New Jersey courts. Mr. Heaney is now standing master assigned to the administrative office of the courts,

Twenty years ago, when he was starting the Princeton community Pee Wee hockey program, John Bernard probably would have fainted had someone told him he would one day be coaching a women's ice hockey team.

Second Lieut. Hiroo Onoda of the Imperial Japanese Army, who came down from a mountain hide-out in a Philippine jungle on Saturday, returned to his native land today to an outpouring of patriotic emotion.
The Assembly Codes Committee voted today to release for floor debate a comprehensive obscenlty bill that contains a long, detailed list of specific sexual acts whose depiction would be prohibited.

The White House indicated today that President Nixon was unwilling to supply 42 additional Watergate-related tape recordings requested by the House Judiciary Committee for its impeachment proceedings.

Lazaro Pefia, former secretary general of the National Confederation of Cuban Workers, died last night at the age of 73, Radio Havana reported today. I The report, heard here, called Mr. Pena one of the top Communist party leaders.
James D. St. Clair says he represents "the office of the Presidency," not the occupant of that office "individually."
The District of columbia elections board yesterday canceled the May 7 primary for the city's nonvoting delegate to Congress.

Way back in 1967 when Scali, McCabe, Sloves was launching itself with the Volvo account, Sam Scali, resident art directing genius, was proving that he not only had an eye for graphics but also a head for business and a heart for money. His liver wasn't so bad either.
A major confrontation between Congress and the White House appeared today to be developing over information the White House is withholding from the House Judiciary Committee.

Vice President Ford said today that had he been in Mr. Nixon's place last March 21 when the former White House counsel, John W. Dean 3d, detailed the involvement of top Presidential aides in a Watergate cover-up, "I think I would have" taken the information directly to the Attorney General.
American banks are moving exuberantly into lucrative consumer finance operations in West Germany and the West German central bank Is worried that this may circumvent its policies of credit restraint.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass.--Future kidnappings cannot be prevented by physical security measures like those established at airports to reduce the risk of hijacking. There are far too many potential victims to think of solving the problem by bodyguards.

The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation has brought its Tristar airbus to the Soviet Union to show to top Soviet aircraft and airline officials in a bid for a major order, a Lockheed spokesman disclosed today.
Prime Minister Wilson's Cabinet told Parliament today that it intended to renegotiate the terms of Britain's Common Market membership, and to submit the results to a popular vote.
Arab oil ministers began arriving here today for a crucial review of Arab oil strategy tomorrow, including a decision on continuation of the embargo on oil shipments to the United States.

The top official of a major paper company said here yesterday that future demand for paper and related products could be met if industry and the Government coordinated their efforts to preserve natural resources.
The Turkish Government has sent official word to the United States that Turkey will resume the cultivation of the opium poppy, official sources said here today.

Raises of $10,000 a year for Mayor Beame and other members of the Board of Estimate, voted by the City Council at the end of last year, will be allowed by the Federal Cost of Living Council but on only a two-step basis, it was disclosed yesterday.
Mrs. Catherine Snell Crary, a historian and adjunct professor at Finch College, died Monday of cancer in Memorial Hospital. She was 65 years old and lived on Underhill Road in Scarsdale, N.Y.

Israel distributed yesterday a memorial booklet listing 2,522 soldiers, sailors and airmen killed or missing in action from the beginning of the October war up to Feb. 12. Nearly one fourth of the casualties were officers.
Government forces cleared a five-mile strip of Route 4 from here to the coast today, opening it to the important provincial town of Kompong Speu, the Cambodian command reported.
The Federal Bureau of Investigation, announced last night that it had arrested three more suspects in Miami in the kidnapping last week of 8-year-old John Calzadilla of Dix Hills, L.I.

A "citizens' inquiry" by a panel of urban liberals and academicians into a bitterly deadlocked coal mine strike here in the remote Appalachian Mountains ended today with an unexpected, if tentative, break in a sometimes violent seven-month bargaining impasse.

Testimony ended yesterday in the trial of Henry S. Brown, who is accused of the murder of two police officers, Gregory P. Foster and Rocco W. Laurie, on Jan. 27, 1972, at Avenue B and 11th Street in the East Village.
President Juan Domingo Peron appointed one of his conservative followers today to replace the deposed left-wing Peronist Governor in the strife-torn industrial city of Cordoba.

The Theater at St. Clements is becoming-or now, I suppose, has become--one of our most interesting institutional theaters in town. It is willing to try anything in its protean space in St. Clements Church on 46th Street between Ninth and 10th. Currently it is giviig a new play, "Alive and Well in Argentina" by Barry Pritchard.
Claude and Paloma RuizPicasso, offspring of the late Pablo Picasso and Francoise Gilot, his longtime mistress, were officially recognized yesterday as legal heirs of the great artist.

Representative Frank J. Brasco took the stand at his trial yesterday to deny that in return for payoffs he had conspired to help an underworld figure obtain Post Office contracts and an $85,000 loan for trucks to carry out the contracts.

The Cerro Corporation said yesterday it had signed cormpensation agreements in Santiago for $41.8-million in cash and notes with the Government of Chile for Chile's 1971 expropriation of the business of Compania Minera Andina, S.A., then owner of the Rio Blanco copper mine, which went into production in mid-1971.

European Common Market officials in Brussels, seeking indications of the policy the new British Cabinet of Prime Minister Wilson will take toward the trade bloc, were disappointed by the terse program announced, by Queen Elizabeth II. "There was nothing in it we didn't already know," one of the officials said.

Defense officials, facing questioning about the Diego Garcia naval base in the Indian Ocean, left it unclear today whether the United States wished to use the facility for B-52 strategic bombers or could do so.

A New Jersey mortgage broker, pleading guilty to conspiracy, admitted yesterday that he "paid the Sewer Commissioner a fee" for depositing $1-million in bond money of the Bergen County Sewer Authority in a New York bank.

Representative Wilbur D. Mills says he believes that the American people will be outraged when they see a forthcoming Congressional report on President Nixon's taxes because there will be so many different items on which the legality, or at least the morality, of Mr. Nixon's claims will be questioned.

Bills that would penalize medical schools in the state that did not admit New Yorkers on a preferential basis were introduced today by a bipartisan coalition of 52 Senators and Assemblymen.

An attempt to "hypnotize" Robert Petrarca last June while he was only a suspect and before he was indicted in the May 14 murder of two Upper Montclair women was disclosed today in questioning by the prosecution of one of its chief witnesses.

The local board of Community School District 28 in Queens voted 5 to 4 early yesterday to comply with a Federal demand that it submit data on the ethnic composition of its teaching staff-data that the board has resisted giving.

John Conteh ot Britain recovered from a first-round knockdown and retained his European light-heavyweight title tonight when Tom Bogs of Denmark was unable to answer the bell for the 'seventh round because of a cut.

The Government-controlled oil concern, Veba, A. G., announced today that, it would stop its Soviet oil purchases at the end of the month. The West German company said the Russians were making excessive price demands and slowing down deliveries. About a quarter of the 10.83 million tons of oil refined by Veba last year came from the Soviet Union.

The Sergeants and Lieutenants Benevolent Association yesterday unanimously rejected a fact-finder's proposal for a three-year contract with the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority.

An Israeli Army spokesman announced tonight that after two days of quiet on the Syrian border, Syrian forces directed artillery fire against Israeli positions in the northern sector. Israeli units returned the fire, the spokesman said.

Rival tender offers for the Commercial Solvents Corporation have sent the stock of this industrial chemical producer moving ahead briskly and, in the process, provided another fast-unfolding drama on Wall Street.

The agreement to merge Blue Cross and Blue Shield in the metropolitan area is unquestionably a desperation move born of the financial and administrative woes that have engulfed Blue Shield in recent months. Even without these exigencies, the projected consolidation would have represented a worthwhile step toward simplifying the maze of financial interlocks that push countless New York patients to the brink of relapse in trying to collect reimbursement for hospital and medical bills.

Although its name wasn't picked out of a drum, Wells, Rich, Greene has won the New York State Lottery account, which has been at Fuller Smith Ross since the lottery started in 1967. The billings are $2-million. The decision was made by the three-man State Racing and Wagering Board working on recommendations of a six-man selection committee.

Mrs. Sidonie Matsner Gruenberg, who directed the Child Study Association of America from 1923 to 1950 and then became an influential writer on raising children, died Monday at her home, 100 Central Park South. She was 91 years old.

Parks Administrator Edwin L. Weisl Jr. announced an immediate new security program for the city's zoos yesterday following what he called the "senseless and brutal" beatings last week of five Fallow deer at the Central Park Zoo and the theft of two parrots and 30 fancy pigeons from Prospect Parks's Zoo.

A shortage of coal has forced layoffs and production cutbacks in the steel industry, and more are forecast this week unless coal miners return to their jobs in West Virginia, the Associated Press reported yesterday.

PARIS-The only sure thing about France's next presidential election Is that the principal opposition candidate will be Francois Mitterrand, head of the Socialist party and leader of its leftwing alliance with the Communists.

Guatemala's Congress today proclaimed the former Defense Minister, Gen. Kjell, Laugerud Garcfa the winner of last week's presidential election. The major opposition candidate, Gen. Efrain Rios Montt, immediately challenged the proclamation and asked for support from the people.

The Aeolian Chamber Players can seldom play together as a complete ensemble since literature for flute, clarinet, violin, cello and piano can hardly be said to exist at all. At Carnegie Recital Hall Monday night, the five young musicians joined forces only once during their concert, to give the premiere of Raoul Pleskow's Motet and Madrigal.

Otto F. Otepka asked the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit today to grant a new trial in his $4million libel suit against The New York Times.

A $200-million class action suit charging violations of state antitrust and monopoly laws has been filed here against seven major oil companies. Named as defendants are Amoco, Texaco, Shell, Mobil, Arco, Gulf and Exxon.
The City Council passed a home-rule message yesterday supporting two bills introduced in the Legislature that would bar the use of city policemen as guards at foreign government delegation buildings.
Prime Minister Wilson retreated today from his campaign pledge to nationalize North Sea oil, the natural resource that is regarded as Britain's greatest potential asset in foreign trade.
Wayne Cashman broke a scoreless tie late in the game tonight as the Boston Bruins defeated. the Buffalo Sabres, 4-0, in a National Hockey League game. Gilles Gilbert was in the net for Borton.

Reports of renewed military action between Israel and Syria yesterday added to the rising costs of most basic commodities. The notable exceptions were cotton, livestock products and lumber.

John J. Sheehan, lawyer for Typographical Union No. 6, said that a proceeding involving a request by The Daily News for a permanent injunction enjoining the union from interfering with the newspaper's operations had been moved from the State Supreme Court to Federal Court in the Southern District.

Glenn Wortham, a 35-year-old convenience food store operator, did not have much to do here this weekend. So he went out back and played with some rattlesnakes. Diamond-back rattlesnakes. The 5-foot-long kind. The ones with the fangs and the deadly yellow venom.

The Illinois Department of Insurance said last night more than 1,500 persons, including two sons of Mayor Richard J, Daley, had received passing grades after failing examinations for state insurance brokers's licenses.

Theodoros Stamos, the abstract expressionist painter named' as one of three executors by the late Mark Rothko, testified yesterday in Surrogate's Court that he had left his former agent to become a client of Marlborough Gallery because he was impressed with the way the gallery, had handled Mr. Rothko's paintings following his death.

The Justice Department agreed yesterday to surrender "a truckload" of documents pertaining to the Federal Bureau of Investigation's role in gathering intelligence on the Black Panther party before a 1969 raid that left two Panther leaders dead.

Clerical and staff employes at the Brooklyn Museum won the right yesterday to hold elections for union representation. A joint agreement was announced by the museum and District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employes, which has been negotiating to become bargaining agent for the employes.

Directors of Dome Mines, Ltd., yesterday proposed a three-for-one stock split subject to shareholders' approval. Directors also declared a 5-cent extra dividend on the outstanding shares, as well as the regular 25-cent quarterly dividend.

North Caroiina's basketball team is under the onus of being seeded No. 1 in the National Invitation Tournament, which begins Saturday in Madison Square Garden. But the Tar Heels have none of the benefits of playing a weak team first.

A cab clipped Mayor Beame's official automobile last night, according to the police, but no one was injured in the minor mishap, which occurred at the intersection of West 54th Street and Madison Avenue shortly before 10 P.M.
At a time when schoolboy athletes are being heavily recruited and virtually assured of a diploma, only 62 per cent of the nation's basketball professionals have their college degrees.

The American Express Company, Inc., Avis, Inc., and the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation reached an agreement in principle last night for the proposed merger of Avis into a subsidiary of American Express. The transaction would involve $150million in cash.

The New Republic, founded in 1914 "less to inform or entertain its readers than to start little Insurrections in the realm of their convictions," announced today the second change of ownership in its 60-year-history.

In one of those coincldences that strike the concert field now and then, Bruckner's rarely performed String Quintet turned up three nights in a row at Alice Tully Hall this week. The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center performed it on Sunday and last night, and it was played in the Music From Marlboro program on Monday night.

The Finance Committee to Re-elect the President, the money manager for the richest political campaign in United States history, has closed its books and transferred $3.57million to a trust account with a Washington bank.

The hibacking of a Japan Air Lines Boeing 747 ended after seven hours tonight when policemen disguised as airport maintenance men arrested an 18-yearold Japanese who said he wanted to "'research the earth."

Four leading Cambodians have left the country to join Prince Norodom Sihanouk's government in exile, political sources said today. The four included Ing Kiet, an engineer and a Minister of Public Works in the Sihanouk government before the Prince was ousted from office March 18, 1970.

Sunny skies and cold temperatures will cover the Northeast today. Scattered showers and thundershowers are forecast for northeastern Texas and the South Atlantic States, except in central and southern Florida.

LA CELESTINA, a play in Spanish by Fernando de Rolas; directed by Rene Buch; presented by the Spanish Theater Reportory Company, at the Gramercy Arts Theater, 138 East 27th Street, 8.
A Government witness testified yesterday under cross-examination that "never at any time" did he ask John N. Mitchell to "fix" a case for Robert L. Vesco, the financier, who is now a fugitive.

Yale, the one-time king of college polo, overwhelmed Harvard, 17-8, and Cornell turned back Menlo College of Atherton, Calif., 27-13. tonight in the first round of the national indoor championships at the Ox Ridge Hunt Club.

" An American Millionaire," the Murray Schisgal comedy now in previews at the Circle in the Square/Joseph E. Levine, Theater on Broadway, has postponed its press opening scheduled for Monday. "Thieves," the Herb Gardner play, has postponed its March 21 opening at the Broadhurst Theater. The play is now being shown in Boston.

A woman who works in midtown, but lives with her husband in Morningside Heights, was called at work by her maid the other day. The maid said that everything electrical in the couple's apartment had stopped working, and the woman, remembering that she had forgotten to pay Con Ed, hurried tp its nearest office.

An apparent high bid of $75.6-million was offered today for a tract of oil-shale land that contains an estimated 244 million barrels of recoverable crude oil.

Second Lieut. Hiroo Onoda of the Imperial Japanese Army, who came down from a mountain hide-out in a Philippine jungle on Saturday, returned to his native land today to an outpouring of patriotic emotion.

Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn intends to settle with his family in Zurich, the Swiss Government announced today.

The latest salvos can only make it harder for Washington to get wholehearted European Community backingleaving aside the hopeless case of France-for a collective approach to the oil producers or even for Middle East peace efforts.

Attorneys for two imprisoned members of the Symbionese Liberation Army said today that they would seek permission for the men to make a televised statement on their plan to win the release of Patricia Hearst.

, a senior vice president of A. G. Becker Co., a brokerage firm at 55 Water Street, died Monday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived at 1185 Park Avenue.

, an editor and producer of specials for the National Broadcasting Company's radio network news, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital of complications from meningitis. He was 46 years old and lived at 711 Amsterdam Avenue.

Twelve University of Massachusetts students are dribbling a basketball to New York City to demonstrate support for the Massachusetts basketball team. The university will compete in the National Invitational Tournament at Madison Square Garden and faces its first test Saturday evening against Jacksonville University.
Britain had a deficit of $3.3-billion last year in her commerciall transactions with the rest of the world, in contrast to a 1972 surplus of $158-million, the Treasury announced today.
The badly decomposed bodies of a couple who were found on the roof of a Lower East Side building Tuesday night had bullet wounds in their heads, the police reported yesterday.

A months-long lobbying effort by an Upper Darby third grade class has paid off with state Senate passage of a bill to make the firefly, or lighting bug;. the state's official insect.

The Administration's dubious proposal to channel billions of American investment dollars into developing the Soviet Union's Siberian natural gas fields has run into a well-timed legal barrier. On political and strategic grounds, beyond the technical point of law involved, the Congress would do well to grasp this unexpected opportunity to subject the Siberian venture to harder scrutiny.
A State Supreme Court Justice on Staten Island upheld yesterday the right of a Roman Catholic high school to expel a student without holding a hearing.

An old Balkan quarrel of the kind once capable of starting major European wars has been striking vestigial sparks during the last week, causing muted grumbling between the neighboring Communist governments of Bulgaria and Yugoslavia.
Mayor Joseph Alioto announced tonight that an agreement had been reached on all but the wage issue in negotiations aimed at ending a sevenday strike by municipal employes.

Pat Dobson posted his second consecutive scoreless three-inning effort against the Orioles. His former teammates have managed only four hits off the right-hander.... Juan Bernhardt, a 20-year-old third baseman, got his first chance to play second base inBill Virdon's latest experiment, and looked impressive....

London-John Conteh, 175 pounds, Britain, knocked out Torn Bogs, 173, Denmark, in 7 rounds; Joe Bugner, Britain, 221, outpointed Pat Duncan, 198, Carson City, Nev., 10; Johnny Clark, Britain, 119, knocked out Chuck Spencer, Cleveland. 7.

The Irish Republic's Prime Minister, in a landmark declaration, acknowledged today that neighboring Northern Ireland was a province under British control.
The House-Ways and Means Committee voted today to reduce even further the impact of a cut in the oil depletion allowance that it approved yesterday.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 13--In his typically quiet way, undetected by even the closest and most knowledgeable observers, Bill Virdon has been building a lethal weapon in Florida this spring.
A tropical cyclone lashed the coast of New South Wales today, adding to the destruction and flooding it has left along Australia's eastern seaboard.
LAGOS, Nigeria-Only a few people stepped up from the dirt road that is Gafiri Olokodana Street and asked Efiong Udoh to take their pictures. But Mr. Udoh, a photographer, was not unduly concerned.
An assistant United States attorney for New Jersey and a Rutgers Law School professor disagreed sharply today on whether an individual's right to privacy is in serious jeopardy in American society.

The Sun Oil Company has sold its two center city buildings here for $8-million to 1600 Properties, Inc. Sun said that its subsidiary, the Sun Oil Company of Pennsylvania, will continue to occupy the buildings for five years or more.
About 200 firemen asking for a $1,200-a-year raise t picketed City Hall yesterday while hearings were being held on Mayor Paul T. Jordan's record $82.2-million budget for fiscal 1974.

John Cinicola, assistant basketball coach at Duquesne University for the last 14 seasons, today was named to succeed Red Manning as the school's head coach. Manning, who relinquished his coaching duties to become athletic director, coupled the announcement of Cinicola's appointment with that of a new assistant, James Sims.

SAN FRANCISCO-A systematic search of the 500 nearest stars that seem the likeliest centers of planetary systems like that of the sun has failed in a preliminary analysis to reveal any radio emissions suggestive of other technological civilizations.

William Lukacs, president of the New York Society of Architects and chief specifications architect for the Eggers Partnership, 100 Park Avenue, died Monday at Hillcrest General Hospital, Jamaica, Queens. He was 67 years old and lived at 64-45 137th Street, Flushing.

Officials in the metropolitan area, which has always been heavily dependent on imported oil, cautioned last night that the end to the Arab embargo would probably not ease fuel shortages here for another couple of months and might never return prices in the region to their previous low levels.
Governor Wilson will recommend that a state bond issue of $250,million be put to the voter this fall to raise capital for commuter and upstate railroad improvements, reliable sources said today.

International Arab oil ministers reportedly agreed to end the embargo against oil shipments to the United States. Informed sources said that the decision was made during a private four-hour meeting in Tripoli, but that a formal announcement had been postponed until Sunday in Vienna. [1:8.]
There are more Amencan troops in the Western Pacific now than there were 10 years ago, before the major United States involvement in Vietnam, Americans for Democratic Action said today.
The Houston Rockets, led offensively and defensively by Rudy Tomjanovich and Dave Wohl, rallied tonight to whip the Capital Bullets, 11793, for their third straight victory.

Eastern division skiers captured both the men's and women's downhill events of the 27th North American junior alpine championships today. Rod Bicknell, 18 years old of Middlebury, Vt., skied the men's 21/2-mile downhill in 2 minutes 8.08 seconds to lead more than 100 competitors.
Sports recruiting has forced the National Collegiate Athletic Association into the predicament of a man fighting a forest fire with a garden hose: 664 memkers and only four investigators.
Textile exports are expected to increase by at least 25 per cent a year over the next few years, John Thompson chairman of USA-Tex, said yesterday.
Carmine Tramunti, a reputed Mafia chief, was convicted yesterday on a Federal charge that portrayed him as "the chairman of the board-the financier" of a massive heroin operation.
An 84-year-old Bronx woman who lived alone was found bludgeoned to death yesterday in her second-floor apartment at 2166 Bronx Park East, near Boston Road.
Governor Wilson will recommend that a state bond issue of $250million be put to the voters this fall to raise capital for commuter and upstate railroad improvements, reliable sources said today.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, one of the world's largest and most controversial conglomerates, reported yesterday that net income in the fourth quarter of 1973 declined 6.6 per cent to $117.2-million from year-earlier levels.

ABRAMSON-Jennle, beloved wife of the late Joseph E., devoted mother of Samuel, David, and the late Diana Goldie, darling grandmother of Joel, Rebecca, Radine and Ellis Jay, loving great grandmother of Rachel. Services Thursday, 9:30 A.M. at "The Riverside," 76 St. and Amsterdam. Ave. Shiva will be at 81 East Cedar Lane, Teaneck, N.J.

All 35 persons aboard a "skier special" airplane were believed killed tonight when the plane crashed into a mountainside in the eastern California Sierra, Sheriff Floyd Barton of Inyo County said. Officials said 35 persons were aboard the Sierra Pacific Airlines Convair 440 that went down about six miles from Bishop.

The Super Bowl winner's payoff of $25,000 a man, an increase in exhibition-game pay to an average of $2,000 a game and "adjustment pay" of perhaps $5,000 a season to retiring players will be among the demands by the National Football League Players Association in negotiations with the club owners for a new collective-bargaining agreement.

" A system that fails to respect its citizens' right to privacy, fails to respect the citizens themselves." This is how President Nixon defined the issue of individual privacy in a recent radio address to the nation, and not even the most scrupulous civil libertarian could ask for a more succinct statement of a crucial but battered principle.

The White House obviously expects bad news on the subject of President Nixon's taxes: a finding that he owes several hundred thousand dollars. In anticipation, it has already retreated to the usual last line of defense-that any wrongdoing was not his fault. He was too busy to worry about tax returns, it is said; any blame attaches to the accountants and lawyers.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass. -"Maybe we need an economic planning agency." Coming from Herbert Stein, this statement might reflect momentary frustration with the inability of the "invisible hand" of the automatic market mechanism to arrest galloping inflation, rising unemployment and mounting shortages of prime necessities.

Judges at the New Jersey interscholastic gymnastic championships this month have been doing doubletakes when the defending champion East Brunswick team took its turn on the apparatus. For two of the four key members in Coach Don Wieder's club are the Gaertner twins, Noel and Marc, who have helped their school extend its domination of the sport for the last three years.

A Federal grand jury has indicted nine of the nation's leading producers of paper labels and eight present or former executives on charges of conspiring to illegally fix prices. The indictments, issued yesterday in San Francisco, said the nine companies accounted for $90-million in sales in 1971.
David Ross, the recently appointed administrative judge of tall state and city courts here, set down new rules yesterday that he promised would make "speedy trials a reality" here.

District Attorney Richard H. Kuh's directive that his assistants refrain from recommending sentences to judges drew a generally unfavorably response yesterday from other New York City prosecutors, sitting judges and lawyers.

In the announcement of the engagement of Miss Tania Lawson-Johnston to Mark Tassie in The New York Times on Sunday, the headline incorrectly identified the future bridegroom's father, John Tassie.
Two errors by Ted Martinez undermined some tight pitching by Jon Matlack today and staked the Montreal Expos to a 4-3 victory over the New York Mets.

A Federal court jury has awarded $3.8-million in antitrust damages against Burroughs Corporation of Detroit to a man whose computer data processing center went bankrupt in 1971.

The Dallas Symphony Orchestra has suspended operations for an indefinite period due to a financial crisis. Kenneth Meine, general manager of the Texas orchestra, said yesterday that the organization was $800,000 in debt and that it would need $1-million to finish the season in the black.

Alan J. Gibbs, former first deputy assistant health commissioner of New York City, has been chosen to serve as deputy commissioner of New Jersey's Institutions and Agencies Department. The department announced in Trenton that Mr. Gibbs, 35 years old, of Haworth, would take charge of management, planning and policy development in the state's largest Cabinet-level agency as soon as the deputy commissioner post was established by the Legisla-, ture later this year.

The era of negotiation may be replacing the era of confrontation in the household as well as on the international scene. The Judiciary Committee of the Massachusetts Legislature heard testimony yesterday on a bill to allow couples to sign contracts specifying the terms of their marriages.

After the market, which rose, had closed, it was reported from Libya that the ministers had decided to end the embargo but would not announce it until Sunday.

Byron Bertram of South Africa, a former Wimbledon junior champion, downed Charlie Owens of Birmingham, Ala., 6-3, 7-5, in the first round of the $25,000 Canadian indoor tennis championships yesterday.

Rosenthal, Queens Democrat, a "coward" on the air.

Joseph E. Berman, a Mississippi food broker and attorney, died a few years ago in a plane crash while en route to a convention. Before he boarded the plane, he bought a $30,000 flight insurance policy, the smallest policy offered, for $1 and named his son as beneficiary.
The ruling political party in the allblack enclave of Transkei has voted unanimously to ask for independence from white South Africa within the next five years.

Tom Weiskopf and Bruce Crampton of Australia, again playing with power and precision, loom as the golfers to beat in the $150,000 Greater Jacksonville open, which begins here tomorrow. Weiskopf and Crampton combined for a total of 11 victories and more than one-half million dollars in prize winnings last season, but both had been fighting mild slums this year.

Roosevelt Leaks, an all-America fullback of the University of Texas, injured ligaments in his right knee today and doctors said he would have to undergo surgery tomorrow. A spokesman for the school said it was doubtful Leaks could be rehabilitated in time for the 1974 football season.

The Metropolitan transportation Authority's quest for $300 million to save New York City' 35-cent transit fare took a few steps forward and a few step backward yesterday. Despite intense maneuvering In Albany and Washington there was no indication tha the months-long fight to keep the fare was nearing a resolution.

Edward Specter, a founder and manager of the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra and a former Broadway producer, died today at West Penn Hospital. Mr. Specter, who was 73 years old, had returned to Pittsburgh last year to practice law.

A would-be bandit was shot by a jewelry-store owner today when he tried to flee with a tray of 43 diamond rings brought out of a safe for his inspection. The police said the victim, Robert Brown, 20 years old, of Jersey City, had been shot once in the left side by Larry Schonborn, 49, owner of the Dansinger Jewelry Store.

General Atomic is a joint venture of Gulf and the Royal Dutch Shell Group.
Bill Goldsworthy's 40th goal of the season broke a tie and later Dennis Hextall scored twice in a 15-second span as the Minnesota North Stars routed the Atlanta Flames, 5-1 tonight in an N.H.L. game.

Superior Court Judge Ralph L. Fusco ruled yesterday in Newark that the prosecution in the double-murder trial of Robert Del Petrarca could use four statements it contended were "confessions," despite defense arguments that the "confessions" had been obtained by "psychological coercion." The judge's ruling ended two days of arguments, outside of the jury's hearing, over whether the statements by the defendant were admissible as evidence.
Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz called today for emergency shifting of rail cars to transportation of fertilizer to assure vitally needed food production.

Prices on the American Stock Exchange rose for the fourth consecutive session. The overthe-counter market also advanced. Trading in both markets increased somewhat on hopes during trading hours for a lifting of the oil embargo by the Arab states against the United States.

A boy who suffered brain damage in 1967 at the age of six when a taxicab struck him at an unguarded school crossing in Brooklyn was awarded $1,237,000 yesterday by a State Supreme Court jury. Judith Somogi does not look like a historical figure, but come Sunday she will be one. On that day, the New York City Opera is going to revive its production of Gilbert and Sullivan's "The Mikado," and Miss Somogi will conduct it.
The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, which lost more than $51-million in 1972, said yesterday that it planned to' resume dividend payments in May, after a suspension of more than a year.

The coup executed by the House Rules Committee in "burying" land use planning legislation the other day may prove to have been more apparent than real. The committee's sudden and arbitrary sidetracking of the bill was a shock, as the measure had already been passed twice by the Senate, warmly supported by the House Interior Committee and supposedly favored by the Administration.

With the Arab oil-exporting states expected to announce the end of their embargo against the United States in the next few days, analysts in Western Europe held out hope that oil prices might drop later in the year under pressure of increased production.

The Environmental Protection Agency proposed yesterday to simplify its standard forbidding smog strong enough to harm human health. The agency proposed to replace its present three-part standard with a single standard,
Could an abstract expressionist artist be expected to know, in 1970, whether death would enhance or decrease the value of the work of another abstract expressionist, Mark Rothko?
A 30-year-old insurance broker was indicted today on a charge that he swindled more than 2,000 people here and abroad out of at least $15million in a get-rich-quick investment scheme.

In a deliberate attempt to spoil the high speed serve and volley game of men's tennis and foster longer rallies instead, American Airlines has resurfaced the asphalt courts with a rough finish for its $150,000 tennis games March 18 through 24 at Mrs. Margaret Court's Racquet Club Ranch in Tucson, Ariz. Seeded players include such serving powerhouses as John Newcombe and Stan Smith, as well as Rod Laver, Arthur Ashe, Tom Okker and Ken Rosewall.

Mitsui Co., a major Japanese trading concern, said today it had received an inquiry from the Soviet Union concerning a possible purchase of eight ammonium manufacturing plants valued at $400- to $500-million. Each would be capable of producing 1,350 metric tons of ammonium a day.
Guatemala's left-leaning opposition front has apparently resigned itself to the re-election of the governing conservative coalition despite its claim of election fraud.
The White House announced today the resignation of Treasury Secretary George P. Shultz, effective in early May.

Judge Theodore Trautwein to day upheld the constitutionality of a "moral pledge" backing the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority's bonds, He also ruled that the authority had the right to lease tax exempt facilities to a private profit-making organization like the New York Football Giants.
The government of Quebec, after years of controversy and debate, announced today that it had decided to proclaim French the official language of the province.
Portugal's two leading generals were dismissed tonight for advocating an end to the nation's wars against guerrillas in her African territories through a policy of offering political concessions.

Fipance Minister Pinhas Sapir told Israelis today that they would have to tighten their belts to help defray higher costs of maintaining national security after the October war.
Morris Bienenfeld, who retired two years ago as president and board chairman of the Florida Glass and Mirror Company, died here yesterday. His age was 75, and he lived here.

Benjamin J. Malcolm, the city's Commissioner of Correction since January, 1972, was reappointed yesterday to the $39,563-a-year post. The appointment had been held up because the Bronx Democratic organization had suggested Milton Williams, a Bronx lawyer, for the post. On Wednesday, however, Mayor Beame named Mr. Williams as Commissioner of the Office for Veteran Action.

Ezzes, chairman of the board and chief executive officer of United Artists Television, Inc. Rabbi David M. Posner performed the ceremony.

Maggie Bell, who appears as the opening act for Foghat and Frampton's Camel at the Academy of Music for two shows tomorrow night, must be tired of being compared to the late Janis Joplin, but the comparison remains an inevitable one.

International President Nixon made several important foreign policy statements in a nationally televised question-and-answer session at the Executive Club of Chicago. He warned Arab nations not to attach conditions to the expected removal of the oil embargo and said the United States "is not going to be pressured" in its efforts to bring about a disengagement of Israeli and Syrian troops.
" 6 Rms Riv Vu" is classified-ad shorthand for an apartment alleged to have six rooms and a view of the river. It is also the title of a successful Broadway play by Bob Randall.

A circus aerialist, Jacqueline Serbini, was reported in good condition today after falling 30 feet to a concrete floor last night when the rigging on her high-wire act collapsed at the end of her performance.

Joseph Edward Unsworth, who retired four years ago as chief of transportation-service contracts in the State Department's Bureau of Cultural and Educational Affairs, died Thursday at Georgetown Hospital in Washington. He was 65 years old and lived in College Park, Md.
Texaco, one of the country's largest oil companies, announced yesterday that it had completed the purchase of 95 acres in Harrison, N. Y., where it expects to develop a major office facility.

The jury in the corruptionconspiracy trial of Representative Frank J. Brasco deliberated for three hours and 50 minutes yesterday before being excused by Federal District Judge Inzer B. Wyatt until 10 A.M. Monday.

, the Swedish economist, has been named to receive the first Frank E. Seidman Distinguished Award in Political Economy. He is scheduled to receive the $10,000 award at a banquet given by Memphis State University on May 20.

Not even a 15-point lead late in the second quarter was enough to prevent the New York Knicks from suffering their annual Portland prattfall tonight as they lost to the Trail Blazers, 107-105, before a crowd of 10,160.

The police reported today what they said was the city's first "gasjacking." A driver for the Arco Petroleum Company rolled into a service station shortly after midnight to fill the station's underground tanks.

Louis D. Davidow, a retired F interior decorator and a founding member of the National Society of Interior Designers, died Monday in Mount Vernon Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived at 89-50 56th Avenue; G Rego Park. Queens.

The South Vietnamese Government and the Vietcong bitterly denounced each other today over a mortar shell that killed 32 children and wounded 56 children and adults at a primary school in the Mekong Delta last week.
A state court has ordered the Roman Catholic Bishop of Baton Rouge to pay a $150 fine or spend 30 days in jail for driving while intoxicated.

Don Adams tossed in 21 points and Bob Lanier added 19 points and as many rebounds as the Detroit Pistons held off the Milwaukee Bucks, 93-89, tonight to clinch a spot in the National Basketball Association playoffs as a wild-card team.

More than 3,000 New York City policemen are studying for New York Institute of Technology degrees. In most cases they do not have to leave their precinct houses to attend college classes. Instead, faculty members travel to the precint houses to give the instruction.

The aviation pioneer Henri Pequet, who became the first flying postman when he carried mail by plane in 1911, has died at his home here, friends said today. He was 86 years old.

J., for four steam turbogenerators of about 1.23 million kilowatt capacity each. The generating equipment is for use in a new four-unit nuclear power installation that is being planned for commercial operation in 1980-82 to help meet projected demand of the T.V.A. area at that time.

A Federal civil rights official said yesterday that the Government would make changes in its proposed pupil data questionnaire, intended to be given next month to 100,000 elementary school pupils here, to meet the "legitimate" concerns of the New York City Board of Education.
Industrial production declined in February for the third consecutive month, with automobile output still a major factor, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
President Nixon declared today that he would not resign and that he refused to "be a party to the destruction of the Presidency of the United States."

But all three networks have rejected the idea as a dangerous precedent.

PARIS--The petulance now featuring United States relationships with France is ridiculous and unnecessary. From certain remarks attributed to Henry Kissinger one must conclude he should never be indiscreet in private, which he now inferentially acknowledges.

Charlie Evans, a New York Giant running back who was suspended briefly during the 1973 National Football League season, will sign with the Washington Ambassadors of the World Football League on Monday, The Associated Press learned yesterday. The A.P. also learned that Danny White of Arizona State, the first quarterback selected in the N.F.L. draft-taken by Dallas in the third round-will sign with the W.F.L.'s Toronto team Monday.
All but a handful of the major coal mines in southern West Virginia were back in operation today, marking the end of a two-and-a-half-week strike over gasoline allocations.

About 35 tenants of the Knickerbocker Hotel, which the city has ordered vacated as unfit for human habitation, stayed in or near their rooms yesterday for fear that the police stationed in the lobby would not permit them to return if they went out even for food.

Bill Ficker, an Amnerica's Cup champion, and Hugh Treharne, the sole Australian entrant, scored double victories yesterday on the opening day of the three-day Congressional Cup yacht racing series, which was plagued by fog.

Governor Wilson's three-part transportation package shrewdly combines promised assistance for hard-pressed mass transit in New York and other cities with two railroad aid proposals designed to garner rural support. The initial section of the Wilson program, which would provide $100 million in transit operating subsidies, has clear merit. Although the present draft omits a desirable legislative suggestion to include incentive bonus for new riders, the proposal generally provides for a fair distribution of funds.
The Japanese Foreign Ministry said today that Japan had decided to join a new multilateral textile trade agreement drafted by the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.

Russell P. Kantor, president of Victor Gloves, Inc., manufacturer, and a past grand director of ceremonies of the Masonic order's Grand Lodge of the State of New York, died Wednesday in the DeWitt Nursing Home.

Nearly 600 residents of Nassau and Suffolk Counties confronted an official of the Public Service Commission at a hearing here today and angrily told him that they would not tolerate a proposed 18 per cent increase in their electricity bills.
Former Senator , Democrat of North Carolina, who led the 1964 Senate investigation into the activities of Bobby Baker, the Senate aide accused of influence peddling, died at his home today.

John G. Dow, a Tormer Representative who had announced that he would seek the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate, said today that he had changed his mind and would seek the 26th District seat.

James S. Linburn, a retired partner in Vilas Hickey, an investment securities firm, died Thursday in University Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived at 1125 Park Avenue and in Long Branch, N.J.

The Senate vote of 54 to 33 to restore the death penalty for a number of vaguely defined Federal crimes allows a dismal glimpse into the savage irrationality beneath the veneer of civilized society. Giving the state power to kill as a means of deterring criminal killers is an empty threat.

A disgruntled former employe allegedly set a fire in the basement of Doctors Hospital tonight, forcing administrators to transfer or discharge 70 of the 176 patients, the police said. The only injuries reported were to two volunteer firemen who were overcome by smoke during the 90-minute fire.

Brother Francis Joseph Kapp, a member of the Roman Catholic teaching order of the Brothers of the Christian Schools for 62 years, died Thursday at St. Joseph's Hospital, Yonkers. He was 78 years old and was a member of the Brothers community at Manhattan College.
Oliver J. Sterling, a senior partner in the law firm of Law. ler,. Sterling Kent, died yesterday at his home, 941 Park Avenue. He was 67 years old and also lived in East Hampton, L.I.

The availability of gasoline in the Metropolitan area appears to be improving for this weekend, particularly for tomorrow, when more service stations will be open than on any other Sunday since President Nixon called last November for voluntary Sunday closing, the Automobile Club of New York said yesterday.

Dean Witter Co., Inc., the wholly owned investment banking subsidiary of the Dean Witter Organization, Inc., reported yesterday a net income of $1.2million for the second fiscal quarter ended Feb. 28, down from $1.4-million a year ago.

The American Broadcasting Company has canceled the guest appearance of Mrs, Richard M. Nixon on tomorrow's "Issues and Answers" television interview, because of a dispute with the White House over ground rules for her appearance.

The birth of a son to the wife of Jonathan L. Goldstein, the Acting United States Attorney, caused an unexpected recess today in the campaign-fraud trial of Nelson G. Gross, the former state Republican chairman.
Richard R. Deupree, honorary chairman and former president and board chairman of Procter Gamble, died yesterday in Holmes Hospital. He was 88 years old and.lived here.

The stock market did little yesterday, but what it did was negative. It opened on the downside, with the Dow-Jones industrial index at 884.23, down 5.55 from Thursday. By 2:30 P.M. it was off only 0.31 and by the close it was down 1.95 at 887.83.

New Jersey state officials said today that they were investigating a search for contraband at the Trenton State Prison in which inmates have charged that many cells were "torn apart" and that prisoners' belongings were broken or confiscated.
E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., announced yesterday that it had entered into an agreement with Iranian interests to form a joint venture to produce polyester and acrylic fibers in Iran.

President Nixon warned the European allies today that failure to cooperate with the United States in political and economic fields could lead to a substantial cut in American military forces based in Europe.

A $4 book by a general seeking to make his pen as mighty as his sword has changed the face of Portuguese politics. The book is called "Portugal and the Future," News and it burst upon a startled PortuAnalysis guese public Feb. 22 like a bomb.

Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's Government, faced with a two-month-old student-led revolt that has killed 80 people in Gujarat, dissolved that state's legislature tonight.

A Government request for an adjournment of the extortion trial of Representative Angelo D. Roncallo, Republican of the Third Congressional District and two other defendants, was granted "reluctantly" yesterday by Edward R. Neaher, a Federal judge in Brooklyn.
Mills Hobby Husted 3d of 387 Nbrth Maple Avenue, Greenwich, lawyer and yachtsman, died today at Greenwich Hospital after a short illness. His age was 84.

Oklahoma State crept into a narrow lead tonight in the 44th National Collegiate wrestling championships but was closely pursued by crosssate rival Oklahoma.
Two young Britons jailed on charges of spying appealed for freedom today at a public hearing before a Yugoslav court-martial here.

Judge Herbert J. Kenarik, judge of the Essex County Juvenile and Domestic Relations Court here since 1963, died yesterday of a heart attack. He was 68 years old and lived at 377 South Harrison Street in East Orange.

Thomas Barman, who was the British Broadcasting Corporation's diplomatic correspondent for 21 years, died last night at the age of 70. Mr. Barman covered every major international conference from the time he joined the B.B.C. in 1946 until his retirement in 1967.

E. Howard Hunt Jr., the Watergate burglar and former C.I.A. operative, has begin writing his memoirs, his publisher said yesterday, and he has been guaranteed "a substantial six figure" sum against his eventual royalties.

In separating the prosecutorial function from the judicial obligation to impose sentencing, District Attorney Kuh of New York County has taken a purist and sound position that deserves a chance in practice. Plea bargaining (the method whereby an assistant district attorney reduces the charge against an accused) and sentence bargaining (where the judge agrees to impose a shorter jail term) are clearly related.
Consolidated Edison announced yesterday that it expected to begin construction of its controversial pumped-storage generating plant near Storm King Mountain in Cornwall-on. Hudson within a month.

The State Lottery Commission reported today that it had recovered more than $150,000 and suspended 14 sales agents as the result of a two-month investigation of alleged fraud and irregularities involving lottery receipts.

Back In the good old days of matriarchy, the Earth Mother goddess's favorite form of worship is said to have been the belly dance. And, who knows, the Earth Mother may have been gazing down upon the National Organization for Women's center at 47 East 19th Street on Thursday night.
Vice President Ford said today that the staff of the House Judiciary Committee appeared to be seeking to "dictate proceedings" involving empeachment of Preiident Nixon.

The first-seeded team of Pancho Gonzalez and Jimmy Connors defeated Alex Olmedo and Ham Richardson, 2-6, 7-5, 6-4, today in the quarterfinals of the Tennis Masters tournament, matching Hall of Fame players with current pros.

There is a curious mix of esthetic values at the corner of 79th Street and Park Avenue now that a Henry Moore sculpture has been installed, with conspicuous fanfare, in front of a big, new apartment house. It could be called throwing good art after a bad building, since the event forces on the spectator a comparison of the art of sculpture and the art of architecture.

Lillian Mae Frink, a former state representative and town official, died yesterday at Villa Maria Convalescent Hospital in Plainfield. She was 91 years old and the widow of Clinton E. Frink.

A secretary in the Essex County Prosecutor's office testified today that the 26-year-old window washer on trial for the murder of two Upper Montclair women last May had confessed to her in a private conversation that he killed them.

Striking city workers and the San Francisco Board of Supervisors settled today a nine-day walkout that had snarled public transit and crippled city hospital operations. Victor Thuesen, a union spokesman, said that the workers would return to their jobs as quickly as possible.

As the strike here against the CIBAGeigy Corporation by Local 9, International Chemical Workers Union, enters its eighth week, scientific workers at the pharmaceutical plant are complaining that they are being forced to perform janitorial and animal-maintenance duties.

Walt Tkaczuk of the Rangers suffered a fracture of the jaw Thursday night against the Chicago Black Hawks and will be out of action for an indefinite period.

FOOTBALL KANSAS CITY (AFC)-Signed Tom Condon, Boston College offensive guard, 10th-round draft choice; Bob Thornbladh, Michigan fullback, 11th-round draft choice; Carl Brown, West Texas State wide receiver, 12th-round draft choice, and Norm Romagnoll, Kentucky State linebacker, 13th-round draft choice.

The Federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission says it has found "reasonable cause" that Tufts University is guilty of sex discrimination in refusing to rehire one woman professor and in denying tenure to another.

The Government said today that it would not give any more money to the Louisiana Family Health Foundation, a private family planning program that has been accused of multimillion - dollar irregularities.
The Cost of Living Council exempted today the newspaper, broadcasting, advertising and other communications industries from price controls.

There were two 1973-74 basketball Seasons for Morristown High School. The first produced a 14-6 won-lost record that resulted in a second-place finish in the Jersey Hills Conference. During the campaign the Colonials of Coach Ed Blackmon dropped a pair of 3-point decisions to the league champion, Hanover Park.

TOYAMA, Japan-Ben Villaflor, 127 pounds, the Philippines, beat Apollo Yoshio, 1291/2 pounds, Japan, 15 rounds. LOS ANGELES-Jose Luis Garcia, 213 pounds, Venezuela, outpointed Bob Mashburn, 220 pounds, New York, 10.

More than 2,000 disabled and elderly people held a rally yesterday in the auditorium at Pace College here to demand emergency funds because, they contended, a new Federal assistance program is not working.
Three persons were killed today as terrorists staged a series of bombing attacks and hijacked trains, buses and trucks throughout Northern Ireland.
The $2-million food giveaway established in an effort to obtain the release of Patricia Hearst, a kidnapping victim, was reported near an end today because of a lack of funds,

The Agriculture Department announced today a transfer of 158,540 tons in the 1974 United States sugar quota to 19 other foreign countries because some production areas could not provide their full share. Officials said the redistribution was the result of deficits in Puerto Rico, 55,000 tons; the Texas sugar cane area, 40,000, and Venezuela, 63,540 tons.
The British Government announced today that it would continue to guarantee the value of certain foreign holdings of sterling until the end of this year.

Most of the Yankees had an easy workday today, but Bill Virdon didn't get a rest from the multitude of line-up variations that keep swirling around in his managerial head.

The Jersey Knights erupted for three goals in 80 seconds early in the second period, two of them by Wayne Rivers, and went on to hand the Minnesota Fighting Saints a 5-3 World Hockey Association setback tonight.

Arnold R. Miller, the president of the United Mine Workers of America, lost today his third attempt in a month to win the concurrence of other union officials in his plan to move the U.M.W. headquarters to West Virginia. his home state.

Clark E. Squire, a 36-year-old black militant and admitted member of the Black Liberation Army, was sentenced to life in prison here today by a Middlesex County Court Judge for having murdered a New Jersey state policeman in a turnpike shootout last May 2.

Bill Steele's second goal of the game at 31 seconds into overtime tonight gave Michigan Tech a 6-5 victory over Harvard in a semifinal game of the National Collegiate Athletic Association hockey tournament.

Jose Toha Gonzales, a former interior and later Defense Minster in the Marxist Government of the late Dr. Salvador Allende Gossens, committed suicide by hanging himself, the military unta of Chile reported today.

Even though oil prices and profits have been climbing almost vertically, Congress appears reluctant to take back any of the tax breaks from that industry. It would be unnecessary to consider now such emergency expedients as windfall or excess profits taxes if oil companies were simply taxed on the same basis as others.

Mrs. Pauline Eisenstein Schwartz, a psychologist with the Bureau of Child Guidance in New York from 1945 to 1965, died yesterday on a visit here. She was 81 years old and lived at 8 Highland Court, Far Rockaway, Queens.

Edward A Hodge, a vice president and a director of Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, Inc., the publishers, died Wednesday evening of a heart ailment in Northern Westchester Hospital in Mount Kisco. He was 63 years old and lived here until recently.

When the luck of the Irish ran out last night Notre Dame's basketball players must have been wondering just how unlucky they could be. Completely surprised by the talents of a fast, good-shooting Michigan team, Notre Dame compounded its problem by missing 61.3 per cent of its shots and was upset by the Wolverines, 77-68, in the Mideast regional of the National Collegiate championship tournament.

Col. Robert S. Beard, Army Corps of Engineers, retired, who taught spatial geometry at Yeshiva University in New York, died Wednesday in Arcata, Calif. He was 91 years old and lived in Trinidad, Calif.

President Nixon's personal secretary, Rose Mary Woods, has been subpoenaed to appear for the prosecution in the Mitchell-Stans conspiracy trial here, The Washington Star News said yesterday.
Kareem Abdul-Jabbar got 38 points, 22 rebounds and a black eye today in leading the Milwaukee Bucks to a 107-82 triumph over the Chicago Bulls.

Senator Edward M. Kennedy has told Secretary of State Kissinger that a cablegram from the United States Ambassador in South Vietnam has raised the "worst kind of innuendo" about Congressional criticisms of American policy in Indochina.
Memphis State a team of recent basketball glory, and Boston College, on its way back, gained the quarterfinals of the National Invistation Tournament last night at Madison Square Garden.
There was little resemblance between the defending National League champion Mets and the team that staggered through a 9-2 loss to the Los Angeles Dodgers here today.
The Saigon command said today that South Vietnamese and Communist troops battled in the Central Highlands over the weekend, with more than 500 casualties on both sides.
, who introduced strained baby foods to millions of Americans, died last night after a brief illness. He was 75 years old.

Mrs. Margaret Davenport Griffith, wife of Dr. Ernest Stacey Griffith, retired director of the Congressional research service of the Library of Congress and founding dean of the School of International Service at American University, died yesterday of cancer in the Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore. She was 69 years old and lived here.

President Nixon's outburst in Chicago against the European allies makes it clear that serious difficulties have again overtaken Secretary of State Kissinger's year-long flickering effort to reinvigorate the Atlantic Alliance and establish a "special relationship" with the nine-nation Common Market. The vehemence with which Mr. Nixon wielded his bludgeon was apparently designed to pave the way for yesterday's disclosure that he has decided to cancel his projected April visit to those allies in Europe.
The United States Ambassador to Switzerland, Shelby Cullom Davis, has given $750,000 to Wellesley College to establish a professorship in Slavic studies at the school.
Jasmine Twyman, a 52year-old black day worker, recently won $60 at Bingo but that wasn't enough to pay for the lavish party she threw here last night for her white employers from Croton-on-Hudson.

SEASONAL Yesterday was St. Patrick's Day, and the accent is still on the Irish. There's an unusual twoweek series of lectures, free to the public, which is starting today and running through March 31, that should tell you all you might want to know about the Irish and Ireland, and then some.

Sparky Lyle,. the missing relief pitcher, finally arrived in camp, nine days after the Yankees invoked the renewal option clause in his contract. He's still unsigned but will work out.... Pat Dobson became the first Yankee pitcher to work four innings this spring, shutting out the Tigers on two hits and extending his scoreless performance for exhibition play to 10 innings.... Yankees won the game with a four-run outburst in the fifth.
New York State is planning to build a new salmon hatchery to increase the salmon population in Lake Ontario and Lake Erie and to promote sport-fishing.
A group of scholars proposes in a report being made public today the establishment of an insurance system to make it easier for college teachers to leave their profession at midcareer.

Four short fiction collections and a very long novel, Thomas Pynchon's "Gravity's Rainbow," are among the 110 books designated as leading contenders for the 10 annual $1,000 National Book Awards, which are to be announced and given out here April 18.
Teachers in .the Kansas City School District voted overwhelmingly today to go on strike tomorrow against the 62,000-student district, union officials said.
Reformers were firmly in control today as the Democratic Party's charter commission approved the first written rules for any major American political party.

Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, who has one of the biggest campaign funds in Congress, said today that he was conducting a feasibility study to see whether he should seek the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1976.

The Boston Celtics locked up their third straight National Basketball Association Atlantic Division title tonight as Paul Westphal and Artie Williams sparked a 129-103 Victory over the Capital Bullets.
, the Secretary of State of New Jersey, has been summoned to testify Thursday before a state grand jury investigation of alleged corruption involving highway construction in the state.
Montreal's lanky defenseman, Larry Robinson, and Capt. Henri Richard each blasted in two goals tonight and led the Canadiens to a 4-2 victory over the New York Islanders.

For nearly a year a special search committee set up by the board of directors of the trouble-wracked Health and Hospitals Corporation has been combing the country in quest of the best-qualified administrator it could find to head New York City's $900-million-a-year hospital system.
President Nixon has advised the European Common Market that he has canceled his plans to go to Europe next month for a meeting with European heads of government, it was disclosed today.
Forrest King Moses of Eagle Bridge, son of the primitive painter "Grandma" Moses, died yesterday at Albany Medical Center Hospital. He was 76 years old.

Secretary of State Kissinger has told his top aides that he will probably leave on another trip to the Middle East around April 20 to try to conclude a troop. separation agreement between Syria and Israel in the Golan Heights area.

Haldeman, President Nixon used the words "it would be wrong" only when the idea of clemency for Watergate burglars was brought up and not during talk of paying them money to keep quiet.

Melvin R. Laird announced today the names of seven elected officials who will be advisers on a national energy project. Dozens of gasoline stations opened for business even though it was a Sunday,'families took to their cars in droves, creating heavy' traffic on major arteries, and only high gasoline prices-remained to remind car owners of their winter ordeal.

A senior Dan Anderson and a sophomore, Bob Trowbridge, combined to score 9 points in overtime to send 15th-ranked Southern California to victory over Bradley, 76-73, today in a Collegiate Commissioners Association basketball tournament semifinal game.

A Federal judge here will decide in a month or so whether a school operated by a religious sect has a right to refuse admission to black students on the ground that the Bible prohibits commingling of the races.

" Which one of you guys is Sep Palin?" a man asked the two leathery old horsemen who were getting into silks in a locker room near the paddock at Pompano Park Raceway. "And which is Nat Ray?" The leathery old horsemen didn't seem to recognize either name, which was a surprise because Sep Palin and Nat Ray were legendary figures in harness racing.

The sun shined brightly on today's St. Patrick's Day parade along Kennedy Boulevard, warming thousands of marchers and onlookers.

Steve Jones scored 15 of his game-high 25 points in the third quarter to lead the Denver Rockets to a 101-90 victory over the Virginia Squires in the A.B.A. tonight. The victory broke a sevengame losing streak for Denver, which is battling San Diego for a playoff berth.

Arab oil ministers again postponed the expected lifting of the oil embargo against the United States and scheduled another meeting today. Sheik Ahmed Zaki al-Yamani, the Saudi Arabian Minister of Petroleum Affairs, said last night in Vienna, where the oil conference is being held, that "you can say categorically the embargo will be lifted tomorrow." He also said that oil production will be raised. [1:8.]

The Assembly minority leader, Thomas H. Kean, Republican of Essex, plans to introduce legislation banning campaign contributions by corporations and placing a $500 ceiling on individual contributions. The bill also would ban cash contributions or more than $25 and would prohibit the acceptance of contributions within two weeks of Election Day.

Calm prevailed in Ossining, N. Y., yesterday as officials enforced a 7 P.M.-to-6 A.M. curfew that was imposed after racial rioting by teen-agers last Friday night. One girl was arrested on Saturday for violating the curfew, the police said. They gave no details but said there had been no disturbances during the night.

To the Editor: Much has been said in recent months about the "immense burden" on the balance of payments of Western countries created by the quadrupling of oil prices. Rates in the credit markets, as measured by three different indexes, stood at week's end at their highest levels since last summer. A fourth index reached its highest point since the end of January.

The Government appeared today to be in complete control of the country after putting down an army revolt yesterday.

It was almost back to normal -- pre-energy crisis style--for motorists in the New York area yesterday. Dozens of gasoline stations opened for business even though it was a Sunday, families took to their cars in droves, creating heavy traffic on major arteries, and only high gasoline prices remained to remind car owners of their winter ordeal.

The estimated cost of the Rockwell International B-I bomber program has risen $1.3-billion to $15-billion be cause of a recent program change and an allowance for greater inflation, informed De fense Department sources saidtoday.

After eight months of litiga tion, a complex pollution trial is nearing completion in Fed eral District Court here in which the trial judge informed the defendant, the Reserve Min ing Company, that its discharge of ore processing waste into Lake Superior and the air had created a "very substantialpublic health menace."

One hundred paintings sold by the executors of the estate of Mark Rothko for an average of $18,000 each to the Marl borough Gallery should have brought an average of $40,000 to $50,000 instead, the presi dent of a rival gallery testifiedin Surrogate's Court yesterday.

The Justice Depart ment is stepping up its antitrust investigation of the oil industry by forming an energy unit in the antitrust division to prepare and try antitrust cases. Thomas E. Neither Mickey Mantle nor Willie Mays, the two rank ing "special coaches," attended the annual reunion of the Yankees and Mets. The United States and Canada overwhelmed weak opposition today in the first two rounds of the world curling championship. They share the lead with Switzerland, which upset Swedenthe defending champion, 6-2.

The Indiana Hoosiers, playing inspired, rugged bas ketball after Coach Bobby Knight was rejected from the game, defeated Southern Cal ifornia, 85-60, tonight to win the inaugural Collegiate Com missioners Association basketball tournament.

The list of 1972 Nixon cam paign contributors made public yesterday during the court tes timony of Rose Mary Woods, President Nixon's personal sec retary, is 123 pages long and contains hundreds of names,divided according to state.

The energy crisis has forced some serious rethinking of the nation's $5 billion-a-year Federal highway pro gram. With gasoline in short supply and the long-term outlook precarious, it is doubtful wisdom to invest in additional highways for gasoline-hungry automobilesrather than in energy-savings railroads.

The State Depart ment said today that the Unit ed States had agreed to help sweep mines from the Suez Canal. Informed sources said mine sweeping helicopters would probably be sent to the MiddleEast soon.

Sharp drops in operating in come and net income so far this year were reported yester day by the Consolidated Edison Company to the state Public Service Commission. They were attributed in part to reduced sales as a result of conserva tion efforts and in part to increasing costs.

Purdue and Maryland East ern Shore, which knocked off favored teams in the first round of the National Invi tation Tournament, will at tempt to continue their climb to the tournament title to night in quarterfinal-round action at Madison SquareGarden.

Cambodia reaffirmed today the extent of her conti nental shelf as she claimed it in a decree in July, 1972. Once again, Chatham Borough's basketball team frus trated many of its opponents this season-not only by winning most of its games, but also by the method it used to win. The Morris County team, which was finally stopped by Orange in the state tournament last Saturday, has become legendary for employing the slow, deliberate style offense. That tactic has been a key ingredient in theschool's 60 victories in the last three seasons.

The death rate from heart at tacks and heart disease in the United States is going down, a Federal health official said yes terday. New studies of health statis tics show "a steady decline" in the death rate of 10-11 per cent since 1963, compared with "an unremitting increase" of 18 per cent from 1940 to 1963, the official said.
