Around the turn of the century gold hunters from all over the world con verged on the rich lodes in the harsh Canadian north. That heyday of the lone prospector-the "sourdough" -is long gone, though mech anized mines still make Can nada, the third largest producer of gold.

Canned fruits and vege tables were removed from price controls today by the Cost of Living Council in its first ac tion toward decontrolling the food industry. But the council indicated there would not be a big jump in consumer prices of cannedgoods in the weeks ahead.

With the stroke of a pen and a lengthy round of backslapping and picture-taking, Governor Wilson made some election year mileage with the Team sters Union today as he signed a law that mandates wage levels on nonunion garbage and moving-van companies that dobusiness with the state.

George T. Hook, who retired in 1968 as executive vice president of Chilton Company, publisher of industrial magazines, including Iron Age, which he edited for many years, died Sunday in the Yale-New Haven Medical Center. He was 74 years old and had lived in Westport, Conn., since his retirement.

Most Arab oil nations finally announced yesterday an end to their embargo on oil shipments to the United States. The an nouncement came near 1 P.M., at which point the Dow-Jones industrial average was off 5.71points at 882.12.

The state's mental-health pro gram came under strong at tack yesterday, with Repre sentative Odgen R. Reid and Howard J. Samuels, two of the leading Democratic candidates for Governor, saying they would make it a major campaign issue.

TEL AVIV, March 18--Israel lost two dead and three injured today in artillery and tank duels on the Syrian front, an army announcement said. Reports from the front said that observation posts had seen fires in Syrian ammunition dumps, antitank positions, tanks, jeeps, and other vehicles.
Housing starts, one of the two major sectors of the economy showing weakness, turned around with a strong increase in February from January, the Commerce Department reportedtoday.

Manuel Santana of Spain, who triumphed at Wimbledon and at Forest Hills before retiring from big-time tennis four years ago, yesterday was named player-coach of the New York Sets of the World Team Tennis League. The 35-year-old star is the first man to be signed by the Sets who previ ously came to terms with Fiorella Bonicelli of Peru andBeatriz Araujo of Argentina.

The trustees of the Penn Central Transportation Company reiterated yesterday a position they have taken for the last year. Their position is that the bankrupt railroad cannot be reorganized as an independent money-making entity.

The Mobil Oil Corporation and some of its Connecticut gasoline dealers are pitted against one another in a battle that typifies the nationwide fight for survival of independent service station operators.

Cambodian re bels today captured Phsar Oudong, a former royal capital 24 miles northwest of Phnom Penh, the military command said. It was the first major town to fall to the Communistsin more than three years.
A Federal judge today sentenced an airplane hijacker to 50 years in jail after the prosecutor urged a penalty "so severe that others will thinktwice before attempting it."

If Marianne Leonard had to surrender just one of the appliances in her stainless steel and butcher block kitchen, which would it be? Her microwave oven. "That's the one thing I could do with out," the Westport, Conn., woman says."Everything cooks so darn fast.

Two courts -- one in northern Italy and the other in the south - began new efforts today to solve the mystery of a 1969 bombing incident in which 16 persons were killed and about 80 injured. Two apparently un connected sets of defendants were accused of the samecrime.

Concern about the future of Chinese-American rela tions has been aroused by disquieting recent develop ments in the riddle wrapped in a mystery inside an enigma that is the internal politics of Communist China. Western diplomats and journalists in Peking have found their access to medium-level Chinese officials much reduced.
An angry crowd of 600 electric-consumers and local political leaders Switched their attack today at a hear ing on a proposed rate in crease from Consolidated Edi son to the Public ServiceCommission.

The Arab oil countries, except Libya and Syria, ended their oil embargo against the United States and moved to restore produc tion to meet the needs of American consum ers. Saudi Arabia pledged an immediate production increase of a million barrels a day for the United States market, which would restore half the current deficit inAmerican imports of Arabian oil. [1:1.]
A 15-year-old schoolboy was shot and critically wounded yesterday as he stood with a group of boys at Canal and Forsyth Streets near PublicSchool 65 in Chinatown.

Manuel Santana of Spain, who triumphed at Wimbledon and at Forest Hills before retiring from big-time tennis four years ago, yesterday was named player-coach of the New York Sets of theWorld Team Tennis League.

The overwhelming Democratic ma jority in the State Senate ap proved a Byrne administration measure this evening providing a 50 per cent increase of the state's urban aid program,raising it to $36-million a year.

Rich ard W. DeKorte, New Jersey's energy administrator, said today that he almost turned down the job of counsel to former Gov. William T. Cahill last year be cause he "was reluctant to be come associated with the Cahilladministration."

A prominent consultant has declared that a major housing subsidy program here - which the Lindsay administration con sidered a leading accomplish ment and which is continuing under the Beame administration -is a multimillion-dollar sub sidy for luxury-housing con struction that should be terminated.

State regulatory agencies can not set minimum prices for nat ural gas sold within the state without violating the Constitu tion, under a decision affirmed today by the Supreme Court.The vote was 6 to 3.
The 73-year-old William K. Vanderbilt mansion, which has served as the administra tion building of Dowling Col lege in Oakdale, L. I., since 1968, was heavily damaged byfire early yesterday.

The Arab oil producers seem finally to have made it official. Their lifting of the five-month embargo against the United States removes the proximate cause of the winter's dramatic fuel shortages. But the frailty of the reopened supply lines is underlined by the Arabs' declared intention to "review" this decision next June, on the basis of whether United States policy in theMiddle East still warrants their favor.
Mrs. Gunnar Kronholm, the wife of a South St. Paul banker, who was kidnapped last Friday, was released un harmed today by one of her abductors, the Federal Bureauof Investigation announced.
Bond prices continued to move lower yesterday in quiet trading. In the Government market intermediate Issues extended declines registered last week and Treasury bills also moved higher
The Federal Bureau of Investi nation has come out against the sealing of some criminal records as proposed in biparti san legislation before a Senatesubcommittee.

The announcement that most Arab countries were lifting their embargo against the United States was greeted here today with restraint, partly because it had been anticipated and partly because the official statement said nothing about increases in the production ofcrude oil.
The Army is moving to correct a vulnerability that was discovered in its main battle tank during last fall's ArabIsraeli war.

The United States and Canada overwhelmed weak opposition today in the first two rounds of the world curling championship. They share the lead with Ewitzerland, which upset Sweden,,the defending champion, 6-2.
The eternal light has been put out at the Chasam Sopher Synagogue, at 8 Clinton Street, on the Lower East Side. A dwindling congrega tion is afraid that the lightwould attract vandals.

Spurred by outbreaks in Eu rope and Asia of a puzzling, newly discovered disease caused by a fish parasite, the Food and Drug Administration is seeking to protect Americans, whose appetites for raw fish disheshave grown recently.

The grocery windows are still piled with exotic in gredients, pungent cooking aromas still drift from restau rants--but Chinatown is feel ing the pinch of rising food prices in ways that affect restaurant economics aswell as private eating habits.
John Cappelletti, the 1973 Heisman Trophy winner from Penn State, signed a four year contract today with theLos Angeles Rams.
Most of the Arab oil countries an nounced officially today that they would lift the embargo against shipments to the United States that they had imposed during the Middle East war oflast October.

The recent Tony awards committee decision classifying "Candide" and "Lorelei" as eligible for the annual An toinette Perry (Tony) musical awards has stirred a series of protests from various managements of musical revivals.

Secretary of State Kissinger has been told privately by two key Senators that they would consider trade concessions for the Soviet Union only if Mos cow guaranteed that the flow of Jewish and other emigres would continue at a yearly rate well in excess of the current35,000.
The Yankees and Mets shared a home away from home tonight in their annual spring reunion 1,100 miles from New York, with the Mets teasing out a 1-0victory.

Pavel M. Litvinov, grandson of a former Soviet Foreign Minis ter and one of the most promi nent Soviet dissidents, arrived in the West today. An official of the Jewish Agency said Mr. Litvinov would not return tothe Soviet Union.

Lute Olson, the Long Beach State basket ball coach frustrated by Na tional College Athletic Asso ciation probation because of alleged recruiting violations by his predecessor, quit as basketball coach of the ninth ranked 49ers today to takethe same post at Iowa.
The failure of the favorite to leave the gate for the start of the sixth race at Aqueduct yesterday nearly caused an outbreak by sev eral hundred fans in the crowd of 17.749.

HOUSTON--President Nixon arrives today to visit "Baghdad on the Bayou" and there are a few billboards up around town that say, "Welcome to Houston, President Nixon." They were paid for by Metromedia, Inc., whichis headquartered in New York City.

The prosecution put Rose Mary Woods, President Nixon's personal secretary, on the wit ness stand in the Mitchell-Stans trial yesterday, and she prompt ly told the jury that each defendant was "a fine man."

Having dismissed the idea of sitting out the season altogether, Sparky Lyle, the Yankee's flamboy ant and determined relief pitcher, said today he planned to play this year withoutsigning a new contract.

The apparent deci sion by the Arab oil producers to maintain their oil embargo against the Netherlands is ex pected to increase the country's pressure on her Common Mar ket partners for help in endingit.

The armed holdup of a Long Island bank last Wednesday went smoothly and there was $11,176 to be shared by three robbers and their mastermind. But a triple-cross over the division of the spoils led to the shooting of the mastermind, Federal authorities said yesterday.

Joseph Monty, former chief investigator for the Queens Dis trict Attorney, was sentenced yesterday to an indeterminate term not to exceed four years for having received free use ofAvis cars as bribes.

An 85-year-old man was killed and 45 families were made homeless early yesterday as a fire believed to have started by careless smoking in bed swept a six-story apart ment building in the East Tre mont section of the Bronx, just across the street from theBronx Zoo.

The city's school administrators have never faltered In their defense of student evaluation as an instrument needed to uphold academic quality. But these same supervisors now see nothing inconsistent in attempts to sabotage evaluation of their own performance under a program introduced last month by Chanceller IrvingAnker.

The Atlantic dialogue that Secretary of State Kissinger began so confidently 11 months ago has deteriorated into charges and counter charges of "hostility" and "lack of consultation" be tween the United States and its traditional Western European allies.

Reports from Turkey last week about fighting between the Iraqi Army and Iraq's Kurd ish minority were "exaggerat ed," but the situation is tense, Beirut's leading newspaper, An Nahar, said today In a dispatchfrom Baghdad.

Business executives and ener gy experts were optimistic yesterday about a speedy re turn to a normal petroleum supply situation following the announcement of the lifting of the Arab oil embargo against the United States. Most in formed analysts, however, were quick to point out that the Arab action in itself was not a panacea for the nation'slong-term energy problems.
The Federal Government moved today to make air bags, or some similar kind of "passive" restraint system, mandatory on all automobiles beginning with1977 models.
Jorge Ahumada, a light heavyweight contender from Argentina, scored a unani mous, one-sided decision over Terry Lee of Concord, Calif., in their 10-round bout at FeltForum last night.
The Federal Government moved today to make air bags, or some similar kind of "passive" restraint system, mandatory on all automobiles beginning with1977 models.

Ste phen Rother, this city's tax col lector, today announced plans to auction a tax lien on four and one-half acres of land at Newark International Airport if the Port Authority, which leases the facility, did not agree to pay $20,000 in back taxes onthe property.
MONTICELLO, N. Y., March 18--Ski lifts at almost all of Vermont's major areas were humming in midwinter form today in a sudden reversal of snow conditions that had the...

The owners of small Appala chian Mountain coal mines that are facing mandatory closing for long-standing Federal safe ty violations asked the Interior Department today to postpone the closings and ease the safety regulation that requires thesweeping shutdown.

Troops moved into a state capital 500 miles southeast of here today to control ram paging students. Official sources said the police opened fire on crowds seven times, killing fivepeople and wounding 60.

NOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN by Consolidated Edison Company of New York, that on March 11, 1974 it issued and filed with the Public Service Commission amendments to its gas rate schedule, PSC No. 8 -Gas applicable to its customers within the City of New York and the County of Westchester to be come effective on and as of April11, 1974.

When Maria Alba first stepped onto the. Kaufmann Concert Hall stage on Satur day night, she received a show-stopping ovation, and enthusiasm both off and on the stage persisted through out the program of Spanishdance.

Pan American world Air-, ways, the nation's largest international airline, asked the Government yesterday for permission to negotiate consolidation of trans-Atlantic service with Trans World Airlines. Pan Am said that "skyrocketing" fuel prices had plunged it into a "serious financial crisis."

Bobby Riggs has agreed to play in a series of five $10,000 tournaments for seniors, officials said today. Invitations have been extended also to Pancho Gonzales, Vic Seixas, Pancho Segura and Jaroslav Drobny.

World grain production, up 7.5 per cent mainly as a result of record harvests in the United States and the Soviet Union last year, is expected to gain another 3.2 per cent by mid-1975, the Agriculture Department said today.

A $9.5-million suit was filed in Federal Court in Brooklyn yesterday on behalf of a 22year-old Floral Park, Queens, girl who died with 345 other persons in the crash of a Turkish DC-10 jumbo jet near Paris on March 3.

President Nixon said tonight that he was confident that enough progress would be made in American efforts toward a Middle East settlement to insure that the Arab states did not reimpose their oil embargo against the United States.

As most Arab nations ended the oil embargo, the stock market looked in vain yesterday for some bullish news. It found none, and the Dow. Jones industrial average closed at 867.57, off 6.65 for the day.

President Nixon announced tonight that he was easing a number of restrictions on energy consumption-including lifting the ban on Sunday gasoline salesas a result of the ending of the Arab oil embargo.

Charles Hoerter, sports editor of The Daily News in New York from 1957 until his retirement in 1967, died last night, apparently of a heart attack, at Palm Beach Gardens Hospital.

State Commissioner of Transportation, supported by elected officials, business interests, commuters and environmentalists, sharply attacked today a Federal Government proposal to eliminate 300 miles of railroad lines in New Jersey.

Bob Lutz upset eighthseeded Tom Gorman, 2-6, 6-2, 6-1, in the first round of the $150,000 American Airlines tennis tournament today. The first upset occurred yesterday when Australia's Allen Stone beat Manuel Orantes of Spain, 2-6, 7-6, 6-3.

-Iraq and Iran have agreed to stop the border conflict that has erupted between them intermittently since late January, the Middle East News Agency said today.

The Government of the Republic of Ireland has now made an outstandingly important contribution to building sectarian cooperation, stability and peace in Northern Ireland. It takes the form of public acknowledgment by Prime Minister Liam Cosgrave of Dublin's recognition that Northern Ireland is "within the United Kingdom" and that the status of the province "cannot be changed except by a decision of a majority of the people of Northern Ireland."
William E. Simon, the Federal energy administrator, contended today that the end of the Arab oil embargo would cause further price increases on gasoline and heating oil in the United States.

ON THE GOLAN HEIGHTS, Israeli' Occupied Syria, March 19 - One Israeli soldier was killed and two others, and two United Nations truce observers were wounded today in some of the heaviest exchanges of artillery fire between Israeli and Syrian forces since the October war.

Dr. Joseph Beasley, chairman of the board of Family Health Foundation, a statewide family planning agency, was indicted today by a Federal grand jury for conspiring to defraud the United States Government.

Now that Eubie Blake, at the age of 91, has brought his twilight career as a pianist to a steady peak of activity and acclaim and has contributed to the ragtime revival, he has turned to torch-passing.

Roy Ash, director of the Ofice of Management and Budget, said here yesterday that the nation's gross national product would be the "worst" of the year in the first quarter of 1974. He said energy-related problems were responsible.

Senator Hubert H. Humphrey acknowledged today the possibility that Howard Hughes might have contributed $50,000 to his Presidential campaign against Richard M. Nixon in 1968.

Organization candidates and incumbents were leading tonight in virtually all races in an Illinois primary Where voter interest was heightened by a limited referendum on a new regional mass transit authority.

Representative , chairman of a House Commerce subcommittee, said yesterday that financial institutions should be given wider latitude to invest In brokerage houses in order to help ease brokers' needs for capital.

President Nixon's special Watergate counsel, James D. St. Clair, has been meeting privately on Capitol Hill with key Republicans in an apparent effort to win support for President Nixon's refusal to give Watergate evidence to the House Judiciary Committee.

The International Systems Controls Corporation announced yesterday that its Lang Companies subsidiaries were awarded contracts of $60-million from the Government of Dahomey for a sugar production complex and a $10.5-million contract from a private company in Venezuela for a sugar syrup mill.

The political corruption case of Dale Anderson, the Democrat who succeeded former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew as elected executive of Baltimore County in 1966, was handed to a United States District Court jury this evening.

Methadone poisoning surpassed heroin as a definite cause of narcotics deaths here in the first half of 1973, while the total of narcotics deaths fell substantially, Dr. Dominick J. Di Maio, the city's Acting Chief Medical Examiner, disclosed yesterday.

President Nixon said tonight that he believed that despite recent sharp exchanges, the United States and the West European allies "are going to work out the differences that we have in the economic and political field."

Members of the Brotherhood Synagogue carried their eight Torah scrolls out of the Village Presbyterian Church in a solemn procession yesterday, ending one of the city's oldest experiments in religious brotherhood.

The Houston police used guard dogs tonight to keep yelling demonstrators from carrying their demand for President Nixon's resignation or impeachment to Jones Hall, where he was speaking to the convention of the National Association of Broadcasters.
Representative Jonathan B. Bingham, Democrat of the Bronx, called on Congress today to extend wage and price control legislation beyond the April 30 cutoff date.
Governor Wilson disagreed tersely with Senator James L. Buckley today and said that he did not think President Nixon should resign.

Ron Lyle, a heavyweight battled his way to a unanimous decision over Oscar Bonavena a Argentina tonight in a 12-round bout in which neither man was able to knowk down the other. The victory lifted the record of Lyle, ranked fifth by the World Boxing Association to 27-1-1 and sparked his hopes for an enventual shot at the heavyweight crown. The slugging Bonavena is now 59-9-1.

President Nixon declared tonight that he would continue to resist demands for his resignation because it "might be good politics but it would be bad statesmanship" to yield to his critics or to low standings in public opinion polls.

A University of Texas law professor, Ernest E. Smith, was named dean of the Texas Law School. today succeeding Dean Page Keeton, who is retiring. Mr. Smith, 37, is a graduate of the Harvard Law School, where he was editor of The Harvard Law Review.
-Atter nearing claims that the Equal Rights Amendment could send pregnant women to the battlefront, the Tennessee Senate has voted to rescind its ratification of the proposal.

Commanders in each of New York City's 73 precincts have been required to submit estimates about the level of corruption among their men, and these estimates are being compared with the public complaints of corruption registered in each precinct.
A Federal grand jury to day indicted seven persons in connection with the March 6 kidnapping of John Calzadillo, 8 years old, of Dix Hills, L.I.
Libya, by declining to go along with other Arab petrole- t um producers in lifting the embargo against the United States, is continuing her maverick role I in international oil and politics.
Manhattan District Attorney Richard H. Kuh plans to establish a Bureau of Consumer Protection - the first new bureau in the Manhattan prosecutor's office in 36 years.

New Jersey's trackless Sports and Exposition Authority is expected to get dates for a race meeting this year and set up the first winter racing in the state, a source close to the Racing Commission indicated today.
A Parliamentary committee has recommended that Kuwait take over ownership of Western oil installations on its territory by 1979, sources close to the committee said today.
A Federal grand jury today indicted seven persons in connection with the March 6 kidnapping of John Calzadillo, 8 years old, of Dix Hills, L.I.
Rancor has erupted among leaders of the Palestinian guerrilla movement over whether to take part in Arab-Israeli peace talks in Geneva, even. though they have not yet been invited.
A small explosion and fire in a mail truck damaged some mail and injured a postal employee late last night on West 57th Street between Ninth and Tenth Avenues.

Louis I. Kahn, whose strong forms of brick and concrete influenced a generation of architects and made him, in the opinion of most architectural scholars, America's foremost living architect, died Sunday evening, apparently of a heart attack, in Pennsylvania Station. He was 73 years old.

Pan American World Airways, the nation's largest internationall airline, asked the Government yesterday for permission to negotiate consolidation of trans-Atlantic service with Trans World Airlines. Pan Am said that "skyrocketing" fuel prices had plunged it into a "serious financial crisis."

Small businessmen in many fields are suffering from supply shortages and soaring prices, but few have been hit as hard as Chinese laundrymen by the shortage of paper and its rising price.

Space scientists have discovered a major feature of the atmosphere of Venus that one expert has nicknamed "the great Venusian eye." It is thought to result from interaction between Venus's atmosphere and direct radiation from the sun, but just how it is formed is still unclear.

A private collection of impressionist and modern paintings, labeled by art connoisseurs as the best of its kind in Latin America, has been taken out of Argentina and will be auctioned in London on April 2, according to Government officials here.

The Supreme Court ruled today that the mining division of the General Dynamics Corporation had not illegally stifled competition in the coal industry when it acquired control of a stripmining company operating in Illinois and Kentucky.

Mayor Beame's blunt rejection of a plan to regionalize water services for the city and eight neighboring counties marks a disappointing retreat from the Mayor's earlier warm support for closer regional cooperation. Even before he took office, Mr. Beame stressed the interdependence of city and suburbs in a meeting with nearby county leaders.
The convention of the National Association of Broadcasters, President Nixon suggested at one point in his question-and-answer session tonight, was not the best place for him to discuss the press.

The month-long trial of Representative Frank J. Brasco of Brooklyn ended in a mistrial yesterday when the jury failed to reach a verdict on a charge of conspiracy to obtain payoffs to help a truck company headed by a reputed Mafia member.

Dr. Istvan Barankovics, who was head of the last effective opposition party to the Communist regime in Hungary when he fled to Vienna in February, 1949, died March 13 in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 67 years old and had lived here since 1951.
Three real estate dealers were indicted here today on charges of bribery and forgery in an alleged $1-million scheme involving the sale of land that belonged to the Town of Brook-haven.

Layoffs of as many as 3,871 Model Cities workers in Harlem, the South Bronx and the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, threatened to begin April 1 because of a gap in Federal financing, have been averted, city officials said yesterday.

The new Labor party Government, in its first major statement on foreign policy, today adopted a conciliatory approach to relations with the United States and said that Europe should engage in the "fullest and most intimate" cooperation with Washington.
After strumming. their balalaikas in the locker room, the wrestlers from the Soviet Union last night went out and proved they can use their feet as well as their hands.

President Nixon's personal secretary kept a detailed list of major contributors to his 1972 re-election campaign with the names and amounts carefully arranged under the donors' corporate affiliations, examination of her notes has disclosed.

A leading art dealer who had testified that Mark Rothko's executors sold his paintings for less than their worth to the Marlborough Gallery was se verely challenged yesterday in Surrogate's Court by lawyers for Marlborough and the executors.

George Marshall Durant, retired partner in the Ridgefield real-estate and insurance firm of Keeler Durant, died Sunday in the United Methodist Convalescent Home here. He was 79 years old and lived at 354 South Avenue, New Canaan.

The state Attorney General's office said that its campaign to uncover antitrust violations involving local contracts was not aimed primarily at prosecuting corruption among local officials. Senator James L. Buckley of New York, who has stanchly supported President Nixon, today became the first conservative Republican in Congress to call upon the President to resign.

Howard J. Samuels, a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor, proposed yesterday a state income-tax credit of up to $50 a person for direct personal gifts to parochial or private schools and other nonprofit voluntary institutions.
What's an ex-computer consultant from Nashville, Tenn., doing in a renovated hardware store on Broadway and 123d Street? He's baking bread-soya, oatmeal-raisin and dill-onion rye.
Thomas W. Binford, Princeton, Class of '48,was named yesterday by the United States Auto Club as chief steward of the May 26 Indianapolis 500 'classic.

Verdi's "Macbeth" is a problematical opera and far from easy to stage. The New York Lyric Opera showed a good deal of pluck in tackling it, and the performance Tuesday night at the Universalist Church, Central Park West and 76th Street, was a surprisingly sound one in many respects.
Arab oil-production cutbacks imposed last October have not yet been fully relaxed, despite the ending of the embargo on shipments to the United States.

With both teams scoring in flurries last night at Madison Square Garden, the Vancouver Canucks won a defenseless battle from the New York Rangers, 7-5, and proved that a team fighting for seventh place may have more desire than a team fighting for second.

With gasoline in apparent abundance throughout the metropolitan region yesterday, Governor Byrne said he was "considering" lifting the oddeven distribution arrangement in New Jersey for a test period, possibly the month of April.

Adm. Elmo R. Zumwalt Jr., the Chief of Naval Operations, said today that the United States must have a naval support base in the Indian Ocean on the British-held island of Diego Garcia so as to be able to project military power into the region.

Israel's Minister of Interior said today that he had directed his officials to refuse to register as Jews immigrants who were converted abroad unless their conversions had been in accordance with the orthodox interpretation of Jewish law.

For the fourth week in a row the continuing decline in meat prices reduced the cost of feeding a family of four in New York City, producing a 1.1 per cent drop in the price of the 38-item market basket of the City Department of Consumer Affairs.

Federal Judge John J. Sirica refused today to grant more than 24 more hours' delay in sending a secret grand jury report to impeachment investigators at the House of Representatives, and the matter was taken immediately to the United States Court of Appeals.
The state police announced today the arrest of a Trenton man who allegedly worked overtime at his state printing job to use state presses to print illegal lottery tickets.
John Kean Roosevelt, a stockbroker and retired executive of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and a cousin of President Theodore Roosevelt, died in Roosevelt Hospital on Tuesday.

Arthur Ashe and New Zealand's Brian Fairlie shook off long plane journeys to win first-round matches in the $150,000 American Airlines tennis tournament at the Tucson Racquet Club today. Rond .Lanver also triumphed.

One-family and two-family houses here are using just about as much electricity as a year ago, and an over-all 6.5 per cent decrease in electric use has come primarily from efforts of large building owners, the Consolidated Edison Company said yesterday.

The preliminary agreement between the United States and West Germany on renewed payments by Bonn to offset the costs of basing American forces in- Germany could not have come at a better time. It represents sensible, workable compromise on a delicate issue after arduous negotiation; an example of exactly the kind of cooperation that has long been lacking in the NATO Alliance but that is imperative for its effectiveness and long-run survival.
The Delaware legislature handily passed today a bill to restore capital punishment for first-degree murder. The House sent the bill to Gov. Sherman W. Tribbitt, who has indicated he will sign it.

With a passenger-load factor of 60.9 per cent in the first two months this year, against 47.7 per cent in the corresponding months last year, American Airlines, succeeded in reducing its deficit in February to $7.5million and for the first two months this year to $11.6-million.

Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger announced yesterday that President Nixon had taken the rare action of moving to give a general's star posthumously to an Air Force officer who was said by the North Vietnamese to

Irving Anker, Chancellor of the city school system, has ordered District 26 in Queens to eliminate 38 teaching positions and seven supervisors in an effort to reduce a $700,000 deficit in the district's budget.

Ken Rosewall, the 39-yearold Australian, provided the chief interest today in a $150,000 tennis tournament here before he was upset by Cliff Drysdale of South Africa, 6-4, 6-4, in the third round tonight. Rosewall, competing in his first international tournament in four months, rallied to eliminate Ross Case, his 22-year old countryman, 4-6, 7-6, 6-2, with a string of 15 straight points during the day.
Richard C. Leone, the State Treasurer, said today that New Jersey intended to make the rate o return the prime/ criterion for allocating deposits of tax money and other revenues to banks.
Mrs. Sarah Roberts Ahrendt, widow of Douglas E. Ahrendt, was married here this afternoon to William L. Boyle Jr. of New York, a vice president of the Council for Financial
The Supreme Court has been told that any relaxation of its 1966 Miranda ruling would seriously threaten a criminal suspect's right against self-incrimination.

Pope Paul VI has called for increased devotion by Roman Catholics to the Virgin Mary, declaring that such action is fully in keeping with the modern women's rights movement and the search for Christian unity.
Consumer price inflation worsened again in February, but there was further evidence that the slowdown in production and employment may be mild, Government reports disclosed today.
President Hafez al Assad of Syria is reported planning to go to Moscow Sunday for talks with Soviet leaders before Secretary of State Kissinger arrives there later in the week.

Common Cause, a citizens group advocating public financing of elections, accused the Democrats today of stalling electoral reform. "There's another political scandal in town, but this one belongs to the Democrats," Common Cause said in a fullpage advertisement in The Washington Post.

The lights in Piccadilly Circus, extinguished' five months ago with the onset of the national energy crisis, will be turned on again Sunday with the rest of the lights in Britain, under a Government directive issued today.

Republican sources said today that speculation over the possibility that Associate Justice Domenick L. Gabrielli of the Court of Appeals might run as the Republican candidate for Lieutenant Governor had reached the point where "he could have it, if he's willing to leave the bench."
New initiatives from Britain and West Germany this week provide hope of combating the trend toward disintegration within West Europe's Common Market and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

Citing "lack of data" as an excuse for staying out of black media is an advertiser "cop out," a leading black marketing executive said yesterday.

For the first time ever, Western Canada will be the setting for national championships of the American Contract Bridge League during the next 10 days.
Joseph L. Tynan, emeritus professor of English literature at City College, died Wednesday at the Woodland Nursing Home in New Rochelle, N.Y. His age was 91.

Severe reservations about the effectiveness of tne sixyear-old "Ghetto Medicine" program were voiced by top city officials yesterday as the Board of Estimate reluctantly approved contracts covering $6.8-million in services provided to the poor by 30 voluntary hospitals. Council President Paul O'Dwyer and Controller Harrison J. Goldin voted in favor of the contracts but made clear their feeling that the program had departed from its intended purpose of

A renewed outbreak of Lassa fever has occurred in Nigeria, claiming two lives and generating intensive efforts to cope with the deadly and baffling viral infection. In addition to the two deaths, a German missionary physician has become seriously ill with what is suspected to be Lassa fever. He was flown yesterday from Nigeria to Hamburg on a chartered Lufthansa jet transport.
Richard A. Neiss, a Yonkers businessman, and his young bride were found dead last night in their $150,000 Chappaqua home, an apparent murder and suicide, according to police and medical officials.
Candy Darling, the transvestite performer who appeared in films and on the stage, died yesterday of cancer and pneumonia at the Columbus Hospital Division of the Cabrini Health Care Center.

State arts leaders vigorously protested yesterday a proposal by the fiscal committee of the Legislature that would cut Governor Wilson's recommended budget of $30.5-million for the Council on the Arts by more than one-third.

Chief Justice Warren E. Burger has maintained a judicious silence in the face of press commentary on the Supreme Court and its leadership, but elements of the American Bar Association have taken up the cudgels for him.

Two Brooklyn lawyers were arrested yesterday and charged with attempting to pay a $25,000 bribe to a State Supreme Court justice to get him to fix the case of a man indicted for attempted murder. Theodore Rosenberg and Leonard Fusfield, right, in custoday after booking at First Precinct station house. The lawyers were indicted for allegedly arranging a bribe.
Leon Jaworski, the special Watergate prosecutor, disclosed today that he had subpoenaed additional documents from the White House files.

The Society for Animal Rights yesterday offered a $650 reward for information leading to the arrest of those who attacked five fallow deer in the Central Park Zoo two weeks ago. One of the deer died later.

Compagnie Generale d'Electricite announced in Paris yesterday that it had received a $44-million contract from the public utility district of Chelan County, Wash., for the supply of eight generator of 54 megawatts each for its Rock Island, Columbia River, hydroelectric power plant.

Governor Wilson moved quickly today to still the controversy over the State Racing and Wagering Board by appointing Bertram D. Sarafan, a veteran government official, as the new chairman and by cutting the job's salary by almost 30 per cent, to $55,000 a year.
The board of the American Maize-Products Company yesterday decided its plan to acquire Helme Products, Inc. "cannot be carried out."
Spring and the New York Rangers came to the Omni tonight, but the Atlanta Flames stifled the Blue Shirts' renaissance by tying them, 5-5, on a goal 25 seconds from the end of the game.

Ideas change society; architecture changes the visible, functioning environment. Occasionally, one man's creativity spans both; and the way men build to express their emotional and physical needs is never quite the same again. Louis Kahn was such a man.

If wooden birds could fly, those carved by Gilbert Maggioni and Grainger McKoy would be among the first to take wing. A wood duck on driftwood in the "Birds in the Wood" show at the American Museum of Natural History.
It has been 45 days since Patricia Hearst was abducted from her Berkeley apartment, but there is still no indication when she might be released.

Senator J. Strom Thurmond, Republican of South Carolina, announced today that he planned to seek re-election in 1978. "I think what counts is how a man feels, his mental and physical," said the 71-yearold Senator.

Champagne glass in hand, Beverly Sills was beaming as she spun gracefully through the crowd on stage in the first act of "La Traviata." She was doing what theater people call bits of businessflirting here, laughing there, Julius Rudel, conductor, giving Beverly Sills a congratulatory hug after her last-minute performance in New York City Opera's production of "La Traviata."
The arrest of 31 persons broke up a city-based drug ring that took in $800,000 through illegal narcotics sales and falsified prescriptions over the last nine months, the police reported.

Bank loans to corporations continued to expand strongly during the week ended Wednesday, growing more than usual even for a tax-payment date, Federal Reserve Bank of New York figures showed yesterday.
A 21-year-old woman, on her way home after working late, was shot and killed Wednesday evening by an unknown assailant along a quiet residential street in Far Rockaway, Queens.
Federal tax indictments were announced yesterday against six alleged procurers who were charged with failure to pay income taxes on the proceeds of prostitution.

The appointment of Ellmore C. Patterson as the 1974 general chairman of the United Fund of Greater New York, was announced yesterday by R. Manning Brown Jr., the present chairman. Ellmore C. Patterson
WASHINGTON-As a lawyer, I have been at once saddened and dismayed to read and hear the criticisms that are being heaped upon James D. St. Clair for his defense of President Nixon.

Michael A. Kinney, who returned home this week after 18 months in the Army in Korea, ended up in jail mistakenly charged with desertion. Officers said the mix-up resuited from an Army notice that listed Mr. Kinney, 21 years old as a deserter.

Texaco, Inc., the nation's third-largest oil company and the largest seller of gasoline in the United States, announced yesterday a. wholesale price reduction of 1 cent a gallon on all its grades of gasoline and residual fuel oil.

The Kentucky Colonels scored a 121-103 victory over the Memphis Tams tonight in a wild American Basketball Association game that saw Coach Bill van Breda Kolff of Memphis get ejected and an irate fan run onto the floor and slug Referee George Conley.

During the activist nineteen-sixties the universities were under pressure to come to the rescue of the nation's strife-torn and decaying urban centers. Many higher education spokesmen, in fear of militant attacks, agreed too readily to action programs which, though temporarily popular, held out little hope for practical success. Sociology departments, transformed into social policy task forces, could not make up in enthusiasm for their lack of practical knowledge and experience.

As a "telephone trader," Gabe Paul of the New York Yankees may not be in a class with George Allen of the Washington Redskins - who reportedly had an unlimited expense account and used it up the first month on the job -but, in his search for infield help, Paul may be catching up.

Bobby Orr celebrated his 26th birthday two days late tonight with three goals. He led Boston to a 7-0. rout of. the St. Louis Blues, moving the Bruins within 1 point of clinching the National Hockey League's East Division title.

Rumors of a possible revaluation of the West German mark and fears of a United States foreign-payments deficit because of a higher oil-import bill caused a major shakeup today on European money markets.

The City Council, heeding Mayor Beame's suggestion voted unanimously yesterday to extend for five years the rent stabilization program, which limits rent increases on lease renewals in about 275,000' apartments here.

Richard Okamoto, a freelance writer and editor who had served in World War II with the Office of War Information and, later, in Army Intelligence in Austria, died of cancer yesterday at his home, 150 West 82d Street. He was 53 years old.

Lawrence F. Kramer, the former state commissioner of Community Affairs, and Mayor of Paterson, and Betty Kordja, the chairman of the Passaic County Democratic organization, testified here today before a state grand jury investigating alleged corruption involving highway construction in New Jersey. Lawrence F. Kramer after testifying before grand jury yesterday.
Thomas Patrick O'Hara, who for many years had been one of this city's leading political reporters, died last night of cancer at his home, 144 Guyon Avenue, Oakwood, S. I. He was 60 years old.

Bill Bradley-Rhodes Scholar, newlywed, Princeton man, possible politician and last night's postgame guest on Hot Rod Hundley's radio show-summed up the Willis Reed situation about as well as anyone: Willis Reed before return to action for the Knicks in first half of game with Phoenix in Arizona. At left is Jerry Lucas, one of Reed's replacements during injury.

School Chancellor Irving Anker said yesterday that a Federal audit accusing the city system of misusing $28-million in Federal aid "coincides with and appears calculated to reinforce" an effort now under way in Congress to reduce Federal aid to disadvantaged pupils living in urban areas.

A group of American and Canadian corporations formally applied today in Ottawa and Washington for permission to build a 2,625-mile pipeline that would tap the natural-gas reserves of the Arctic. Their action raised the curtain on what is expected to be a prolonged controversy. The pipelines planned by the Canadian Arctic Pipeline. Consortium has asked permission to build.
The United States and Australia formally signed a new agreement today giving Australia more control over operation of the North West Cape communications base in Western Australia.

Another heavy snowstorm -the second of the weekyesterday provided upper New York and New England resorts with their best skiing conditions in two seasons. As much as one foot of snow dropped on many of the areas.
Most commodity prices drifted lower yesterday in lackluster trading, following the lead of the depressed metals markets.

It was a dull day on the Big Board yesterday in what appeared to be a trader's market rather than an investor's market. The Dow-Jones industrial average closed with a gain of 3.13 points at 875.47, less than a third of the gain of 10.09 at its high point of the day-882.43 at 11 A.M.

bodies of six servicemen who died in captivity in North Vietnam arrived here today, military officials said.. They were the first dead prisoners of war returned to the United States since the Vietnam cease-fire, Col. Thomas Byrne of the Army said.

" How much is it worth?" will probably be the question most often posed first, and "What is it?" the second, during Sotheby Parke Bernet's appraising bee that opens Wednesday for a fourday run at the galleries, 980 Madison Avenue (at 76th Street).
Foreign Minister Michel Jobert has warned the Arab oil countries that they must treat all European consumers equally if they want special links with Europe.

The Rev. Jesse L. Jackson, president of Operation PUSH (People United to Save Humanity), said yesterday that he was calling on other black leaders to join him in a class action suit to subpoena Federal Bureau of Investigation files relating to an F.B.I. counter-intelligence program directed at black organizations.
A pair of 30-minute television documentaries examining unfamiliar aspects of life on two islands, the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico and remote Bali, make rewarding weekend viewing.

" In Europe the fencing is a tradition," said Christian Noel, the 1973 world foil champion. But in the beginning, there were human judges instead of electrical ones so today's tradition, it appears, could not go back further than Ben Franklin.

The grit and determination of the Boston College Eagles, who have wrung out a pair of 1-point victories to reach the semifinal round of the National Invitation Tournament, will be tested to the full today against the powerful and speedy Utah Utes

International The Vietcong proposed a six-point plan that included detailed provisions for a new cease-fire and the holding of general elections in South Vietnam. American officials who read the plan said it was the most concrete put forward by the Vietcong since the Paris cease-fire agreement last year.

For more than 20 years, the Apgar score has been used to measure the health of babies in the moments after birth. The score, a rating based on five body functions, is used throughout the world to determine whether a baby needs help to sustain life.
A youth was accidentally shot and wounded in an Upper West Side junior high school yesterday and two other youths were wounded in separate shootings near Queens schools.
The United States Coast Guard graduated its. first-and last-company of women recruits today at its training center here. From now on, recruit companies will be co-ed, the Coast Guard said.

America art in the nineteen-thirties was, like so many other areas of American life in that decade of economic depression and political crisis, a battleground of conflicting ideologies. Exponents of European modernism vied for attention with painters of the American scene. Francis Criss's "Columbus Circle," at Washburn Gallery

Governor Wilson appears to have picked a winner in his selection of State Liquor Authority Chairman Bertram D. Sarafan to succeed Emil (Bus) Mosbacher as head of the State Racing and Wagering Board. Mr. Sarafan's solid track record during a lifetime of public service, especially his reputation as a tough fighter against corruption, make him an excellent bet to carry through the task that was initiated by Mr. Mosbacher at Governor Rockefeller's request last summer.

A White House official said today that The Washington Post, Time magazine, a New York Times book and the television networks had committed specific acts of the type President Nixon has called distorted coverage.

The trustees of the Penn Central Railroad filed five affidavits yesterday with Judge John P. Fullam of the Federal District Court in Philadelphia to support their position that the 20,000-mile system could not be reorganized on a money making basis "within a reasonable time" under Section 77 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

Stock prices fell yesterday on the American 'Stock Exchange but rose slightly in the overthe-counter market. The Amex market value index was down 0.60 to 99.04. Declines outnumbered advances by 396 to 268 while 330 issues were unchanged.

Soybean futures prices on the Chicago Board of Trade showed a sharp decline yesterday. The active May delivery opened at $6.44 1/2, 4 cents above the preceding day's close, moved as high as 6.47 1/2 and then closed around $6.35, down more than 5 cents on the day.

The International Minerals and Chemical Corporation announced yesterday the termination of its. offer to purchase the outstanding common shares of Commercial Solvents Corporation.

Structures of the coal-mining industry loom behind homes. The mines are being phased out. Emile Roger, Mayor of Lallaing, says the Government is "ahead in closing the mines and behind in getting new industries to absorb the miners."

Princess Anne said today that her encounter Friday with a man seeking to kidnap her happened so quickly that. she did not have time to be frightened, so "I just got angry" with the attacker, she said..
The National Highway Safety Administration said yesterday lap and shoulder belts on some 1968-through-1972 Volkswagens may be ineffective in a crash because of exposure to battery acid.

President Nixon flew to his Camp David mountaintop retreat in Camp David, Md., today, and the White House announced that he will make a live radio broadcast to the nation tomorrow on education legislation.

After a two-year hiatus, Consolidated Edison resumed the burning of coal at its Arthur Kill station on Staten Island yesterday under a temporary authorization from the city and state environmental protection agencies, consuming the first of an expected average daily usage of 3,100 tons.

In a statement read to the jury in Robert D. Petrarca's murder trial today, the suspect's version of where he was the day two Montclair women were strangled was in conflict with the version given by two defense witnesses.

Dr. Helen Wise, the president of the National Education Association, announced yesterday the beginning of a campaign by teachers "to elect a Congress that cares about the education of our children."
Johnny Miller, the computer rigged to look, walk and play like a golf pro with wind-tousled blond hair, shot his second consecutive 67 today to dominate at the halfway point of the Heritage Classic.
Irving Anker, the city's School Chancellor, appointed two trustees yesterday to supercede the authority of a community school board in Queens on financial matters.

The Landmarks Preservation Commission said yesterday that it planned to set up a meeting between preservationists and officials of Grace Church in an attempt to resolve the controversy concerning the church's plans to demolish a row of houses on Fourth Avenue that constitute part of its gothicrevival grouping.

About 200 students from throughout the East are meeting at Lawrence High School in Cedarhurst, L. I., this weekend for the school's annual Government-in-Action Conference.

For the first time in many months the Nixon Administration has gained confidence that it can obtain adequate support from its European allies to share the costs of maintaining 315,000 American troops in Western Europe, officials said today.

A suggestion was made in the press recently that if the Soviet Union had challenged the American "military machine" during the recent Middle East crisis, in "anything short of a nuclear exchange, the American forces would have been severely, if not fatally, mauled."

Three convicted bank robbers who attempted to escape from Federal Detention Headquarters in lower Manhattan surrendered shortly before 9 A.M. yesterday and released four hostages unharmed after they had been promised they would not be prosecuted for the escape attempt.

Undefeated St. Anthony's of Jersey City, needing a victory to achieve the best record in New Jersey high school basketball this season, will be in the spotlight tomorrow in the parochial finals of the state tournament. The Friars, who have won 29 games will also bolster a claim to be the top ranking team in the state.

The recent discovery of a rare liver cancer among workers exposed to vinyl chloride has enhanced the concern of some scientists about the myriad substances in the general environment that are known or suspected of causing cancer.

The Civil Aeronautics Board, blaming a "precipitous" rise in the price of jet fuel, authorized the nation's domestic airlines yesterday to raise fares 4 per cent on April 16. The regulatory agency also indicated obliquely that it would sanction an additional 2 per cent increase on the same date if the airlines asked for it.
Foreign Minister Michel Jobert has warned the Arab oil countries that they must treat all Eurrpean consumers equally if they want special links with Europe.

Nelsor G. Gross, the former state Re publican chairman, angrily charged the United States At torney's office today with try ing to "devastate" his law prac twice by calling his firm's cli ents "all over the state."

The Cost of Living Council said today it had permitted the American Motors Corporation to raise its base vehicle prices by an average of $50 above the levels to which American Motors agreed last December.

Ed Davis, a 22-year-old slugger from Freeport, L. I., successfully defended his 175-pound open title last night, but disappointed at least one section of the 20,28 fans who showed up at Madison Square Garden for the 48th annual Golden Gloves Championships.

PARIS-The North Atlantic Alliance marks its 25th anniversary this spring In a far gloomier atmosphere than had been anticipated. Whatever efforts that were still in the air to produce a gala vanished amid the exchanges of verbal brickbats
Israel has complained to the United Nations Emergency Force that Egypt has moved up new artillery on the eastern bank of the Suez Canal, an Israeli military spokesman said here today.

The state's prison-reform efforts still seem largely confined to the semantics of giving to penal institutions the new label of correctional facilities. Since wishing alone can't convert a jail into a place of rehabilitation, there was a flicker of hope in the proposal by Chancellor Ernest L. Boyer of the State University to create a college for prisoners.

State Supreme Court Justice Irwin R. Brownstein was identified by authoritative law enforcement sources yesterday as the judge to whom two lawyers allegedly tried to pay a $25,000 bribe to fix an attempted-mur der case.

The builder of the DC-10 airliner Involved in history's worst air crash said yesterday that preliminary evidence indicated the plane's rear cargo door did not have all changes approved after the near-crash of another DC-10 in June, 1972.
LONDON-France now has 3.4 million immigrant workers--over 15 per cent of her labor force. They come from Algeria, Portugal, Spain, Italy, Morocco, Tunisia, South Korea, Yugoslavia and black Africa.

The Nixon Administration sent to Congress today a package of proposed amendments to the Clean Air Act of 1970 that would extend several deadlines for abatement of pollutants and in other ways weaken the act under the mounting pressures of energy demands.

Dave Cowens came back after two days off to score 17 points and collect 11 rebounds in the first half, lifting the Boston Celtics to a 126-118 National Basketball Association victory over the Pbrtland Trail Blazers tonight.
Mayor Angelo J. Errichetti requested a grand-jury investigation today into charges of brutality against blacks by white policemen.
William E. Simon, the administrator of the Federal Energy Office, called today or Congress to lift its "legislative embargo" on the Administration's energy proposals.
The New York Post, which publishes six afternoons a week, announced yesterday that the newsstand price of its daily and weekend editions would be increased from 15 to 20 cents, starting Monday.

The Justice Department obtained a consent degree today requiring the city of Jackson, Miss., to hire and promote more blacks and women in virtually all municipal jobs and pay, $200,000 to victims of alleged discriminatory practices.

A bill to restore capital punishment in Pennsylvania was vetoed tonight by Gov. Milton Shapp. The veto came 15 minutes before a midnight deadline for action by the Governor, without which the bill would have become law automatically.
William E. Reid, president of the National Cotton Council, told textile manufacturers today that their supply of cotton would be greater this year than at any time since 1965.

The New York Mets took some pretty good rips at Bob Gibson today as they mauled the St. Louis Cardinals, 10-0, and raised a few eyebrows over one of the most intriguing "comebacks" in baseball.

A West German steel consortium has concluded a $1-billion agreement with the Soviet Union for an iron and steel plant. The agreement is the largest EastWest industrial project since World War II, Economics Minister Hans Friderichs said.

Molloy, the New York Catholic high schools champion, and St. Anthony's of Smithtown, the Long Island Catholic champion, advanced to the semifinals of the Top Eight basketball tournament last night at Hofstra University.
Peter Revson, America's top road-racing driver, was killed today when his car crashed and burst into flames during a practice run for the South Africa Grand Prix on March 30.

Capt. Edward H. Molyneux, the British fashion designer, died at his home in Monte Carlo today at the age of 79. The world-famous couturier was stricken by a heart attack last Christmas, followed by double pneumonia.

The Federal Government has i designated two large areas in the Atlantic Ocean off Long Island and New Jersey within which it will locate one or two i sites for the dumping of sewage sludge to replace the present dumping area, which is 12 miles east of New Jersey and 10 miles south of Long Island.

Police Officer James Sullivan burst into a classroom at John F. Kennedy High School in the Bronx and rushed over to Bruny Moravcik's seat. "You're under arrest," he shouted to the 16-year-old junior and snapped out his handcuffs. Police Officer James Sullivan, at Kennedy High School, explains "arrest" of Bruny Moravcik, center. Lenny Kessot acts as lawyer.

TOKYO, March 22 -- On Dec. 7, 1941, Lieut. Heijiro Abe and Lieut. Kiyokuma Okajima led their respective bomber and fighter squadrons through the gray dawn to attack the American naval base at Pearl Harbor in Hawaii.

The United States rink from Superior, Wis., skipped by Bud Somerville, recorded its sixth triumph today in the world curling championships and reached the semifinal round. The Americans defeated Scotland, 8-2, and will meet unbeaten Switzerland next.

Mrs. Robert M. Sutton, a 48year-old housewife who does not think of herself as a liberated woman, was elected head of the New Jersey Daughters of the American Revolution in a hotly contested election here today.

The Council of Presidents of the Lutheran Church-Missouri Sxnod has decided to allow dissident students from Concordia Seminary to serve as parish interns but ' has refused to recognize their "seminary in exile."
The Senate unanimously approved today legislation that would revolutionize Congressional procedures for considering the Federal budget and setting national spending priorities.

TUCSON, Ariz., March 22--Arthur Ashe, who had lost fifteen straight matches to Rod Laver since 1959, scored his second victory in two weeks over the former grand-slam winner today and reached the semifinals in a $150,000 tennis tourney.

United States safety experts are convinced that the recent crash near Paris of a Turkish Airlines DC-10with 346 deaths, the worst disaster in the history of civil aviation--was caused by the sucking out of an inadequately secured rear cargo door. If that proves the official finding, this tragedy could and should have been prevented for there had been ample warning of the danger.
About 50 men and women, all of whom were in service during the Vietnam war, graduated yesterday from a special practical-nursing course instituted by the Board of Education.
More than seven months after the event, a retired merchant told the police yesterday that $80,000 in cash that he stored in shoe boxes had been taken from his apartment.

The World Bank announced today that it had arranged to borrow $200-million from Iran. The loan will be for 12 years at 8 per cent interest It is a fulfillment by Iran of part of her pledge of at least $1-billion from her swollen oil revenues mainly to help the less-developed countries.

Twenty-two million chickens contaminated with a recognized cancer-causing pesticide will be placed on the market unless the Environmental Protection Agency bars the sale within the next few days, government and en-t vironmental sources indicated tonight.

Mayor Beame detailed for news executives yesterday a looming budget deficit that he said "you need. a magician" to solve. The Mayor, using charts, gave the details of what he forecast as a 16 per cent increase in the cost of running the city and a 2.6 per cent increase in projected revenues.
Public education for 76,000 students here, already in deep trouble because of a widerange of problems, is entering its third week of a teachers' strike.

Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger abolished a numerical code today that permitted employers to identify military misfits, alcoholics and drug abusers even though they received honorable discharges from the service.

Viktor Nekrasov, the prize-winning Soviet writer who recently declared support ,for Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, the banished author, and Andrei D. Sakharov, the dissident physicist, was expelled today by the police from Moscow to his home City of Kiev.
Miss Ellan Ashton Metz was married here this afternoon to Russell Roy Anspach, a principal in the New York marketing communications and design firm of Anspach Grossman Portugal.
The Vietcong proposed today a six-point plan that included detailed provisions for a new cease-fire and the holding of general elections in South Vietnam.

Sorecho Nalo, described by authorities as the leader of the gang that took $4-million in jewelry and cash in a robbery at the Pierre Hotel bn Jan. 2, 1972, was arrested and accused of another crime-invading a Queens home last January and stealing $7,000 after holding two persons at gunpoint. The Queens robbery allegedly occurred while Mr. Nalo was free on $50,000 bail, pending appeals in the Pierre robbery.

Despite security precautions, Princess Anne was twice surrounded by crowds today in the garden-party atmosphere of a country equestrian competition. VISITS ITALY: Princess Grace of Monaco arriving yesterday in Rome. She and the royal family are on a private stay.

To the Editor: The sight of various Federal and state agencies, most notably the F.T.C. and the attorneys general of the several states, vying to see who can bring the greatest number of obscurant antitrust actions against the major oil companies and the auto manufacturers would be laughable were it not for the serious situation that faces our nation.

AFRICA Talk about parks in Africa, and you immediately think of a place occupied by Ernest Hemingway, white hunters and angry elephants. But there are cities in Africa, and the cities have parks, too-places where the city folk go to take a breather from urban turmoil.

Glenn Tetley, the American choreographer working in Europe in recent years, has been appointed artistic director of the Stuttgart Ballet. He succeeds John Cranko, the South African-born choreographer who died last June.

Big Sky of Montana, Inc., a $25-million ski and golf resort development, was officially opened and dedicated yesterday, three days after Chet Huntley, its chief promoter, died of lung cancer. A memorial service for Mr. Huntley was held today at the resort's ski village.
Either North Carolina State, champion of the Atlantic Coast Conference, or Marquette, an independent team from Milwaukee, will be the new National Collegiate basketball champion tomorrow night.

Four hundred mothers, chanting and carrying picket signs, marched in the 20-degree cold, in front of Public School 179 in Fresh Meadows, Queens, for more than an hour yesterday morning. They were protesting the Board of Education's proposal to eliminate 38 teacher and seven supervisory jobs in District 26 to ease its $700,000 deficit.

Chancellor Willy Brandt's chief Cabinet-level negotiator with the East, Egon Bahr, recently described West Germany's contacts with Communist East Germany in these terms: "For decades we had no relations. Now we have bad relations. That's a kind of progress, too!"

Rallies have been held at graveyards in China as part of what appears to be an organized effort to remind the Chinese people of atrocities committed by foreigners when weak and pliable governments opened the country to them.

Five months before the deadline for filing such information with the New York Secretary of State, Howard J. Samuels released the names yesterday of 951 persons who have contributed and lent a total of $360,000 to his campaign for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination.

The Amoco Production Company, a subsidiary of Standard Oil of Indiana, said yesterday it had asked the Federal Power Commission for a rate increase on natural gas produced at two Kansas fields in order to finance further gas exploration and development.

A dreary ritualism prevails in the biennial negotiations for new wage agreements covering New York City's mass transit lifeline: On the Sunday before the old contracts expire thousands of subway and bus workers gather in Manhattan Center to vote almost unanimous authorization for a strike, after which New Yorkers hold their breath until the Mayor's fact-finders come up with eleventh-hour recommendations that settle everything.

In 1932 when the author Fannie Hurst decided she needed more space, she moved to an apartment she called "baronial", the living room of which, she later wrote, was so large that it "swallowed our simple furniture at a gulp, leaving us with a vacuum of great reaches of bare floors, bare walls, and bare floor to ceiling windows."

A national fund-raising organization has been formed to seek support from business exclusively for the dance field. The National Corporate Fund for Dance, the new group, promises to be unusual on two counts.
In the late nineteen-forties, when Walter J. Stoessel Jr. was a young consular officer here, he interceded on behalf of a Brooklyn-born woman in Lithuania who was trying to go home.

Louise Taylor, a soprano who sang on the opera and concert stage for more than 50 years and had been a member of the Chicago Opera Company and the Cosmopolitan Opera Company of New York, died Sundayat the Sanger Nursing Home, 500 West 57th Street. Her age was 89.
Maryland was named the top lacrosse team in the university field yesterday in the weekly poll. The balloting among nine. coaches voting on major lacrosse powers was unanimous.

The Internal Revenue official who praised President Nixon for the careful preparation of his 1970 and 1971 tax returns and who accepted them, without change, after a very brief audit has been promoted to head the agency's Philadelphia regional office.

The Soviet Union, increasingly' at odds with policies of Egypt's President, Anwar el-Sadat, today published an attack on Cairo's drift away from the Socialist program of the late President Gamal Abdel Nasser.

Jay Jones, after a remarkable performance, was on the verge of tears in the Hillside High locker room after his team lost to Pleasant, ville, 60-55, in the Group 2 public school final of the state basketball tournament Saturday at Brookdale Community College.
A leading German researcher into human and animal behavior proposed yesterday that violence and war were not primarily the result of inborn instinct but rather of culturally based factors.

Three teams of graduate students in broadcast journalism at the American University in Washington have found a charge by President Nixon that television network news was "outrageous, vicious, distorted" to be generally without substantiation. The students' findings were based on a study of X the two-week period before the I President's attack was made last Oct. 26.

North Carolina State won the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball championship for the first time tonight, a year after the only undefeated team in the school's history had been barred from the N.C.A.A. tournament.

The world energy crisis and the three-day work week gave Britain's biggest auto concern, the British Leyland Motor Corporation, a heavy loss for the first half of its fiscal year ending in March, Lord Stokes, chairman, told the annual meeting in London today.

WASHINGTON, March 25-Question: What is the Presidency? Answer: The Presidency is a 181year-old office with some antique furniture and too many telephones. Q. But what about President Nixon's claim that he is not only the President, but also the Presidency?

The stock market finished mixed yesterday as an 'afternoon recovery erased many of the earlier losses in the slowest trading in almost seven months. Before all the commotion began over the nationality of tomorrow night's referee, George Foreman put the situation in perspective. "I got my referee with me," the champion said, clenching his fists and holding them aloft. "I don't need a referee. God gave me my referee 25 years ago."

Enrollment in the nation's elementary schools has dropped 2.4 per cent in the current school year, the Census Bureau said today. It was the third straight year of decline because of the nation's lower birth rate.

A plan to safeguard policyholders of the scandal-ridden Equity Funding Corporation of America was unveiled here today for court approval. The plan, disclosed jointly by the insurance regulators of California and Illinois, here and in Chicago, calls for the Northern Life Insurance Company of Seattle to assume all business in force of the Equity Funding Life Insurance Company as of last Jan. 1.

Workmen erected 165 yards of triple-catch fencing today at the spot where Peter Revson, the American racing driver, died in a high-speed crash Friday at Kyalami Circuit. Gilbert C. Halsted, chairman of the board of the E. S. Halsted Company of Jersey City, textile bag manufacturers, died yesterday at the Nassau Hospital, Mineola, L.I.

Chris Evert is on her own at last, but independence has not changed the final outcome of her tennis matches. The 19-year-old Floridian recovered quickly from a 1-3 deficit in the opening set, won 15 of the next 20 points and ran off a 6-4, 6-2 victory over Sharon Walsh in the opening round of the $60,000 women's national indoor championships last night at Felt Forum.

A lawyer defending Little League baseball as a masculine preserve was told by a judge in Superior Court here today that he was philosophically out of tune with the "whole idea of sex-discrimination statutes."

In the summer of 1923, President Warren G. Harding turned to his Secretary of Commerce, Herbert Hoover, and asked to speak to him in private. The Labor Department has ordered the Women's Job Corps Center here, long the subject of political controversy, to shut down as of April 17. The Center was opened in 1967.

A shopping spree for alcoholic beverages, furs, jewelry and other luxury goods materialized across Britain today on the eve of the new Cabinet's first budget as people of wealth or high incomes tried to hedge against expected tax increases.

The House of Representatives passed and sent to the White House today a bill allowing the Government to pay transportation expenses for families' going to the 'funerals of Vietnam prisoners of war. The Senate passed the bill last Friday.
Esther Michelson Davis, a sculptor and painter, died Sunday at her home, 10 Park Avenue. She was 80 years old, and the widow of Harold M. Davis, who headed a printing and publishing company.

St. Petersburg s City Council took action last week that could establish the city's population of 235,000 as of July, 1973, as a ceiling and require about 25,000 persons who have moved here since then to pack up and move within six months after the ordinance takes effect.

Olive Higgins Prouty, author of "Stella Dallas," died at her home here last night. She was 92 years old. It also was the basis for a long radio serial of the same name.

" Give me a bag full of money," a man told a teller around 11 A.M. yesterday in the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company branch at 969 Eighth Avenue at 59th Street. The man did not have his own bag.
Governor Wilson may forgo his policy of waiting for the Legislature and introduce his own campaign-practice-reform proposals this week, reliable sources disclosed today.

Members of parliaments in the Common Market countries, including former high-ranking French and British Government officials, have formed an associated for "long-term economic, technical and cultural cooperation" between Europe and the Arab world.
Military sources said today that Government soldiers suffered heavy casualties as they continued their attempt to retake the town of Phsar Oudong northwest of here.

It is not exactly your neighborhood library. It has 4,000 employes, costs almost $100-million a year to run, attracts more than a million persons annually, and its 320 miles of shelves contain more than 72 million books, manuscripts, technical reports, photographs, maps and pieces of' music.
Charges by the Pennsylvania Crime Commission of widespread corruption in the Philadelphia police department are unsubstantiated, the city Police Commissioner, Joseph O'Neill, said today.

National Basketball Association club owners will meet in Los Angeles tomorrow to vote on the possibility of adding San Diego as a 19th team for next season. A couple of weeks ago New Orleans was accepted as an 18th team.

A bill restoring the death penalty in Massachusetts was vetoed today by Gov. Francis W. Sargent.
Robert H. Finch, former Presidential adviser and Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, says that today he "couldn't run for dogcatcher without it turning into a referendum on Watergate."
The great World Series catch is only a memory as far as the Atlanta Braves are concerned and yesterday they released Ron Swoboda unconditionally.

M. Herschel Parsons, who retired in 1962 as vice president of the Turner Construction Company, died Sunday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home, 495 Dean Drive, Mattituck, L. I. He was 68 years old.

The Governor of American Samoa, John M. Haydon, was cleared yesterday of six counts of violating the Hatch Act, but the administrative law judge criticized him for "an unwarranted intrusion into the electoral process."

In Saigon and Phnom Penh the rumble of artillery at night is a reminder that people are probably being killed not far away. The magic words become "outgoing" and "incoming," Outgoing is intended to kill Communists or those who support them.

SAN FRANCISCO-Politics in California is almost always an interesting and important business, as befits the most populous state in the Union. California is on the western edge of things and has two of the nation's most fascinating cities, as well as a reputation for being first to exemplify what will later become national trends.
Justice John J. Dillon of the State Supreme Court died Sunday in White Plains Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived at 54 Ralph Avenue, White Plains.

A bitter debate about whether to allow a debate on the impeachment of President Nixon gripped the Senate this afternoon but ended as it began-with the impeachtment petition referred to the Committee on Finance, almost certainly forever.

Operations of the Allied Stores Corporation in the fourth quarter and fiscal year ended Feb. 2 resulted in record sales and earnings despite a write. off of several million dollars in the periods, the company re. ported yesterday.

The superintendent of the troubled Trenton State Prison was removed yesterday and reassigned to an administrative post. The transfer of the superintendent, Albert D. Gray, came as officials of the state penal system were continuing an investigation into several days of tension at the maximumsecurity prison this month.
A 32-year-old inmate at Rikers Island was found hanged by a bedsheet in his cell late last night. Authorities called the death a suicide.
Streakers in sneakers. Mrs. Abraham Beame in Ultrasuede. Saint Laurent's mantailored suits all over theplace. Oh, it was a great day for fashion watchers yesterday.
