JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 25 (AP)-Workmen erected 165 yards of triple-catch fencing today at the spot where Peter Revson, the American racing driver, died in a high-speed crash Friday at Kyalami Circuit. "Workmen started on the job Sunday," said Francis Tucker, chairman of the South African Motor Racing Club. "We didn't even have time for a quote, but at a time like this the expense is not important."
This week in New York Western Union has begun a multi-media advertising effort that has proven successful for it in six test markets.

The Transit Authority yesterday completed presenting its economic arguments against wage and fringe-benefit demands of its unions, which have threatened to strike the subways and buses next Monday morning if they do not have a new contract by then.

Three California scientists have documented apparently for the first time how atmospheric pollution and cigarette smoking can aggravate the severe pains that result from hardening of the leg arteries.

Daniel B. Hicks, special assistant to the vice president for ambulatory care and community health for the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation, died Sunday at the age of 31. His body was found in an automobile on the Henry Hudson Parkway near Mosholu Avenue in the Bronx.

Domestic steel production for the week ended March 23 increased by 1.3 per cent to 2,875,000 tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. This raised the weekly production index to 117.8 against 116.4 a week ago when a total of 2,839,000 tons of steel were poured.

Despite protests from community planners, key state and city officials appeared ready yesterday to press for Federal designation of the entire Hudson. shore corridor from the Battery to the George Washington Bridge as an interstate expressway route.

A relieved, almost solemn Coach Norm Sloan aid tribute to "a beautiful bunch of guys" after his North Carolina State basketball team had beaten Marquette, 76-64, tonight for the National Collegiate championship.

The state Senate voted today to establish two committees to study the impact of a State Supreme Court ruling requiring an overhaul in the financing of public education. The measures, which now go to the Assembly, were attacked by one Senator who said the study commissions were a waste of money.

The builder of the DC-10 jumbo jet involved in history's worst air crash said today that the plane had left the factory apparently lacking a critical cargo-door design change even though company records show the change had been made.

Declined to review a decision declaring unconstitutional a New Jersey antiabortion law on which the decision of unconstitutionality was made in 1972 before the SupremeCourt invalidated many similar statutes (No. 73-838, Kugler v. Young Women's Christian Association).
Nelson G. Gross, the former state Republican chairman, was accused today by the Federal Government of having used his political power to enrich his law practice.

To the Editor: a Your March 14 editorial "Con Ed's Coal" did not show sufficient concern for either the electric customer who is bearing a heavy burden of skyrocketing oil costs or for the facts regarding the impact of limited coal-burning on New York City's air quality.

A team dominated by players from the East Coast of the United States and a Californian quartet battled for the national men's team championship in the final of the, American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals here tonight, with most of their rivals far behind.

Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Communist party leader, and Secretary of State Kissinger began a series of crucial discussions with eight hours of talks in the Kremlin devoted mostly to Europe and the prospects for a new Soviet-American agreement on the limitation of strategic weapons. [1:1.]

A state environmental law prohibiting the dumping of outof-state garbage in New Jersey was declared unconstitutional by the State Superior Court today on the ground that the ban constituted an unlawful interference with interstate commerce.

The Citizens Union, a nonpartisan civic organization, charged yesterday that the City Council "still has a long way to go toward proving itself an effective legislature" despite steps recently taken for greater accountability to the public.
The Maine House rejected today a bill that would have returned to full public control about 400,000 woodland acres in northern Maine.
The Supreme Court, on a vote of 6 to 3, struck down as unconstitutionally vague today a Massachusetts law that made it a crime to treat the United States flag "contemptuously."
Australia has called on the United States and the Soviet Union to "exercise mutual restraint" in the Indian Ocean.

Rear Adm. Charles F. Behrens, retired, former commander of the Naval Medical Research Institute at Bethesda, Md., and an authority on radiology and atomic medicine, died Thursday at his home in Fair Haven, Md. He was 78 years old.

More than 4,715 disabled poor in the state - about 90 per cent of them in the city -- are being removed from Federal Supplemental Security Income rolls next Sunday because they do not meet stricter Federal definitions, though they had qualified under last year's state rules.

GOOD MORNING, MIDNIGHT. By Jean Rhys. 190 pages. Vintage Books. Paperbound. $1.65. A beautiful woman growing old may be one of the archetypal themes in fiction. Especially when she is alone, when she has no career to console her, no husband and children to cherish her for her other qualities, which often increase as if to compensate her for her lost youth.

Without offering a single new idea, President Nixon managed in his radio broadcast on education to run the gamut from mischievous rhetoric on busing to misleading explanations of aid for college students. When the busing controversy has subsided, in both nation and Congress, Mr. Nixon's call for stringent antibusing legislation as part of the Federal education aid package can only be described as disruptive and inflammatory. The dollar suffered further severe exchange losses in Europe today at one stage hanging to 500 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point , or more against the mark and other major currencies.
The Soviet Union has failed to persuade Norway to back the Soviet call to have the current talks on European security and cooperation end early this year on the summit level.
The Cincinnati Reds announced that Gary Nolan, pitcher, would be optioned to Indianapolis of the American Association when the farm club breaks camp in mid-April.
The leaders of three public employee organizations urged today the enactment of a Federal law guaranteeing the right of all Government workers to bargain collectively.
Syrian and Israeli forces shelled each other today for the 14th day on the Golan Heights front.

Wearing plaid slacks and a leather belt, George Foreman weighed 224 3/4 pounds, the heaviest of the world champion's career, for his heavyweight title against Ken Norton here tomorrow night. The challenger weighed 212 3/4.
Two New York City banks are negotiating with the Government of Argentina for return to Argentine control of banks in that country in which the New York banks hold an interest.
Robert D. Petrarca, a 26-year-old window washer, was found guilty today of first-degree murder in the death of an Upper Montclair matron and her married daughter last May 14.
Opium poppy cultivation has been resumed after a two-year break on six state farms in southwest Turkey, agriculture officials said today.

As Belgium began to feel severe gasoline and heating-oil shortages Premier Edmond Leburton anrlounced the working out of a compromise formula today in efforts to break a three-month deadlock over retail oil price increases.

For the second straight day the highly- regarded New York Mets pitching staff took an embarrassing pounding today when the Detroit Tigers slammed 17 hits off a trio of throwers, one of them a front-liner, Jon Matlack, and coasted to a 14-0 victory here.

The builder of the DC-10 jumbo jet involved in history's worst air crash said today that the plane had left the factory apparently lacking a critical cargo-door design change even though company records show the change had been made.

Matthew Guinan, president of the Transport Workers Union said yesterday that the contract dispute with the Transit Authority was so serious that it was time that Mayor Beame and Governor Wilson got into the situation.

The Sunday half-fare program of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority continued to lure additional riders onto its mass transit facilities last weekend even as open gasoline pumps and good driving weather caused motorists to travel the region's highways in larger numbers.

After more than seven hours of oftenacrimonious debate, the Republican majority in both houses of the Legislature pushed through the bulk of Governor Wilson's $9.3-billion budget for the new fiscal year, which begins Monday.

The Most Rev. Jean Jadot, the representative of Pope Paul VI in this country, declared last night that dialogue between Christians and Jews has entered a "new stage" marked by "sober and serious" consideration of interfaith problems. His speech represents the first time that someone in his position has given a formal address to a major American Jewish organization.

The Vatican said today that Pope Paul VI was not well and had been advised by his doctor to cancel his weekly general audience tomorrow. Reports that the Pope's condition is not so good as the Vatican says have been going around Rome for at least three months. Today's announcement caused some concern.

A three-month delay in putting into effect a new policy of welfare rent ceilings from next Monday until July 1 was announced by Abe Laving, Social Services Commissioner of New York State. He said the delay was to give time to weigh the impact of "unforeseen increases in heating fuel and utility costs"; vacancy decontrols in the city; cut off of Federal housing aid; general inflation and rising construction costs.

Howard Weinstein, a director of the Tishman Realty and Construction Company, 666 Fifth Avenue, died yesterday at the Albert Einstein Hospital, the Bronx. He was 48 years old and lived at 7 Surrey Close, White Plains.

A law partner of Nelson G. Gross made a dramatic courtroom appearance today to support defense testimony in the trial of the former state Republican chairman for alleged conspiracy to conceal campaign funds in 1969.

A State Department spokesman said today that the Government of Iceland had advised the United States in general terms of a proposal that calls for all 3,300 American servicemen in that country to leave by mid-1976. Representative Hugh L. Carey of Brooklyn formally announced his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for Governor yesterday, charging that Governor Wilson was "tied irrevocably by financial obligation and political ambition to Nelson Rockefeller and Richard Nixon."

A 22-year-old Queens man was sentenced to 5 to 15 years in prison yesterday for a robbery-murder in which 30 cents was taken from the victim, a 20-year-old Navy veteran. The defendant, Daniel Rose, a house painter of 142-15'122d Street, South Ozone Park, was sentenced by Justice Albert H. Bosch in the State Supreme Court in Queens on a manslaughter plea.

Shards of court reform bills are strewn about the state Legislature in Albany; the main interest of the lawmakers seems to be to prevent them from ever being put together in a comprehensive package aimed at depoliticizing the courts. Debate is scheduled today on a proposal to make judges to the Court of Appeals appointive, rather than elective.

Dr. Kenneth B. Clark said yesterday that he intended to ask the State Board of Regents, of which he is a member, to appoint a three-member commission to supersede the Board of Education here "for the specific purpose of desegregating the schools of New York City."

Paul M. Freeman, a former executive of the International Business Machines Corporation, died yesterday at Boca Raton Community Hospital. Boca Raton, Fla. He was 70 years old and lived on Deer Knoll Road, in Mount Kisco, N. Y., and in Boca Raton.

After more than seven hours of often acrimonious debate, the Republican majority in both houses of the Legislature pushed through the bulk of Governor Wilson's $9.3-billion budget for the new fiscal year, which begins Monday.

Since the Chicago Cubs are one of the two oldest major league baseball teams in the known cosmos (the Cincinnati Reds are the other), it is of more than routine significance to note that they are entering a new era.

Barbara M. Watson, the first black woman to attain a rank equivalent to Assistant Secretary of State, has been removed by the White House as administrator of the State Department's Bureau of Security and Consular Affairs. Without any advance notice to Miss Watson, the White House announced on Friday that she would be succeeded by Leonard F. Walentynowicz, a Buffalo. N. Y., lawyer.

Ion Gheorghe Maurer retired today as Premier of Rumania and was replaced by Manea Manescu, a Deputy Premier, the official Rumanian news agency, Agerpres, reported. Mr. Maurer, 71 years old, had served as Premier for 13 years.

The trial of John D. Ehrlichman, former White House adviser on domestic affairs, on perjury charges is scheduled to begin April 15. That would make Mr. Ehrlichman the first former high White House official to face a jury for the Ellsberg burglary.

Leonid I. Brezhnev and Secretary of State Kissinger, meeting for a second day at the Kremlin, dwelt today on approaches to a settlement in the Middle East, an area that has lately been a source of strain in Soviet-American relations.

The owner of taxicab fleets in the city asked yesterday for a 15.5 per cent fare increase, contending they were suffering severe financial losses because of increased gasoline prices and labor costs.

Many Brazilian university students have taken advantage of the recent change in governments to embark upon increased protests. While this activity is not worrisome by the standards of some countries, it has caused some concern in official circles here.

The state-owned British Steel Corporation said today it was Introducing price increases effective day after tomorrow. These rises are required to enable British steel to achieve a satisfactory level of profitability in the face of considerable increases in its costs, especially the purchase of raw materials and energy, said. The council, whose chairman is former Chief Judge Stanley H. A Japanese television network and the International Track Association have announced a two-day professional track meet to be held April 6 and 7 in Japan, costing more than $300,000.

The Federal Energy Office said, today that it had issued orders directing three oil refiners to make price reductions totaling about $44-million. However, an uncalculated part of the reductions will be only temporary, officials said.

It was another typical day for Mrs. Billie Jean King. She huddled with agents yesterday, spent two hours taping "The Bob Hope Show," attended meetings on a new women's satellite tour, a possible tennis Grand Prix for women, the Philadelphia Freedoms and answered dozens of telephone calls.

The Senate passed today by a vote of 89 to 0 a bill to extend for three years the nation's research against cancer at a cost of more than $2.7billion. The bill contains an amendment, strongly opposed by the Administration, that would set up a five-member Presidential advisory panel to oversee the research programs of the National Institutes of Health.

Paul H. Nitze, a Democrat, will not be nominated as Assistant Secretary of Defense because of opposition to him from conservatives in the Senate. Another man will shortly be proposed for the position. That information-in tentative terms-was given to the press tonight by Bryce N. Harlow, counselor to President Nixon.

Boxing fans at the RKO Coliseum in upper Manhattan booed George Foreman at first. Then they cheered the heavyweight champion for his devastating knockout of Ken Norton in the second round in Caracas, Venezuela, last night.

Five men on trial in the murder of Police Officers Waverly Jones and Joseph Piagentin were depicted in opening statements yesterday on one hand as executioners and on the other as five men "dedicated to social change in this countryrevolutionary change."

The Government said yesterday that 90 persons were killed and more than 160 wounded in fighting last week between Government forces and rebels in southeast Burma. The fighting was reported at three towns just across the Thai border, about 250 miles northwest of Bangkok.

The stock market managed to eke out a small advance yesterday helped by stepped-up institutional activity although the lethargy that has characterized recent trading conLinued. Brokers noted that the insituations, especially mutual funds, were seeking to readjust their portfolios before the current quarter ends Friday.

With a brutal barrage of punches that reduced the controversy over the nationality of the referee to an academic debate, George Foreman registered a knockout of Ken Norton after 2 minutes of the second round tonight in their world heavyweight title fight.

The Suffolk County Agricultural Advisory Committee urged the county administration today to go ahead as soon as possible with its proposed program of acquiring farmland, and suggested guidelines for the $45-million project.

Stevie Wonder's concert Monday evening at Madison Square Garden built to a quite wonderful climax-or two climaxes, more accurately. But apart from its specifically musical aspects, this was an occasion that reached beyond the moment to assume a symbolic function.

A Federal Trade Commission staff study said today that energy production is apparently no more monopolistic than any other industry, but competition is dwindling. The study said one Federal agency should monitor the situation by gathering information on the reserves of oil, natural gas, coal and uranium and verifying the reports independently.

The leader of the United Farm Workers, Cesar Chavez, said today he would curtail a present secondary boycott if the A.F.L.-C.I.O. would support a nationwide boycott of grapes and lettuce. Mr. Chavez, whose union renewed organizing efforts in California last week, said he expected the endorsement shortly.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company reduced its telephone rates to Honduras yesterday and plans to cut them to El Salvador April 5, In a rate filing with the Federal Communications Commission, A. T. T.'s Long Lines department said annual savings on calls to Honduras would amount to $240,000 to $500,000 to El Salvador.

Roscoe Tanner of Lookout Mountain, Tenn., placing his fast first serve perfectly, upset secondseeded Bjorn Borg of Sweden today, 5-7, 6-3, 7-5, in the first round of the $50,000 Desert tennis tournament, a World Championship Tennis circuit event.

United States reserve assets rose $78-million in February to $14.64-billion, the Treasury Department reported today. The entire gain came from an increase of $69-million in the American reserve position in the International Monetary Fund to $757-million and a rise of $9-million to $68-million in United States holdings of convertible foreign currencies.

The American Symphony led off its Carnegie Hall concert on Monday night with Barber's Second Essay and the Suite from Strauss's !!Der Rosenkavalier" - two pieces that an orchestra plays when it wants to show itself off. Confidence was not misplaced in this instance, for the technical execution was stunningly assured and brimming with vitality,

For that reason alone, the six-point plan proposed last week by the Vietcong's Provisional Revolutionary Government-despite its manifestly self-serving character-deserves better than a knee-jerk reaction of scorn from Saigon's President Thieu.

The State Legislature restored the death penalty today by overriding Gov. Milton J. Shapp's veto of a capital punishment bill. Mr. Shapp had vetoed the measure last Friday, saying several provisions of the bill were hopelessly vague.

The Soviet Navy is reported pressing to join American and British naval teams in the large-scale operations needed to clear the Suez Canal of mines and other explosives and military obstructions left behind by years of war.

A leading Soviet official told American newsmen today that the Soviet Union had "no immense need" to sell its West Siberian natural gas to the United States and would only do so if the United States invested the approximately $6billion necessary for the joint project.

Austin Clarke, the Irish poet and playwright, died here last Wednesday. He was 77 years old. A prolific author, Mr. Clarke producedd poetry, verse plays, poetic comedies and novels in more than 60 years of writing.

After a bitter debate late last night, the Assembly appoined two new members to the State Board of Regents, including the board's second woman member. At 1:15 this morning, after four hours of debate, the Senate approved the appointments by straight party vote of 37 to 22.

She's quite fascinated by it. In fact, she asked Ohrbach's to send her the white spring coat she admired at the fashion show she went to at the store the day before.

Ticket fever - an annual bug that infects the Knick and Ranger fan at playoff time--is rising again. The prescription is costly. "The prices will be the highest I've ever seen," said one scalper outside Madison Square Garden yesterday.

An executive of a food service and his cousin, a bank loan officer, were indicted here yesterday on charges of having fraudulently arranged bank loans for low-income investors who allegedly were then swindled out of their capital in a franchise pyramiding scheme.

A 30-year-old man who accepted the hospitality of a 70year-old man and his wife has pleaded guilty to stealing $3,500 of the couple's possessions. Howard Johnson of 17 West 127th Street, pleaded guilty before Justice Isidore Dollinger in Supreme Court in the Bronx. The judge set' April 24 for sentencing.

Wives of men with cancer of the prostate should have checkups every four months because they may be at greater risk of developing malignancies than wives of men without prostatic cancer, according to results of a Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center study reported in Houston yesterday.

The World Health Organization plans to establish a research center in central Africa aimed at preventing and treating tropical diseases that affect hundreds of millions of people. The center will be the focal point of a network of clinics and field hospitals throughout tropical Africa.

Higher fuel prices and rising operating costs continued to plague Pan American World Airways and Eastern Airlines as their deficits widened in February, they reported yesterday. Northwest Airlines had a profit increase, helped by a capital gain.

The United States Steel Corporation signed a letter of intent yesterday with the Fauji Foundation of Pakistan to build a $135-million fertilizer plant in the Rahimyar District of Punjab Province. The plant will produce 550,000 tons of urea fertilizer when it is completed in late 1977. United States aid funds are expected to cover some $90-million in foreign exchange costs.

Hans Bernd Gisevius, an anti-Nazi German police official who was a leading prosecution witness at the Nuremberg war crime trials, died of a heart attack on Feb. 23 in West Germany, according to a family announcement today. He was 68 years old.

At 9:20 last night, with the Knicks ahead, 98-72, Harthorne Wingo replaced Dave DeBusschere in the line-up and the regular-season playing career ended for the man National Basketball Association fans have tagged "Mr. Defense."

Up to 8:30 tonight, the men who own Ken Norton were threatening to keep their fighter out of the ring with George Foreman, heavyweight champion of the world. For the sake of their man's health, they shouldn't have changed their minds. Reluctantly accepting the referee Foreman's manager demanded, they sent Norton out to be smashed down three times and clubbed senseless in exactly five minutes of fighting.

Tyco Laboratories said it would pay $24.25 cash for each of the 907,823 shares outstanding of the Simplex Cable and Wire Company. The offer came to a total of more than $22million. The agreement, which has been approved by directors of both companies, must be approved by holders of two-thirds of Simplex common shares.
Terrorist bombs rocked the headquarters of an army bomb-disposal regiment in northern England today. The women manager of an army canteen was the only casualty. She was slightly wounded.

The Iraqi Government announced tonight that it had issued decrees placing into effect the plan for self-rule that it proclaimed March 11 for the Kurdish minority in the mountainous northern region of the country. The announcement was made in a broadcast by President Ahmed Hassan al-Bakr at the end of the 15 days that

The Ford Motor Company disclosed today in its annual report that it had decided to defer about $100-million of about $1-billion in capital spending scheduled for this year. The deferred spending had been slated mostly for big-car facilities.

It is not likely that the outside world will know for many months exactly what happened in Uganda over last weekend, but the postscript is tragically familiar. Gen. Idi Amin evidently is using the incident to carry out yet another round of summary executions of Ugandan army officers whom he suspects of doubtful loyalty to his brutal dictatorship.

The caretaker coalition Government of Belgium offered today the country's oil industry a 36 per cent rise in retail oil prices in an effort to avoid threatening fuel shortages. The companies, including many American-owned groups, have asked for a 50 per cent increase to meet recent crude oil price rises and have stopped refinery operations in Belgium to force action.

Matthew P. Boylan, a prominent 41-year-old New Jersey trial lawyer who two years ago was named special state prosecutor in the bribery trial of then Secretary of State Paul J. Sherwin, was named today as director of the Criminal Justice Division in the State Attorney General's office.

Walter Thurston, former Ambassador to Mexico, Bolivia and El Salvador, died Sunday at his cattle farm near here. He was 79 years old. Mr. Thurston, who began his diplomatic career in 1914, became chief of the Latin-American Division of the State Department in 1930.

Governor Byrne signed legislation yesterday increasing the state urban aid program by 50 per cent to $36.7million. The money will be distributed to the 24 cities and townships that have participated in the program since it was expanded in 1971 from the original $12-million plan for the six biggest New Jersey cities.

To the Editor: The energy shortage is a world crisis which will not disappear with the renewed flow of Arab fuel, even if at prices Americans can afford. Necessary changes in our life-support systems will not happen easily as vested interests have much to lose by changes in the status quo.

Killian opened a storefront headquarters on Washington Street here yesterday in his bid to win delegates to the state Democratic convention in the Hartford primary on May 23. Mr. Killian must win in Hartford if he is to remain in the race for the Democratic nomination for Governor.

Austria's Chancellor, Bruno Kreisky, said at a news conference today that fewer Jews were emigrating at present from the Soviet Union to Israel through Austria. "There were always ups and downs in the emigration of Soviet Jews to Israel," he said. "and it appears that there is a down phase presently."

Widespread fighting was reported in Cambodia today, as Government forces pressed a twopronged assault on the town of Phsar Oudong, held by Communist-led insurgents since March 18.

A British Member of Parliament has told the Foreign Office that a Russian woman attempted to seduce him in Moscow in January. He believes it may have been part of a blackmail plot. Ivan Lawrence, a 37-yearold Conservative, said he had also reported the incident to the British Embassy in the Soviet capital.

New Orleans District Attorney Jim Garrison was found not guilty of income tax evasion today by a United States District Court jury. Mr. Garrison, the controversial prosecutor who gained national attention with his investigation of the assassination of President Kennedy, had been accused of failing to report $60000 in income for the years 1965-67-part of it allegedly from bribes.

North Carolina State's 76-64 victory over Marquette for the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball championship Monday night was an anticlimax to the Wolfpack's semifinal triumph over the University of California Los Angeles, on Saturday.

The owner of taxicab fleets in the city asked yesterday for a 15.5 per cent fare increase, contending they were suffering severe financial losses because of increased gasoline prices and labor costs. As a prelude to the city's bicentennial celebration, Mayor Beame yesterday inaugurated a two-year project for the Girl Scout Council of Greater New York called, "Take Stock in New York." More than 50,000 Girl Scouts and 8,000 adults in the city will carry out a project designed to make New York a better place in which to live.

Donald H. Segretti, the 32-year-old California lawyer who pleaded guilty to committing "dirty tricks" against Democrats in 1972 primary election campaigns, has been released from prison, the Justice Department announced today.
Released outright Luis Aparicio, shortstop, and Orlando Cepeda, designated hitter. Optioned Mark Bomback, Dick Pole, right-handed pitchers, to Pawtucket of the International League.

The Louisiana Superdome tried and failed today to sell $139.9-million in bonds to refinance the massive stadium currently under construction. Herman J.Kohlmeyer Sr., financial adviser to the stadium commission. said no bids were received because of "the unfavorable nature of the bond market." The commission voted to readvertise for bids at a new date, hoping for a more favorable market.

The state's special prosecutor, Maurice H. Nadjari, will insist on an unconditional waiver of immunity from State Supreme Court Justice Irwin Brownstein of Brooklyn and will press for his removal if the justice refuses, sources close to the case said yesterday.

DuPont Walston, Inc., which quit the stock brokerage business voluntarily on Jan. 21, filed for reorganization yesterday under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act. Gen. Mustafa al Barzani, leader of Iraq's rebellious Kurdish minority, said today that his tribesmen and Iraqi Government troops "face the possibility of all-out war."

Ash, director of the Office of Management and Budget.

The Trojans have finished second four times in the Hoosiers' streak.

The Harvard University student newspaper, The Crimson, checked into Mr. Horovitz's record and discovered that he had never received a degree from Harvard.

Top-seeded Arthur Ashe survived a tough challenge by Ove Bengston of Sweden today to score a 2-6, 6-1, 7-6 victory and advance to the quarterfinals of the World Championship Tennis circuit tournament.

Two Broadway musicals, "Raisin" and "Candide," walked away with the bulk of this year's Antoinette Perry (Tony) award nominations, announced yesterday. "Raisin" garnered nine nominations and "Candide" eight.
Mrs. Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn announced today that although it was "excruciatingly painful" to leave her Russian homeland, she and her family would join her husband in Switzerland Friday.
Rebels have again seized control of, Asmara and a group of military officers told Ethiopians today that the armed forces would protect civilians from mass killing.

The Newmont Mining Corporation said late yesterday that its subsidiary, the Magma Copper Company, had filed suit in the United States District Court in the District of Columbia seeking to have declared illegal a recent Government action that placed domestic primary producer-refined copper under the defense priority system.

With time growing short in the city's critical transit negotiations, a three-man mediation panel scheduled a meeting for this afternoon with Mayor Beame to report on the status of the talks and the problems in getting a settlement before the 5 A.M. Monday deadline.

Senate investigators today charged that American oil companies in the Middle East acted in concert. to help increase oil prices and profits. Raymond P. Branat, chler or the Washington bureau of The St. Louis Post-Dispatch from 1934 to 1961 and later a contributing editor, died today in Georgetown University Hospital. He was 77 years old.

Soviet crop production in 1974 probably will drop about 8 per cent from last year's record, but Russia probably will reduce its grain imports sharply and may return to its traditional role of a net grain exporter, the Agriculture Department said today.

President Nixon told a Republican fund-raising dinner tonight that "candidates who support this Administration will have a strong case to take to the people this fall." Without mentioning or even alluding to Watergate, Mr. Nixon predicted that "the two great issues that move people in campaigns, peace and prosperity," would carry the Republicans to victory.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 27-On the hotel elevator a man asked: "What is the area of Zaire?" "Four drumbeats," said a witty American. The elevator stopped and he got off, leaving only the man who had asked the question and a woman with a sweet smile. At her floor she paused. "Zaire," she said, "is about 100 square miles." So ended the geography lesson for today.

The United States came a step closer to establishing relations with East Germany when the Government in East Berlin showed a State Department delegation what it considered "reasonable" property for a United States mission, according to officials here.

Strong winds and fog at the Mount Rose resort forced the postponement today of the first men's giant slalom in the World Series of Skiing. The race was rescheduled for tomorrow before the women's giant slalom.

Attorney General William B. Saxbe said today that it was "entirely" up to the House Judiciary Committee to decide whether to allow the White House to take an active role in the House impeachment inquiry.

A 13th minute goal by a midfielder, Joachim Streich, gave East Germany a 1-0 victory over Czechoslovakia today in a World Soccer Cup try-out. A crowd of 55,000 packed Dresden's stadium.

Dr. Donald Decker Wright, professor 6f chemistry at Brooklyn College, died Tuesday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 65 years old and lived on Midwood Street in Brooklyn.

As the nation's bicentennial approaches. historical programs of American music are increasing in number, and since this country had hardly any formal instrumental music during the first century of its existence, most of these programs are of vocal music.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass.--Many of the defects of democracy arise from the principle of one man, one vote. If all men were in fact not only created equal but also remained equal-in ability, intelligence, judgment and wisdom-then granting each man an equal voice in government would be the soundest basis of achieving justice for all.

Without formal advice from top management, directors of live television programs and special events for the networks have put themselves on an alert for streakers, fearing that television might present a new frontier for nude runners determined to reach a larger audience.
A 52-year-old Transit Authority foreman was killed last night when he was struck by a northbound IRT train in a tunnel south of the 149th Street-Grand Concourse station in the Bronx, the police said.
The New Jersey Bell Telephone Company shut off service to the National Socialist White Peoples party, which had been offering recorded hate messages against Jews and blacks.

President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt arrived here today for a relaxed, three-day visit with President Tito of Yugoslavia. With Mr. Sadat were his wife, Foreign Minister Ismael Fahmy and Lieut. Gen. Mohammed Abdel Ghany el-Gamasy, the armed forces' chief of staff.

Wrangling over the planned New York City Convention and Exposition Center continued yesterday as Mayor Beame received letters of intent from three national trade shows that had agreed to take space in the 560,000-square-foot facility on the Hudson River.

Attorney General William B. Saxbe has asked the United States Court of Appeals here to sustain President Nixon's refusal to turn over five White House tape recordings to the Senate Watergate committee.

Last year's oil price and profit increases may well have increased the United States's proved recoverable reserves, but the American Petroleum Institute's annual estimate, released today, showed a decrease in these reserves of one billion barrels in 1973.

Harold S. Foley, formerly vice chairman of the MacMillan Bloedel Powell River Company, a major Canadian newsprint manufacturer, died March 21 at his home in Vancouver, British Columbia.

The plunging British stock market claimed its first brokerage house victim today when Mitton, Butler, Priest Co., a medium-sized firm, said it could not meet its obligations.

Los Angeles clinched a playoff berth for the first time in five seasons as Butch Goring scored twice and added two assists tonight, leading the Kings to a 4-1 National Hockey League victory over the New York Islanders.
Ticket prices will be higher next season for most Metropolitan Opera subscribers. Prices for seats have been raised, with the percentage of increase depending upon location.
On a recent Thursday night, Dr. Harold Dundy left his office on Eastern Parkway in Brooklyn, got into a cab, and was driven off to Brooklyn College, where he joined his wife at a party.
The Sacramento Bee will increase its street price from 10 cents to 15 cents daily and from 35 cents to 50 cents on Sunday, effective April 1, because of rising costs.
Two jailed members of the group that calls itself the Symbionese Liberation Army urged today the "safe return" of Patricia Hearst, who was kidnapped Feb. 4.

Secretary of State Kissinger returned to Washington tonight after failing in three days of talks in Moscow to achieve the "conceptual breakthrough" he had hoped would lead soon to a new Soviet-American agreement on strategic arms limitations.

A political storm in a province capital has generated open attacks on party chiefs and officials for the first time in China's current mass-criticism campaign, according to reports reaching here today.
The dollar sagged further on European money markets notes today as gold prices held steady. In London, the pound closed at $2,402, up strongly from the opening of $2.377.
Prices of natural gas and electricity will triple over the next few years unless inflation is brought under control, the chairman of the Federal Power Commission predicted today.

Ray Charles is back in town. The 43-year-old dean of soul music is appearing twice nightly through Sunday at Jupiter's a year-old supper club at 700 Hempstead Turnpike on Long Island, which is now aiming for big-name shows.

Reductions in the use of electricity, natural gas and steam saved an equivalent of 210,000 barrels of oil in the week ended last Sunday, according to preliminary figures released by Consolidated Edison yesterday.
Syria served notice today that she would demand Israel's recognition of "Palestinian national rights" as a condition for a truce agreement in the Golan Heights sector of the Middle East front.
Robert Hayes, reputed to be a member of the Black Liberation Army, was found guilty yesterday of murder and robbery in the shooting of a transit patrolman last June.

Jack Nicklaus and Miller Barber resumed today where they left off a year ago. They shot six-under-par 66's over the Lakewood Country Club to tie for the lead in the first round of the $150,000 Greater New Orleans open.
Willie Long less and Mike Green helped the Denver Rockets withstand a late fourth-period surge by the San Antonio Spurs and record a 96-92 American Basketball Association victory tonight.

A total of 76 candidates met the filing deadline today for the May 14 race for Mayor and nine Council seats. Six of those candidates, including Kenneth A. Gibson, the incumbent, and State Senator Anthony Imperiale, seek the post of Mayor.

After an 82-game regular game schedule filled with injuries and subsequent disappointments on the playing court, the Knicks will welcome a chance to wipe all that from memory tonight when they begin the defense of their National Basketball Association championship against the Capital Bullets at Madison Square Garden.

Samuel Roskin, founder and board chairman of Roskin Distributors, Inc., in East Hartford, Conn., which represents some 300 manufacturers of varied merchandise, died of cancer Tuesday in Miami Beach, where he had been on vacation.
Oilmen offered a record of $2.16-billion today for the right to drill oil and gas wells farther out in the Gulf of Mexico than ever before, but many of the deepwater tracts were passed over.

A coin laundry in a Roman suburb was the cover for the operations center of a Mafia ring that had been smuggling large shipments of heroin to the United States, court officials say.

Rebel troops today ended a three-day occupation of Asmara, Ethiopia's second largest city, but mounting civil unrest and the threat of clashes between rival military units have virtually paralyzed Emperor Haile Selassie's foundering Government.
Political treasuries for this fall are already filled with at least $14.2-million for the election campaigns of members of the House and Senate, according to a study released today by Common Cause.

The chairmen of the New York and American Stock Exchanges urged the Senate Securities subcommittee today to speed legislation confining transactions in listed securities to the national stock exchanges.
Dr. Donald Decker Wright, professor of chemistry at Brooklyn College, died Tuesday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 65 years old and lived on Midwood Street in Brooklyn.

Although the New York Nets just completed their most successful regular season with an impressive 102-96 victory over Denver on Wednesday night that clinched first place in the American Basketball Association East, they are not taking the fourth-place Virginia Squires for granted in the playoffs.
George Bradford Cook testified yesterday that'Maurice H. Stans informed him at a meeting in the White House mess hall that he had lied to the grand jury investigating the Mitchell-Stans case.

Dr. Louis M. Rousselot, a prominent New York surgeon who was former Assistant Secretary of Defense for Health and Environment and special assistant with the National InsLitutes of Health, died yesterday of an aneurysm while vacationing in Puerto Rico.

The Upjohn Company issued yesterday at its headquarters at Kalamazoo, Mich., a statement seeking to put down "a revivied interest in the financial community" in two major antibiotics.
Six months of energy shortage have paradoxically both dented and strengthened, slowed down and speeded up, the nation's drive for environmental quality.
Assemblyman J. Edward Meyer, a Republican turned Democrat, withdrew today from the race for the Congressional seat being vacated by Ogden R. Reid, who is seeking the gubernatorial nomination.

President Nixon has proclaimed today as Vietnam Veterans Day because a year ago the last American combat soldier departed from that country of casualties. The most appropriate ceremonies. to mark the occasion would be action in Washington to give these veterans improved rights. Educational benefits and job opportunities are the real honors the men who served seek and deserve.

A 41-year-old man who was charged with a murder but released without bail last December in a controversial decision by Judge Bruce McM. Wright of the City Criminal Court has been acquitted of a reduced charge of simple assault in the case.

Dr. Kenneth B. Clark, the Psychologist and educator, said yesterday that the exodus of white families from New York City over the last two decades had resulted from "too little"-father than "too much" school desegregation in the city.
The Senate turned back today renewed attempts to scale down the proposed use of public tax funds to finance Presidential and Congressional election campaigns.

The France, biggest in a vanishing fleet of world passenger liners and for the last dozen years the sparkling symbol of this country's graces, is to be taken out of service, probably within the next six weeks.
Bud Harrelson and Cleon Jones shook hands today, formally ending the dugout skirmish that gave the New York Mets'the distinction of having staged the first flareup of spring training.

Libby, McNeill Libby, a leading packer of canned and frozen foods which is 56 per cent-owned by Nestle Alimentano, S. A., said yesterday that it was seeking ways to reduce the size of its frozen food operations.

The Transport Workers Union, battling against a Monday strike deadline for its more than 35,000 local bus and subway workers,. said yesterday that the negotiations for major gains were the "most difficult" in its 40-year history because of the very tight money situation no.

Secretary of State Kissinger returned to Washington tonight after failing in three days of talks in Moscow to achieve the "conceptual breakthrough" he had hoped would lead soon to a new Soviet-American agreement on strategic arms limistations.
A vice provost of City College has resigned to return to teaching, and he warned that those charged with finding his successor should withstand pressures brought by ethnic or political groups.

Secretary of the Treasury George P. Shultz, in an action apparently without precedent, asked the Tariff Commission today to "reopen, reconsider and reverse" its decision of last January that would lead to higher import duties on lead metal from Canada and Australia under the antidumping law.

Raymond J. Guest, former United States Ambassador to Ireland, win be hoping the third time will be lucky Saturday when his L'Escargot runs in the $93,240 Grand National Steeplechase over the testing Aintree course. L'Escargot, trained by David Moore in Ireland and ridden by Tommy Carberry of Ireland, is the only trans-Atlantic challenger for the $60,240 first prize.
Political treasuries for this fall are already filled with at least $14.2-million for the election campaigns of members of the House and Senate, according to a study released today by Common Cause.
The stock market took its worst beating in almost two months yesterday in active trading as investors' concern over higher interest rates pushed prices sharply lower.
The Pentagon asked Congress today not to restrict its right to check the backgrounds of prospective employes.

From early scanning of the planet Mercury by the approaching Mariner 10 spacecraft, scientists believe that the close-up images of the planet to be received tomorrow afternoon will be some of the great "space spectaculars" of the century.

The campaign fraud case against Nelson G. Gross, the former state Republican chairman, went to the jury this evening after a trial that lasted nearly five weeks and included the testimony of 28 witnesses.

The Todd Shipyards Corporation said yesterday it was negotiating contracts for construction of six supertankers on the Gulf Coast. The ships, which would weigh 400,000 tons each, would be the first built in that area. Todd is asking for a price of $130-million for each tanker with Exxon International, the Zapata Corporation and the Central Gulf Steamship Company. They would be built at Galveston.

The Mayor of this Ocean County community has proclaimed a time for streaking -- Feb. 29, except in leap years, and the sixth week of March.

The pace of Middle East diplomacy in the coming weeks may provide a clearer signal of the prospects for superpower detente than did the unilluminating communique in Moscow. If Mr. Kissinger was unable to gain Soviet support-or at least absence of opposition-for his ongoing mediation effort between Israel and Syria, the whole American peacemaking initiative could be in for a sharp and sudden setback.
Concern of investors over higher interest rates sent the stock market yesterday into its biggest decline in almost two months. The Dow-Jones
The Metropolitan Opera will present four new productions next season as well as two productions that are scheduled to be introduced during the coming June Festival, the company announced yesterday.

Marion H. Smoak will soon step down as Chief of Protocol of the State Department and be succeeded by Henry E. Catto Jr., a wealthy Texas Republican who is the son-in-law of Oveta Culp Hobby, publisher of The Houston Post and former Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare.

The industrial countries that provide 95 per cent of the world's foreign aid to the poorer countries have pledged that they will not reduce their aid programs because of the impact of steeply higher oil prices.

A reputed organized-crime figure once charged with the murder of a restaurant owner who was a key witness in an investigation into an alleged extortion operation in Queens was found slain in the trunk of a car yesterday.

Well before noon yesterday - when the crafts show opened - the lobby was already crowded with people waiting to buy tickets. By 3 P.M., about 2,500 people had streamed into the New York Coliseum and up to the third floor to look, buy and participate, at the second annual Craft Materials and Equipment Show.

The Bankers Trust Company announced yesterday a onehalf point increase in its prime lending rate - to 9 1/2 per cent, effective Monday. At the sametime, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York yesterday reported another week of strong loan demand and sharply rising interest rates.
For the first time in two years, the Watergate affair has had some discernible impact on important Soviet-American negotiations.
Chase Manhattan bank has decided to delay plans to open money shops in Britain specializing in consumer finance, a bank spokesman said here today.

With all the glitter he had spent his life trying to escape, Peter Revson was buried yesterday. The automobile racer, who sought to live down an image as a "Jet-Set playboy" and Revlon heir, was killed a week ago while practicing for tomorrow's South African Grand Prix.
Rick Martin's 47th goal of the season with less than six minutes to play pulled the Buffalo Sabres into a 2-2 National Hockey League tie with the Chicago Black Hawks tonight.

To the Editor: Secretary of the Treasury George Shultz, on announcing his intention of leaving the Administration, made a number of statements which, even discounting for the normally self-serving tendencies of such ceremonies, should not be allowed to stand.

Fifty-five private carting companies in Brooklyn and nine carting industry officials were indicted yesterday on charges of restraint of trade and perjury. The indictments were the culmination of a two-year investigation during which District trict Attorney Eugene Gold of Brooklyn secretly bought a truck and went into the garbage business.

More than 500 North Vietnamese arid Vietcong soldiers attacked a South Vietnamese camp 35 miles northwest of Saigon and held parts of it for more than 24 hours before the 300-man garrison drove them off this morning, the South Vietnamese command reported.

Col. Eric S. Barron, Engineers Corps Reserve, retired, and former senior resident engineer of the Port of New York Authority at its Hoboken piers, died Tuesday in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., where he lived. He was 76 years old and had lived in Malverne, L. I.

United States tax authorities have subpoenaed records of 30 banks in Chicago and five in New York into which W. Clement Stone, one of the wealthiest men in the United States, funneled more than $5-million in campaign gifts, The Chicago Tribune said tonight.

An intensive study of 40 families with leukemic children has shown that only one in 10 families emerges from the experience without serious disruption of the family unit, a Stanford University social worker reported here today.
The Del Monte Corporation, a large canner of fruits and vegetables, indicated in its earnings report yesterday that retail prices of most canning products would probably be higher in mid-summer.
David H. Bradford Jr. has been elected president and chief operating officer of the Allied Chemical Corporation. He succeeds Frederick L Bissinger, who was appointed to the new post of vice chairman.

United States officials said today that the wife of a missing United States vice consul had made "every possible effort to follow the instructions" contained in a ransom note but that she had received no further word from her husband or his captors.

No element in the skyrocketing cost of living has a more direct impact on the economic viability of New York City than the size of the subway and bus fare. The passage by the State Legislature yesterday of Governor Wilson's transportation package-with no restructuring to expand the $70 million in promised state operating subsidy-makes plainer than ever the fateful nature of the negotiations to be concluded this weekend for a new transit wage agreement.
The Dutch Labor party of Premier Joop den Uyl scored gains in nationwide provincial elections yesterday, and its success was generally credited today to his strong leadership during the oil crisis.

Assembly committee today recommended basic changes in the state's Taylor Law, including an end to jail terms for union leaders involved in illegal strikes and a three-year experiment in binding arbitration in negotiations with policemen's and firemen's unions.

Elton McNeil, a child psychologist, died yesterday in St. Joseph Mercy Hospital after a heart attack. He was 50 years old. Dr. McNeil, a professor of psychology at the University of Michigan, was the author of a number of books, including the 1972 volume.

The Indian Government, frightended about a lag in food production and tensions in the nation, decided tonight to scrap its controversial year-old takeover of wheat distribution.

Sharp disagreement between the Government and the American Medical Association on how to assure high-quality medical care erupted in public today.

Venezuela finally found somebody yesterday who could stop George Foreman: its tax collectors. Foreman, boxing's undefeated heavyweight champion, was still cooling his heels in Caracas last night after suffering a "technical knockout" at the hands of the tax men.

The Knicks, who have won two of the last four National Basketball Association championships with a heavy emphasis on defense, started pursuit of a third crown last night with a sparkling offensive display that defeated the Capital Bullets, 102-91.

For twenty years the flourishing relations between Yugoslavia and Italy have served as dramatic proof that even the most intractable and explosive of international problems can be resolved with patience and goodwill. Now, in fits of petulance that defy rational explanation, Belgrade and Rome are restoring the territorial quarrel that once threatened to ignite great-power conflict but that they settled, in fact if not in law, in 1954.

For the first time since his group. purchased the Yankees, their principal owner, George Steinbrenner, held a meeting with all his players tonight and prompted applause from them with a 15-minute: talk.

Like the run on the banks in the nineteen-thirties, Miami football fans were concerned today that the defection of three of their favorite players to the World Football League would trigger a run on the Dolplins.

WASHINGTON, April 1(AP)--Millions of needy Americans will get additional food stamps beginning July 1 to help meet soaring grocery costs, the Agriculture Department announced today.

Bache Co., Inc., yesterday became the third leading stock brokerage house to revamp its price schedule for small investors. Acting just a few days after its two giant competitors Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fennez Smith, Inc., and Paine, Webber, Jackson Curtis,. Inc. -it responded to an industrywide call from the Securities and Exchange Commission for experimentation on orders for stock of $2,000 and under.

Luis E. Cadiz, who was appointed a deputy commissioner fly in the Department of Correction last Saturday by Mayor Beame, confirmed last night that he had railed a civil service test last June for a job as a senior quantitative analyst in the Housing and Development Administration.
Leaders of municipal labor unions called yesterday for cost-of-living raises for their members similar to those won by the transit workers.

The Utah stars of the American Basketball Association were sold today to a Salt Lake City corporation that says it will soon offer 80 per cent of Stars stock for public ownership. Robert L. Vesco, the fugitive financier, declined last night to say whether he ever discussed with President Nixon his secret $200,000 cash contribution to the President's reelection campaign.

The New York Nets presented "Showtime Basketball" tonight at the Nassau Coliseum. It began at 8:07 P.M, with William Paultz Sr., 6 feet 5 inches tall and 250 pounds, singing the National Anthem and ended with a 129-110 battering of the Virginia Squires.

Coming Glass Works, the first major corporation to announce earnings results for the first calendar quarter, reported yesterday a 1.7 per cent decrease in earnings from the year earlier period. It was the company's first quarterly decline in three years.

The first legal challenge to the state's no-fault insurance law was filed in State's Supreme Court in Brooklyn on behalf of six auto-accident victims, each of whose medical expenses were under $500. Under the law, which became effective last Feb. 'I, an accident victim can sue a negligent driver only if he 'required medical treatment costing at least $500.
Dave Herman announced his retirement from professional football yesterday and then issued a bleak series of views on the current state of affairs in the sport.

A 42-year-old Belleville man, described as a key figure in a special Essex County grand jury inquiry into gangland killings, is being held here after being unable to post $500,000 bond on a murder charge.
The price of men's sportswear--currently the bestselling category of male apparel--will rise at least 10 per cent by next fall or even sooner, retailers said yesterday.

Like the run on the banks in the nineteen-thirties, Miami football fans were concerned today that the defection of three of their favorite players to the World Football League would trigger a run on the Dolphins.

A bill to aid parochial schools that critics charge is just as unconstitutional as one struck down by the United States Supreme Court last year passed the Assembly today without debate and with only nine negative votes.

Petroleum refining capacity last year increased at its greatest rate in at least 10 years. The Oil and Gas Journal said today.

The State Commissioner of Education, Ewald B. Nyquist, told the Mount Verlon Board of Education today that it could no longer delayl implementation of a plan to integrate its schools.

A legislative repeal of a 1962 bond covenant that precludes the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey from any involvement in mass-transit projects that may lose money won initial and overwhelming approval here today in the New Jersey Assembly.
A pregnant Greek woman flying to New York so her baby could be born American was thwarted yesterday when she went into labor over the Atlantic and her flight was diverted to Montreal.

Production of steel for the week ended Saturday declined by 0.1 per cent to 2,872,000 tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. This lowered the weekly production index to 117.7 from 117.8 the week before, when 2,875,000 tons of steel were poured.

The Supreme Court declined today to review a decision upholding an order by the Federal Trade Commission against the Kennecott Copper Corporation. As a result, Kennecott must divest itself, of the Peabody Coal Company, which it bought for more than $600-million in 1968.
More than 2,000 drug treatment specialists ended a three-day meeting here today with much greater accord on the changing pattern of drug abuse than on what to do about it.

Dr. John R. Olive, director of the American Institute of Biological Sciences in Washington, died of heart failure Saturday at the Scottsdale Memorial Hospital in Arizona at the age of 59. His home was in Bethesda, Md. Dr. Olive was visiting the Arizona State University in Tempe to prepare for the institute's 25th anniversary meeting, which will take place there in June.

An allegation by Senator Edward M. Kennedy that the Nixon Administration had made "new commitments" of support to South Vietnam was denied today day by the State Department.

Banks in the United States have been photocopying checks at the rate of 20 Billon to 30 billion a year in compliance with regulations of the Treasury Department under the Bank Secrecy Act of 1970. The regulations which after some delay became effective Jan. 17, 1973, require photocopying of all checks for 100 or more.

Houston's Don Grierson scored second-period goals 55 seconds apart tonight as the Aeros ruined the New England Whalers farewell to Boston with a 4-1 World Hockey Association victory. The largest crowd in Whalers' history, 14,711, looked on.

The Labor Department approved today a program by the elevator construction industry to hire and train additional minority workers. Labor Secretary Peter J. Brennan said.it was the first nationwide plan adopted in the construction industry .

WASHINGTON, April 1--Members of the House Judiciary Committee are considering a timetable that envisions beginning hearings on impeachment evidence by May 1 and completing committee action by mid-June.

State Controller Arthur Levitt reported today that the state had ended Its fiscal year yesterday with a cash surplus of $127-million but he noted that there was up to $500-million that would be available in the budget for new programs or for the enrichmerit of existing ones.

Congressional staff investigators have completed their examination of President Nixon's tax returns, for the years 1969 through 1972, but it was not clear today, just how soon the public would learn what they found.

The House Ways and Means Committee, reversing a series of decisions it made over the last several weeks, voted today to bring an end to the controversial oil depletion allowance, at least where major oil producers are concerned.

Three members of the Board of Estimate said yesterday that they would vote against a request by seven private bus companies to raise their basic fares to 50 cents. The board members said they were certain the board would refuse the request.

In each spring National Championship, the player with the best performance, measured in master points, receives the Geoffrey MottSmith trophy. In Vancouver, British Columbia, last week, an unusual race developed for this honor.
Wayne Carleton's second goal with 2:49 of the game remaining provided the winner tonight as the Toronto Toros defeated the Edmonton Oilers, 3-2, in a World Hockey Association game.
Stocks were irregular yesterday in quiet trading as investors' apprehensions over increasing interest rates continued to discourage activity.

The Most Rev. Thomas A. Boland, Archbishop of Newark, is retiring after 21 years as head of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese, it was announced yesterday. His successor will be the Most Rev. Peter L. Gerety, Bishop of the Diocese of Portland, which includes all of the State of Maine,

WEST DES MOINES, Iowa-In the face of studies that claim to demonstrate that capital punishment does not deter potential criminals, American public opinion clearly favors a return to the death penalty.

Labor and management at the Palace Buffet have finally reached an agreement to end their strike--after 14 years and four months. Settlement was announced yesterday by Local 327 of the Hotel, Motel, Cafeteria and Restaurant employes Union.

Selling pressure in the late afternoon pushed the value of the dollar marginally lower on most European money markets today. Gold prices gained across the board. In its only major bright spot, the American currency gained slightly against the British pound.

A mandatory rollback of interest rates, a reduction in personal income taxes and restrictions on imports and foreign investments were proposed yesterday by Senator Vance Hartke as part of a program to stimulate more employment.

City College is assembling a distinguished advisory council for its Leonard Davis Center for the Performing Arts, and acceptance have already been received from 11 persons prominent in arts and letters.

The Chicago Cougars, led by Jan Popiel's three goals, gained their first World Hockey Association playoff berth tonight by defeating the Jersey Knights, 7-3. The victory eliminated Quebec in the East Division.

A film about a pair of lighthearted con men, "The Sting," kept alive Hollywood's fascination with copsand robber movies by winning the best-picture award tonight in the annual Oscar parade.

After 12 consecutive sessions in which the American Stock Exchange's market value index fell, the index rose yesterday and thus failed to set a record for consecutive sessions showing declines. The record, set in January of last year, was tied with the decline on Monday.

This year's edition of the Newport Jazz Festival - New York, which opens a 10-day run here June 28, will be half the size of last year's extravaganza but, according to its producer, will be better organized for listening and profit.

A memorial service for Hal Boyle, The Associated Press columnist who died here Monday, will be held at 1 P.M. today at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration (the Little Church Around the Corner), 1 East 29th Street.

Lawrence Joseph Cardinal Shehan resigned today as Archbishop of Baltimore. Cardinal Shehan, who was 76 years old last month, had submitted his resignation on his 75th birthday, in keeping with pope Paul's guideline of 75 as the general retirement age for bishops.

The Chrysler Corporation's huge old Jefferson Avenue assembly plant, a long-time symbol of industrial Detroit, closed down last week for the fourth time since the gasoline shortage sent car sales plummeting late last year. On Monday morning its vast parking lot was deserted, a frigid urban plain.
Lewis R. Friedman was named yesterday by District Attorney Richard H. Kuh as chief of his appeals bureau. He had been deputy chief of the bureau for the last two years.

Irving Anker, the city's School Chancellor, returned full control of School District 26 in northeast Queens to the local school board yesterday after settlement of a dispute with the board over finances.
FOrmer Representative Richard L. Ottinger was selected tonight as the Democratic candidate for the Westchester County Congressional seat being vacated by Ogden R. Reid.

Ten undercover narcotics agents who invaded six southeastern Illinois households by mistake last April 1 were acquitted tonight of charges that they had conspired to deprive the victims of their civil rights.

A festive crowd. of approximately 5,000 jammed the University of South Carollna baseball field tonight and saw Eddie Ford rip Whitey Ford for a single and Hank Small outslug Thurman Munson and Duffy Der in a home-run hitting contest.
An admitted killer who provided the first major break in the murder of Joseph A. Yablonski 'and members of his family told today how he and two other men stalked their prey.

Reacting to evidence in the investigation of the crash of a DC-10 near Paris on March 3, the Federal Aviation Administration said yesterday that all future design changes "to correct an unsafe condition" would be dealt with by compulsory decrees.
The yields on three-month United States Treasury bills rose slightly and the yields on six-month bills fell slightly in the Government's weekly competitve sale Monday of these short-term securities.
"O.K.," Renee Kelvin said, facing her students from a corner of the classroom, at Eastern District High School ih Brooklyn, "what are some symptoms of measles?"
The Manufacturers Hanover Corporation expects this year's first quarter to be the best quarter in its history, Gabriel Hauge, chairman, told shareholders at the annual meeting yesterday.
The case of John C. Doyle chairman of the executive committee of Canadian Javelin Ltd., has been postponed to Aug. 1.

Lieut Gen. David Elazar resigned tonight as Israel's chief of staff shortly after an official commission investigating Israeli setbacks at the start of the October war recommended that he and other senior army officers be removed.
Two persons were burned to death last night in a two-car collision on the upper roadway of the Bruckner Expressway near Longwood Avenue in the South Bronx, the police reported.

House Judiciary Committee prepared today to issue a new request to the White House for evidence for its impeachment inquiry amid indications that President Nixon would comply with an earlier demand for Watergate tape recordings.

Chancellor Willy Brandt delivered a sharp warning today to the left-wing radicals in his Social Democratic party. in the wake of the three defeats that the party suffered last month in state and local elections.
Charles Green Shaw, whose abstract and semiabstract paintings have been widely exhibited, died yesterday at his home, 340 East 57th Street. His age was 81.
The Export-Import Bank rejected today an appeal from a key Senator to suspend further export credits to. the Soviet Union pending Congressional resolution of the whole controversial issue.

Frank S. Hogan, the shy, courteous lawyer who became a legend in 32 years as Manhattan's District Attorney, died yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital. Mr. Hogan was 72 years old and lived at 404 Riverside Drive.

Thirtyfour French 19th-century and 20th-century paintings and drawings, owned by Antonio Santamarina of Argentina were auctioned here tonight for a total of [Pound]1,973;000 ($4,725,000);
The American Automobile Association said today that the availability of gasoline at servIce stations throughout the nation was continuing to improve.

The fastest of the speeding Bullets was on target last night. Kevin Porter hit on a jump shot from 17 feet, he scored on a one-hander from the top of the key and registered points on fallaway Jumpers and drives.

At a hearing held by the Environmental Protection Agency here yesterday, E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc. made the sharpest challenge so far to the Federal Government's attempt to control the dumping of waste in the ocean.
Voters in yesterday's municipal elections passed narrowly a proposal reducing the penalty for the use and sale of marijuana within the city to a $5 fine.

Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer, Denis Healey, faced what he rightly called an "appallingly difficult" task in' drawing up the new Labor Government's first budget. Inflation is grave; consumer prices are climbing at an annual rate of 13 per cent. Britain's economic growth record remains the worst in Europe, with industry hesitant to invest-and short of investible capital.

The Justice Department's finding that the composition of a number of legislative districts in Brooklyn and Manhattan violates the Voting Rights Act of 1970 should surprise no one. It leaves the State Legislature with the obligation to do what it should have done long ago without Federal prodding; that is, to redraw outrageously gerrymandered district lines to provide the kind of racial equality envisaged under the law.

The Cost of Living Council today exempted wages paid to employes of the newspaper industry from Phase 4 controls. The action follows the removal two weeks ago of price controls on newspapers, as well as wage and price controls on the rest of the communications media.
Georges Jean Raymond Pompidou, the 18th President of the modem French Republic, died tonight at the age of 62.
Msgr. Francis X. Brochart, pastor emeritus of Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church in East Glendale, Queens, died on Saturday at Ozanam Hall, Bayside, Queens. His age was 87.

The Columbia Broadcasting System's top-rated "Sonny and Cher" television variety program has been canceled and will not be on the network next fall, Fred Silverman, C.B.S.'s programing chief, said yesterday.

The nation's unemployment rate took a slight dip in March, dropping from 5.2 per cent of the labor force to 5.1, the Labor Department reported today. The rate thus held essentially steady for the third consecutive month, after rising in the late fall and early winter.

Sales of metals in powder form topped $350-million in 1973--up 8.5 per cent from 1972--and setting a record, the Metal Powder Industries Federation reported yesterday. In the past seven years, sales have risen by more than 50 per cent and the industry sees more expansion coming.

Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn said today that the Soviet Union "lives under the rule of serfdom." The Russian author, who was deported seven weeks ago and is living in Zurich, made the accusation in a 300-word statement telephoned to the British Broadcasting Corporation.

France will vote on May 5 for a President to succeed Georges Pompidou. The date was set at a meeting of the Cabinet. More than 40 chiefs of state or government, including President Nixon, will attend a requiem mass for Mr. Pompidou in the Cathedral of Notre Dame in Paris today.

The Paris Brokers Association said today it had decided to suspend operations by its members on the Paris Bourse, effective Monday. It said in a communique that unions representing bourse clerks have consistently failed to inform the association of their intentions.

A Superior Court judge granted today a delay in the opening of John D. Ehrlichman's perjury trial. After a 10-minute court appearance by Mr. Ehrlichman, Judge Gordon Ringer moved the start from April 15 to May 20.

Donald F. Cawley, who resigned as Police Commissioner of New York City as of last Jan. 11, has been named to a senior position at the Chemical Bank. He will be a group vice president in charge of all aspects of security--plus purchasing and communication services. Donald F. Cawley

WASHINGTON, April 5--George M. Steinbrenner 3d, chairman of the American Shipbuilding Company and principal partner in the New York Yankees, was indicted today on 14 felony charges growing from illegal campaign contributions to both Republicans and Democrats.

Baby Laurence, tap dancer who performed with many of the great jazz instrumentalists, died Tuesday in the Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital, where he had been admitted several weeks ago for treatment of cancer. His age was 53.

Dwight L. Chapin, President Nixon's former appointments secretary, was found guilty today on two counts of lying to a Watergate grand jury. And a 55-54 loss to Palisades Park was all that prevented Hopatcong from'reaching the state semifinals.

Seven defending champions see action tomorrow when the first eight of the 30 titles in the national Amateur Athletic Union men's and women's short-course indoor swimming championships will be decided. There were 1,100 entries for the four-day meet.

Despite political differences there is a new monetary entente in the Atlantic world. Evidence shows that interest rates have been falling in Europe while they have been rising in the United States. Helmut Schmidt, West German Finance Minister. Secretary of the Treasury George P. Shultz.

Rebekah Harkness's dream of an peacock-blue dance theater in New York City came to fulfillment last night, when the new theater, named the Harkness, opened its ornate doors to the public. "Ceremonials" being performed last night at the opening of the Harkness Theater
