Judge Lawrence A. Whipple was asked in Federal District Court, today to dismiss Federal taxfraud charges against Joseph M. McCrane, the former New Jersey treasurer, on the ground that Mr. McCrane had been the victim of "an orchestrated indictment publicity.
Testimony before the staff of the Senate Watergate committee alleging that Howard R. Hughes ordered a campaign contribution to Hubert H. Humphrey was made public here today in Federal District Court.

Robert Goldstein, a motion-picture producer and former production chief at Twentieth Century-Fox Studios died of a cerebral hemorrhage, in his home in London yesterday, his family announced here today. He was 70 years old. old.

Bib Marr, a Boston scaffolding contractor, was named president of the New England Patriots yesterday, succeeding Billy Sullivan. Sullivan, the president of the club since it was formed in 1959, will remain with the club as director. Bob Marr at news conference yesterday in Boston.

Robert G. Youngson, a producer, director and writer whose short-subject films won two Oscars and six Academy Award nominations from 1948 to 1957, died Monday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 56 years old and lived at 29 Washington Square West.
(Reument has officially notified Burmah Shell, the largest foreign oil company operating in India, that it wishes to acquire 74 per cent of the company, Government sources said today.
City taxpayers were warned yesterday that there would be no one-day extension for the filing of city returns.

Soviet leader Leonid I. Brezhnev stressed anew to the Nixon Administration the importance Moscow attaches to gaining Congressional approval for lower tariffs and larger credits from the United States. Leonld I. Brezhnev, Soviet party leader, second from left, and Frederick B. Dent, Commerce Secretary, right, during meeting on trade in Moscow yesterday. Mr. Dent was in MOSCOW to open an American exhibition.
A recent article on fish and pollution prompted Toby Lelyveld of Manhattan to write us concerning an English woman's reaction to an item of local food a hundred or more years ago.

The State Commission of Investigation charged yesterday that "by and large" the judiciary in New York City and seven surrounding counties "has failed to fulfill its obligation to properly discipline judges."
Fred Waters, an account executive and a partner in the Shorlane-Benet Company, Inc., an advertising agency, died Sunday at his home, 126 New York Avenue, Freeport, L. I. He was 73 years old.
Dr. William J. Dougherty, Acting State Commissioner of health, said yesterday that 252 new cases of measles--169 more than usual--were reported from last September

A Federal judge in Brooklyn ruled yesterday that diet-thin matzoh crackers, manufactured by the B. Manischewitz company, Inc., were mislabeled because they contained as many calories as regular matzoh.
An Akron doctor and a researcher in physiology have developed a method of growing human skin in a laboratory-a technique that could revolutionize the treatment of burns.

Cesar Cedeno drove in tour runs and Larry Dierker, battling back from arm and shoulder problems, held San Diego to six hits and two runs in seven innings as the Houston Astros defeated the Padres tonight, 9-5.

The leading magazine of the Peronist left wing has been shut down on order of President Juan Domingo Per6n. The weekly magazine, called El Descamisado, or The Shirtless One-a term long used to describe General Peron's working-class followers - was the most widely read and authoritative organ of the President's youthful left-wing followers. It served as a platform for leftwing guerrilla organizations.

When Leonard Hindell, New York Philharmonic bassoonist, decides to give a concert, he gathers around him some worthy colleagues and plays chamber music. Because the bassoon turns up in an uncommon repertory, his programs are fresh and novel.

There wasn't anything artistic about the Boston Celtics' rough-and-tumble, 100-97 victory over the Buffalo Braves in their National Basketball Association first-round playoff tonight. Celtics' Dave Cowens reaching over Braves' Randy Smith for the ball in the first period of the playoff last night in the Boston Garden. In background is Ernie DiGregorio (15).
Foreign oil companies operating in Venezuela earned profits totaling $5.4-billion from 1962 to 1972, the Venezuelan Federation of Public Accountants said today.
Dr. John L. S. Holloman, the new president of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, has sent letters to 54 top corporation officials asking them to submit pro-forma resignations.
Vice President Ford defended tonight the White House decision to continue reviewing tapes and other materials requested by the House Judiciary Committee.
In the promised land of economics it would not be the lion and the lamb that exist side by side but full employment and stable prices.

MINNEAPOLIS-- Taped to the wall of a service elevator in the new 51-story IDS Center here is a postcard view of the Foshay Tower, the eccentric nineteentwenties obelisk Central glass-roofed court is focus for IDS Center's buildings. The store-lined area, accessible from the street, a ceiling of glass and street pyramids. The new 51-story IDS Center looms over Foshay Tower, right, which had been Minneapolis's tallest building.
The World Football League lost the cover of Sports Illustrated magazine to Henry Aaron this week, but landed another heavy hitter for the 1975 season, Calvin Hill of the Dallas Cowboys.

W. A. Boyle, former president of the United Mine Workers of America, took the witness stand in his own defense today and denied all charges that he had plotted the murder of Joseph A. Yablonski, a reformist rival for his $50,000-a-year union post. W. A. Boyle on his way to testify in Media, Pa.

The Attorney General's list of subversive organizations is, like all punitive rosters drawn up by fearful governments, a shameful page in the nation's annals. An Attorney General with the good sense to scrap that useless and vindictive document need offer no explanation or apology.

A touch of intestinal virus may have an important bearing on the Knicks' attempt to wrap up their opening round National Basketball Association playoff series against the Capital bullets tomorrow night at Capital Centre.
The planet Jupiter's great red spot is apparently a towering mass of clouds. The orange blemish on the planet's visible surface has intrigued astronomers for centuries.

If it weren't for that exclusive five-year $1-million contract with Magnavox, there would probably be a lot of advertisers lined up on Henry Aaron's doorstep with hopes of using the new natinnal hero.

The floating Japanese. yen has been defying most of the accepted laws of economics for the last month or more. The conventional wisdom says that a floating currency tends to weaken when a nation runs a persistent deficit in its balance of payments. Takeo Fukuda, Finance Minister of Japan.

A bill has bobbed up in the State Legislature calling for pay increases of $12,000 a year for the three lifetime members of the New York City Board of Water Supply. Although there was some early mystery about the bill's sponsorship, there is no mystery about what ought to be done with the measure.

A Federal district judge in Newark dismissed yesterday a $500-million defamation suit brought by four health-food stores. The judge upheld the right of the Food and Drug Administration to warn the public about possibly dangerous developments in the field of nutrition.
Breaking something of a drought, corporate bond prices showed modest improvement yesterday. Tax-exempt obligations were mostly steady.

Speculation on the possibility of another revaluation of the West German mark preoccupied many of the commodity experts gathered here today for the opening of the United Nations General Assembly's special session on the world crisis in raw materials.

The International Paper Company told 500 stockholders at its annual meeting at the Essex House yesterday that profits climbed 39 per cent to a record $41.2-million, or 93 cents a share. Sales rose 18 per cent to $650.6-million.
Frank Mahovlich thinks "the goalies will decide the issue" in the Rangers-Canadiens first-round series, which opens tomorrow in the Montreal Forum. (Televised on Channel 11 in New York at 9:05 P.M.).

Edward G. Harnes was named yesterday as chairman and chief executive officer of' the Procter Gamble Company, effective May 1 He succeeds Howard Morgens, who will become chairman of the executive committee.

A penny increase in the sales tax paid in the city to 8 cents a dollar, a half -billion dollar borrowing repaid by an increase in the stock transfer tax and the dismissal of at least 2,000 city employes are in the budgetbalancing package that the city is likely to urge upon Albany at a crucial summit meeting tomorrow.

The Asiatic lion was nominated today to a select list-the state's list of endangered species. The Assembly voted unanimously, after a debate punctuated by jeers and laughter, to add the animal to the list, a move that is subject to the approval of the Senate and Governor Wilson.

The Assembly voted sharper restrictions today on the cutoff of gas and electric service by the state's utilities during the cold-weather months, prohibiting it entirely on Friday, Saturday, Sunday and holidays.

As he strolled casually out on the stage, his head cocked to one side and his tanned features lit by the familiar, quizzical sliver of a smile, the audience that filled Carnegie Hall rose to greet him with a roaring cheer. 01' Blue Eyes was back.

The Special State Prosecutor, Maurice H. Nadjari, said yesterday that his office would receive "all documents and evidence" on the disappearance of 200 methadone tablets from the city prison hospital on Rikers Island.

The only major world bridge title now held by American players will be at stake next month in the Canary Islands when Mary Jane Farell of Los Angeles and Marilyn Johnson of Houston defend their women's pair laurels. They will face strong opposition from Europe, South Africa and the United States.
The House Ways and Means Committee finished its basic work today on a petroleum fax reform bill after voting to keep a depletion allowance of 22 per cent for most natural gas.
One defense lawyer asked the judge to disqualify himself and another accused the chief prosecutor of lying in a stormy day-long hearing yesterday at the race-fixing trial of 13 harness drivers.

Yogi Berra sat in his office in the Mets' clubhouse in Shea. Stadium yesterday, pondering what he might do with his unexpected day off. "I got a haircut and picked up a couple of suits yesterday [Monday]," the manager said, "today I might go out to the club and play cards. It's a good day for it." A group of students yelling derisive slogans, blowing whistles and banging chairs were threatened with arrest yesterday at New York University before sufficient quiet Could be obtained to permit Dr. William B. Shockley to expound his controversial views about intelligence and race.

New Canadian regulations on meet and livestock imports have halted, at least temporarilly, trade with the United States that has been worth more than %150--million a year to the American export industry.

The General Electric Company this year had its best first quarter ever, Reginald H. Jones, chairman, reported yesterday. Mr. Jones placed sales at a record high of $2.0 billion, up 14 per cent over the $2.5-billion of a year ago. Net income rose by 7 per cent to the new high of $122.3-million, or 67 cents a share, from $114.4-million, or 63 cents a share, in the three months ended March 31, 1973.

The International Telephone and Telephone and Telegraph Corporation flied suit yesterday in Federal District Court in Wilmington, Del., to overturn an Internal Revenue Service revocation of its 1969 tax rulings that facilitated the I. T. T. acquisition of the Hartford Fire Insurance Company.

Frank Mahovlich thinks "the goalies will decide the issue" in the Rangers-Canadiens first-round series, which opens tomorrow in the Montreal Forum. (Televised on Channel 11 in New York at 9:05 P.M.).
Interior Department officials have announced acceptance of 91 offshore oil lease bids totaling $2.092-billion. Twenty-three other bids totaling $82.5-million, were rejected as too low.
Stocks edged lower yesterday in an indecisive day on the American Stock Exchange. The trading pace picked up to 1,928,255 shares from the 1,858,000 shares traded on Monday.

Senator James L. Buckley, Conservative - Republican of New York, said today that President Nixon should not go to Moscow while impeachment proceedings were pending. The Presidential visit is planned in June.

At 11 A.M. today, the bondmarket men in Wall Street are apt to cast their eyes in the direction of the Municipal Bullding, a few blocks away. That is the deadline for Controller Harrison J. Goldin, in Room 530, to receive sealed bids on the sale of $436.6 million in city bonds-the biggest municipal financing ever.

" You don't have any trouble getting excited about this one," Arnold Palmer told The Associated Press in Augusta, Ga. "It's the Masters, isn't it?" Failing to make the cut in the Greater Greensboro open last week, Arnold showed up earlier than expected at the Augusta National Club, that green garden in the pines where the Palmer Era of golf began.

David Rockefeller opened a fund-raising appeal last night for International House, the twin-towered residence on Riverside Drive his father built to house graduate students from all nations, in the hopes of raising $7.5 million to operate the house and its programs.
Deputy Inspector Gertrude Schimmel, the highest-ranking woman in the Police Department, will be named commanding officer of the department's Public Information Division today.
Winfield W. Riefler, former assistant to the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board at his retirement in 1959, died Friday in Sarasota, Fla., where he was living. He was 77 years old.

The White House told the House Judiciary Committee tonight that it needed more time to decide how to respond to the committee's request for tape recordings of 42 Presidential conversations relating to Watergate.

Dr. William J. Ronan, the chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, is expected to be nominated Thursday as chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. Dr. William J. Ronan

Effective interest rates on conventional home mortgage loans closed in March were mixed, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported today. The effective rate on the purchase of newly built homes climbed 2 basis points-hundredths of a percentage pointto 8.64 per cent.

Nine former employes or the Grumman Aerospace Corporation and seven officers of companies that did work for Grumman have pleaded guilty to an elaborate kickback scheme in the awarding of millions of dollars worth of Navy subcontracts, the Acting United States Attorney in Brooklyn announced yesterday.

Dr. Alfred Stillman 2d, retired chief of surgery at Roosevelt Hospital-where he had first interned in 19?7--died there on Monday. He was 93 years old and lived at 610 Park Avenue.

Jerry Quarry will meet Joe Alexander: in a 10-round heavyweight bout on May 8 at the Nassau Coliseum in Uniondale, L. I. It will be the first of six proposed cards at the Coliseum this year to be staged by Top Rank Coliseum, Inc.

Donald C. Alexander, the Commissioner of Internal Revenue has asked that the special Watergate prosecutor's office initiate into a possible criminal conspiracy, stemming from President Nixon's claim of a $576,000 tax deduction for his Vice-Presidential papers, well placed sources said today. Donald C. Alexander

The murder trial of W.A. Boyle, former president of the United Mine Workers of America, neared its conclusion today with a long, angry confrontation before the jury by the prosecution and defense lawyers.
An Essex County Court judge, William Harth, granted a rent abatement today of between 60 and 80 per cent to tenants in the Columbus Homes public housing project.
Women under age 40 run a far higher than average risk of developing breast cancer if their mothers and-or sisters had the disease, a new study reports, according to The, Associated Press.

When people talk about Aaron here, they mean Tommy, not Henry. Tommy Aaron is the defending champion in the Masters tournament that starts tomorrow at the Augusta National Golf Club with its green grass, green matchbooks, green paper cups, green pencils and green paint. The winner is presented with a green blazer that is supposed to be worn only in the clubhouse or on the grounds.

President Nixon campaigned today for a Republican Congressional candidate-and for himself-in the small crossroads towns of rural Michigan. At Bad Axe, Mich., a sea of faces greeted President Nixon, left center foreground, and James M. Sparling Jr., to left, as they made their way to a speaking stand. Mr. Nixon hailed Mr. Sparling as candidate for a seat in the House.

Orange and Rockland Utilities, Inc.'s, electric sales volume has decreased by 3 per cent in each month from November through March, Charles H. Tenney II, chairman, told about 200 stockholders at the annual meeting in company headquarters here today.

The American Petroleum Institute reported today that total estimated gasoline production, aviation and motor, for the latest week amounted to 6,035,000 barrels a day, compared with 6,110,000 barrels a day in the previous week and 6,240,000 barrels a day a year ago.
Heavy selling continued to dominate silver and other metals markets yesterday. On the Commodity Exchange most silver futures once more declined the daily limit of 20 cents an ounce.

Bertram A. Powers, president, and other leaders of Typographical Union No. 6 were directed to show cause in State Supreme Court today why they should not be found in contempt for holding a union meeting at The New York Times during working hours yesterday.

The Central Vermont Public Service Corporation reported yesterday its 1973 earnings fell to $432,000, or 2 cents a share, from $4.2 million, or $1.85 a share, in 1972. However, revenues rose to $40.2-million from $37.2-million a year earlier.

Two high-ranking officials of the staff of the central Board of Education were named yesterday by Samuel Polatnick, executive director of the Office of High Schools, to investigate an incident in which a teacher at James Monroe High School in the Bronx exhibited a film-strip depicting sexual intercourse and oral-genital sex.

Governor Byrne named David J. Bardin, a New York City-born lawyer and now an environmental consultant to the Israeli Government, as New Jersey Commissioner of Environmental Protection. Mr. Bardin was proposed by Attorney General William F. Hyland of New Jersey, who became familiar with the appointee's work on the Federal Power Commission. The Occidental 'Petroleum Corporation, the 11th largest oil company in the nation, disclosed yesterday that it made a profit of $46.9-million in January and February, up from $3.4-million in the year-earlier period. It was the first indication of oil-company profits this year.

MOSCOW - No politically active person can be indifferent, in a positive or negative sense to the joint determination, proclaimed by Moscow and Washington two years ago, to pursue a course of peaceful coexistence and expanding cooperation in solving urgent international problems.

Prime Minister Gough Whitlain announced plans today to hold a national, election for both houses' of Parliament. The proposal comes less than halfway through the term df Mr. Whitlam's Labor party Government, which was elected to office in December, 1972, for three years.

Benjamin Levy, who served in the New York Fire Department from 1907 until his retirement in 1954, died in Coney Island Hospital bn Tuesday evening. He was 89 years old and lived at 1900 Quentin.Road, Brooklyn.

After almost eight years on the road leading his big band, Buddy Rich has decided to come in out of the cold. He has opened his own club, Buddy's Place, on Second Avenue at East 64th Street. It's a pleasant, warmly lit room that seats 200, and. the sextet Mr. Rich has settled down with, man for man and instrument by instrument, reflects the same electrifying drive that is characteristic of his drumming.

Five American records fell tonight in the Amateur Athletic Union short course swimming championships, with Shirley Babashoff coming up with the most sensational performance. Wendy Cook of the Canadian Dolphins after setting an American record in the women's 200-yard- backstroke in A.A.U. meet at Dallas last night.

Premier Golda Meir of Israel announced her resignation, bringing down her month-old coalition Government and setting the stage for new elections in the next several months. Mrs. Meir said she had found it impossible to continue because of deep divisions within her Labor party over the issue of assigning responsibility for Israel's military shortcomings at the beginning of the October war.

Bertram A. Powers, president, and other leaders of Typographical Union No. 6 were directed to show cause in State Supreme Court today why they should not be found in contempt for holding a union meeting at The New York Times during working hours yesterday.

LYNDHURST, April 10-Hal Daiker lined up his bowling ball and rolled it down 'the lane. Then he put his head down and listened for the pins to drop. "You got six, Hal," said Mike Michaels, one of the spotters for the Light Brigade's league. Hal, like the other league members, is blind and must listen for the bowl against the pins.

Premier Golda Meir announced her resignation tonight, bringing down her month-old coalition Government and making new national elections likely in the next several months. Premier Golda Meir, in Jerusalem, asked cameramen to stop taking pictures as she left after yesterday's meeting. Defense Minister Moshe Dayan leaving the meeting in Jerusalem at which Premier GoldaMeir said that she would resign. Cabinet was a month old.

A year ago this week, Teng Hsiao-ping managed to scramble off what Trotsky and Communists after him have called the "dust bin of history." Teng Hsiao-ping, right, and Chiao Kuan-hua at opening of the special General Assembly on Monday at the U.N.
The Federal energy chief, William E. Simon, said today that the nation's gasoline supply was near normal and predicted that Americans would be able to take their usual summer vacation trips.
Gunmen burst into a primary school near the border of the Irish Republic during classes today and killed the Protestant principal, the police said.
In President Nixon's news summary this morning, the story causing dismay and outrage is a summary of an article in The New Republic entitled "Ford's Future," by John Osborne.

Saudi Arabia, which has been confident that the United States will bring about a settlement in the' Middle East, is now increasingly concerned that the peace effort might be weakened if President Nixon is impeached.

France's second biggest labor union has announced its support for the single candidate of the Left for the Presidency, Frangois Mitterrand. This new development on the French political scene is one that perhaps most worries the already frazzled government coalition.

DETROIT, April 10 (AP)-A United States District Court jury has acquitted two reputed Mafia figures, Anthony and Vito Giacalone, on five counts of income-tax evasion. The decision came yesterday after two hours of deliberations.

Miller, executive director of the layers' Association, called today upon Ray Kroc, new owner of the San Diego Padres, to apologize to his players for publicly berating them last night during their 9-5 loss to the Houston Astros.
Two harness-racing drivers the Government says cashed superfecta checks in a Queens bank offered yesterday to take polygraph tests to dispute the charge.

Gregg Sheppard scored a second-period goal and Gilles Gilbert made it stand up tonight as the Boston Bruins defeated the Toronto Maple Leafs, 1-0, in the opening game of their Stanley Cup playoff quarterfinals.

On the 10th anniversary of the Mets' arrival at Shea Stadium, Ed Kranepool reflected yesterday on the disaster of 1964. "We weren't looking forward much to opening day then," he said, "Now we've got a good cub, But in '64 we weren't going anywhere."

Tommy John and Mike Marshall checked the Atlanta Braves on four hits tonight, pacing the Los Angeles Dodgers to a 4-0 victory. Henry Aaron returned to the Atlanta line-up after a day's rest but went hitless in four times at bat.

Algeria called on Arab countries today to set up a common currency based on the average price of a barrel of oil to avoid any further depreciation in the value of oil caused by world monetary instability. In a study dealing with Arab countries and world monetary problems, the Algerian Development Bank said there is "urgency in defining a currency which would be the expression of the price of oil."

Lorence A. Silverberg, chairman and president of the Kenton Corporation, is expected to become president and chief executive officer of Interstate Stores, Inc., when its pending purchases of more than 1,100 McCrory stores is completed.
" Stand by" read the New York Stock Exchange tape as it flashed over the exchange floor and into the 2,750 firms from Wall Street to Hong Kong yesterday. "Resumption of, service is expected shortly."

The New York Rangers set off on the right skate tonight as they defeated the Montreal Canadiens, 4.1, in the first game of their opening series toward the Stanley Cup championship of the National Hockey Leaue. Rangers' Pete Stemkowski and Canadiens' Guy Lapointe (5) dropping their gloves as they prepared to fight in first period in Montreal. Both went to penalty box.

Mrs. Mildred Taylor Murphy. wife of Robert D. Murphy, the former Under Secretary of State and career diplomat, died Tuesday of a stroke at her home, 1701 Kalmia Road, Washington. She was 83 years old. Her husband is now board chairman of Corning International.

The qualities that we count on conservatism to bring to our moral and political life are restraint, proportion, respect for tradition arid institutions, above all a belief in individual responsibility.

The International Business Machines Corporation reported yesterday records for first-quarter gross and net income. The world's largest computer maker showed a rise of 26.8 per cent in its net and 22.5 per cent in its gross income from sales, services and rentals.
Mayor Beame criticized yesterday what he called a "state plan to confiscate the city's water system" and said he would express his opposition to Governor Wilson at their meeting today in Albany.

Rome, April 10--The Vatican, in an unusual procedure, today corrected a remark by Pope Paul VI on the future of Jerusalem. The new wording seemed to indicate a hardened policy on the politically sensitive issue.

The city borrowed a record $436.6-million yesterday at an interest rate, 6:18 per cent, that cast a pall over the Controller's office. The city Will have to pay $259.4-million Over the next 40 years for the use of the money.

Henry Topper,. a business representative and former executive board member of Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, died Tuesday at his home, 1797 East Second Street, Brooklyn. He was 74 years old.

F. Dewey Everett, who retired as an investment banker in 1973, died at his home, 179 East. 70th Street, on Tuesday. He was 85 years old. Mr. Everett joined Hornblower Weeks, now Hornblower Weeks-Hemphill Noyes, in 1919. He was a governor of the'New York Stock Exchange in 1937-38, a governor of the Investment Bankers Association in 1938-41 and a member of the Association of Stock Exchange Firms 1945-51.

The troopreduction talks between the North, Atlantic Treaty Organization and the Warsaw Pact have recessed with a spokesman reaffirming NATO's proposal for a two-phase reduction of ground forces in Central Europe.

A proposal for plush gambling casinos as a means of revitalizing Times Square will be pressed upon city and state legislators by the Broadway Association, whose members represent theaters. as well as other businesses.

Two Penn Central railroad workers were arrested today and charged with intercepting the $50,000 ransom paid on March 7 by Michael Calzadilla to free his 8 year-old son, John, from kidnappers. Former Controller Beame apparently thinks New Yorkers have short memories.

Pressure within the Byrne administration for the resignation of Secretary of State J. Edward Crabiel increased today following official confirmation that Mr. Crabiel had misled the public when he denied invoking the fifth Amendment before a state grand jury here last month.

Soviet trade with the capitalist world, spurred by the Kremlin's intensive technology hunt, jumped more than 40 per cent last year, and for the first time since World War II the West accounted for more than 25 per cent of the Soviet Union's global commerce.

Bernard Cornfeld, deposed head of the International Overseas Services mutual funds empire, said tonight he had information indicating that Robert L. Vesco, the fugitive financier, met President Nixon secretly in Salzburg, Austria, two years ago.
The Connecticut General Assembly voted today to cut the state sales tax by half a percentage point and approved a record, election-year budget of $1.38billion.

Governor Wilson has told the head of the Federal Environmental Protection Agency that several new Federal actions, including granting of $200-million in aid for mass transit, were needed before the Federal air-quality standards for transportation could be implemented in New York City.

Israel's Ambassador to the United States said today that it was "senseless" for Syria to attempt to justify the continuing shelling in the Golan Heights with "the assertion that Israel is establishing settlements in that area."

Activity on the exchange was halted from 11:09 A.M. to 11:35 A.M. because of a malfunction involving the data equipment that feeds information to the ticker tapes.

The second is for the Company's share of a $150-million floating complex to produce ammonia and urea. It will be in Indonesia.

The Bank of England cuits minimum lending rate today for the second time in seven days, but the move had little effect on international sterling dealings.

The Virginia, Squires, whom the New York Nets eliminated in five games in their American Basketball Association semifinal series, were just a warmup for what the Nets can expect next.

A Michigan newspaper publisher has disclosed that he made an offer early this month to buy The Washington StarNews. John McGoff, president of the Panax Corporation, which owns 51 daily and weekly newspapers, said the proposal, made April 4, was his personally and was not on behalf of Panax.

A Senate Commerce Committhe vote on the nomination of the Rev. Luther Holcomb' for a Democratic seat on the Federal Communications Commission has been held up until after the Easter recess, partly because of questions raised concerning his political affiliation, according to Senate sources.

Rabbi Menachem M. Schneerson, spiritual leader of the Lubavitcher Movement - the worldwide body of Hasidic Jews-was honored by his followers yesterday on his 72d birthday with gifts from installations of the movement the country over.

Satisfaction over Israel's political disarray was mingled with expressions of fear that the move toward a negotiated settlement will be hopelessly delayed and that hard-liners may come to power in Israel.

Pessmism about personal finances and the business outlook in the first quarter of this year resulted in the sharpest erosion in consumer attitudes in more than 25 years, according to the University of Michigan's Institute for Social Research.

Henry Pearlman, a collector of impressionist and postimpressionist art whose private collection has been widely exhibited, died Wednesday at Beth Israel Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived at 993 Park Avenue.

Premier Golda Meir warned the Government of Lebanon today that Israel would hold it responsible for the Arab terrorist attack in northern Israel this morning in which 18 Isarelis were killed. The nation's money supply climbed steeply in the week ended April 3, the Federal Reserve System reported yesterday. The money supply - most checking accounts at banks plus currency in the hands of the public-increased by $1.7billion after a five-week period of no growth.

Hank Aaron drilled his 716th career home run tonight in the seventh inning, snapping a tie and helping the Atlanta Braves to a 6-4 triumph over the Los Angeles Dodgers.

A. Boyle, the deposed president of the United Mine Workers of America, was found guilty tonight of three charges of firstdegree murder in ordering the "assassination" of Joseph A. Yablonski, a reformist election rival in the union. W. A. Boyle in Media, Pa., after verdict yesterday.

East Germany scored four goals in the second period and beat Poland, 5-3, in the world hockey championships. Poland had a 3-1 lead after the first period. But midway through the second, Reinhard Karger and Bernd Karenbauer scored within two minutes of each other for East Germany. Karger then put East Germany ahead, 4-3, and Ruediger Noack added the other score with just two seconds to go in the period.

A 56-year-old male patient jumped to his death yesterday at Triboro Hospital, at Parsons Boulevard and Goethals Avenue in Jamaica, Queens. The police identified him as Wyatte Robinson of 117-46 Springfield Boulevard, Queens Village, an asthma sufferer who was admitted on Tuesday.

The prime rate -- the interest that banks charge on loans to corporations they regard as the most credit worthy -- has moved up to 10 percent, an increase of 0.5 per cent in less than two weeks.

Outside the windows, orange trees are blanketed in late afternoon mist, horses whip flies with their tails, and ten cats and four dogs perform arabesques on the lawn.

Twelve years ago Rachel Carson jolted the nation with a chilling indictment of the indiscriminate use of chemicals to control insects, weeds and fungi. A scientist with impeccable credentials, as well as a gifted writer, Miss Carson warned in her best-selling "Silent Spring" that pesticides were killing birds by the millions and that the poisoning of the environment might be irreversible.

While she waited announcements were made over the loudspeaker system advising clients who wanted to report a lost or stolen check to move to another line. The announcements were all made in English.

In recent seasons, the Youth Symphony Orchestra of New York seemed a model student orchestra. Douglas, that on occasion, Douglas, while listening to oral arguments along with his britren, would also be drafting-a section of a book on his far-flung travels. Suddenly, looking up from his--scrivening, Douglas would ask the key question in the case.

JERUSALEM--In her speech announcing her resignation to the Israeli Parliament, Premier Golda Meir concluded with a message for the Israeli people: "I call on the nation to live and act, not as a defeated community, but as a nation and state with a secure future."

UNDER MARTIAL LAW--The Philippine Republic is under martial law, but that is now hindrance to tourism. In fact, the authorities take special pains to protect tourists. Mugging, or merely cheating, a tourist is considered a serious offense, subject to trial a serious offense, subject to trial and punishment by military tribunal rather than the civil courts.

Paterson is a city of paradox. Its history dates to postRevolutionary War America, when Alexander Hamilton proposed its creation as the country's ultimate industrial microcosm, and it has a past that includes the Wright Brothers, the Colt revolver and the submarine, which was invented in Paterson and "shaken down" beneath the waters of the Passaic River.

At least five Senators and more than fifty Representatives are engaged in trying to undo a grossly unjust provision of the Social Security law. This is the section of the law that limits the amount of money it is permissible to earn while still collecting Social Security. The law puts no limitation whatever on a recipient's unearned income.

Mr. Giddings was serving two to three years at Leesburg State Prison for receiving stolen goods. He had been allowed out of Leesburg under armed guard to attend the funeral of his brother, David, 29, and apparently "walked off" from the guard.

Jacques Esterel, the French couturier and musical composer, died today at the age of 56, from a blood clot in the brain, a spokesman for his fashion house said.

The Toronto Toros, led by Tom Simpson's two firstperiod goals, gained the World Hockey Association semifinal playoffs tonight with a 4.1 victory over the Cleveland Crusaders.
Police Commissioner Michael J. Codd of New York said yesterday he was "very gratified" with the results of a Federal study showing that the city had the lowest crime rate of 13 large cities surveyed.

Production of steel last week totaled 2,904,000 tons, the American Iron and Steel Insti, tute reported yesterday. This was a decline of 0.3 per cent from the 2,914,000 tons poured the week before, and caused the production index to drop to 119.0, from 119.4 during the week ended April 6.

Voluntary hospitals in the state, saying they expect a deficit of $60-million this year in their emergency-room and outpatient departments, have started a drive for passage of a bill in Albany that would require Blue Cross, and possibly Medicaid, to pay a prorated share of the losses.

Syria and Israel remain far, apart in their pro*posals for separating their forces in the Golan Heights, but well-placed diplomats said today that Secretary of State Kissinger believes he can narrow the gap on his coming Middle East trip.
Three of the nation's leading banking concerns - including the BankAmerica Corporation, the world's largest privately owned banking concern - reported yesterday higher profits for the first quarter.

The American Cyanamid Company, a diversified producer of chemicals, pharmaceuticals, and construction prodcuts, reported yesterday that its first-quarter results were the best ever for any three-month period.

A marvelously indigenous short movie combining photographs of underprivileged Negro life in the Depressionera Deep South, reminiscences by blues singer and blues songs is the highlight of the new program at the Whitney Museum of American Art.

Mrs. Ruth Taylor McDowell, A an early graduate of the Juilliard School and the wife of James H. McDowell, retired president of Central Stations Signal Inc., died Sunday in Northern Westchester Hospital, Mount Kisco, N. Y. She was 79 years old and lived in'Katonah, N. Y., and in Delray Beach, Fla.

M. William Adelson, a lawyer, died here last night at the age of 62. Mr. Adelson, a Democrat, was the principal adviser on patronage and other political matters so Theodore R. McKeldin, a Republican who served two terms as Governor and two terms as mayor of Baltimore.

An annual grant from the Shubert Foundation to the Yale School of Drama was cut from $30,000 to $10,000 this year after Irving Goldman, Shubert's president and owner of a paint company, complained that Yale was not buying paint from his company, according to the dean and an instructor at the school.

The Supreme Court took the following actions today: CRIMINAL LAW Agreed to review a decision that a defendant could not be convicted of conspiring to assault a Federal officer unless he knew beforehand that the victim was such an officer. (No. 73-1123, United States v. Feola.)
The Cost of Living Council removed today the last controls over food retailers and wholesalers, the largest segment of the economy that had still been subject to price and wage restraints.

The three women members of the group calling itself the Symbionese Liberation Army who are wanted for the robbery of a San Francisco bank today have a history of ties to one another and to earlier S.L.A. activities.
Christian Fouchet, one of the four Gaullist candidates for the Presidency of France, pulled out of the race today and threw his support behind the official Gaullist nominee, Jacques Chaban-Delmas.
The Canton Trade Fair opened in a huge new glass-add-concrete exhibition center today with a barrage of firecrackers, slogans and revolutionary songs to welcome foreign buyers.

Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet party leader, journeyed to Poland today for an important East European meeting that is expected to press for an EastWest summit gathering in Helsinki soon to conclude the European security conference.
Contract talks between the printers and the city's three major daily newspapers were recessed indefinitely yesterday after the two sides reached a new impasse.

The news about education today is largely confined to questions of money. The high cost to the taxpayer, skyrocketing college tuition, university budget deficits and fund-raising campaigns dominate the greatly reduced attention that education commands in the news--and in public discussion.

Fairleigh Dickinson University announced yesterday that Dr. Jerome M. Pollack had been elected the third president of the university by the board of trustees at their regular monthly meeting last Wednesday.

Governor Wilson submitted his own campaign reform proposal this evening. It differs basically from the measure already passed by the Assembly in that its enforcement would be placed in the hands of one of the Governor's cabinet officers.

Mrs. Eugene ward Root Riley, widow of Col. James Wilson Riley, who had been a partner of the New York brokerage firm of Vilas and Hickey and president of the Southern Society of New York, died today at her home here. She was 84 years old.
Maurice H. Nadjari, the special state prosecutor, charged last night that proposals to establish a commission on judicial conduct were "attempts to diminish the effectiveness of my office."
Both candidates campaigned furiously today in the closing hours of a special Con. gressional election that Democrats and Republicans alike described as a referendum on President Nixon.

The Urls Buildings Corporation said yesterday it had completed disposition of its interest in a Rockland County, N.Y., office complex to "a bank construction lender in lieu of foreclosure." It did not name the lender.

The J. C. Penney Company and the T. Eaton Company, Ltd., Canada's largest general-merchandise retailer, have announced a joint study of retailing opportunities in Canada. Their objective is an eventual joint retailing effort in that country.

Four residents of San Francisco filed suit in United States District Court here today alleging that the city's contract with the Pacific Gas and Electric Company for power distribution violated a 1913 Federal law.

Thousands of employees and supporters of antipoverty programs here marched and held a rally yesterday to demand Federal, state and city support for Congressional action to extend the life of the Office of Economic Opportunity beyond its June 30 deadline.

William S. Leahy, an assistant district attorney in Queens, died yesterday in North Shore Hospital in Manhasset, L. I. He was 41 years old and lived at 35-30 212th Street, Bayside. Wendell Ladner, a reserve, contributed 29 minutes of his usual hectic play tonight and helped the New York Nets score a 99-80 victory over the Kentucky Colonels for a 2-0 lead in the American Basketball Association Eastern final playoff.

The Consumer Product Safety Commission said today that a glue so strong it could temporarily bond hands and fingers together appeared to be safe and would be allowed to remain on the market without further controls.

The Xerox Corporation reported yesterday a 13 per cent increase in first-quarter earnings on a revenue gain of 20 per cent. Profits and revenues both set records for the period. Net income rose to $79.1-million, or $1 a share.
The American Institute of Certifiedd Public Accountants has proposed 10 basis standards for use in developing forecasts of financial results on a recurring basis.

Estep of Dallas was knocked out of the $50,000 Clows tennis- tournament in the first round today by John Yuill an unheralded South African, 4-6, 6-1, 6-2. The tournament is part of. the World Championship Tennis Red group circuit.

Secretary of State Kissinger's stress at the United Nations on the interdependence of developed and developing nations points the way to progress on excruciating resource problems now facing mankind. Confrontation, cartels, production restrictions and steep price rises by other raw material producers on the model of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries can only lead to global inflation and global recession, from which no one would ultimately benefit.
Birth and fertility rates in the United States dropped to their lowest points in history last year, according to a summary report by the National Center for Health Siatistics.

James Irwin's "The Sea Horse," a tender, wistful play about two outwardly abrasive characters, opened last night Off Broadway at the Westside Theater after a limited engagement at the Off Off Broadway Circle Repertory Theater Company.
After several days of reading news stories about the steel industry, securities analysts are assessing the impact on steel-company earnings of two developmentsone recent and the other imminent.
Following are excerpts from the address to the General Assembly today by Secretary of State Kissinger. The text was made available by the United States Mission to the United Nations.
A battle reiaching to the White House is raging between the Council on Environmental Quality and the American Electric Power Company over its energy crisis advertising.

The army of Niger, one of the West African countries hardest hit by drought and famine, seized power today and announced in a broadcast that it had acted because of the nation's "catastrophic situation."

The Rev. Dr. Liston- Pope, dean of the Yale Divinity School from 1949 to 1962, who retired last June as Gilbert L. Stark Professor of Social Ethics, died yesterday in Trondheim, Norway, where he 'had been living. He was 64 years old.
After showing a gain at the opening, stocks on the American Stock Exchange closed sharply lower yesterday in light but slightly increased trading. Prices also fell in the over-the-counter market.
The Federal Bureau of Investigation said tonight that Patricia Hearst participated in a bank robbery here this morning, but it strongly indicated that she may have been acting under duress.

Ivor Bell, a leader of the Provisional wing of the Irish Republican Army, escaped' today fromn a prison camp here. He exchanged places with a prisoner who was due for release and apparently walked out unchallenged.

Exporting has turned out to be much more profitable than the Government thought and the new DISC tax benefit for exporting companies has consequently: cost the Government more revenue than expected, a Treasury: report disclosed today.
Sixteen more food stores, restaurants and other establishments in the city have been cited by the Health Department for uncorrected Health-Code violations found on a second inspection.

An industry-sponsored study w of vinyl chloride has indicated th that when mice are exposed to the amount of the chemical that workers are currently permitted to inhale, the animals develop a rare fatal cancer of the liver that has been found in 12 vinyl chloride workers.

A public hearing on a bill that would establish a new Department of the Public Advocate, a key governmental objective of the Byrne administration, disclosed today some opposition on the Senate committee studying the measure that could delay its consideration by the full State Senate.

The army of Niger, one of the West African countries hardest hit by drought and famine, seized power today and announced in a broadcast that it had acted because of the nation's "catastrophic situation."

SECURITY COUNCIL Meets at 3:30 P.M. on Lebanese complaint against Israel. GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. to hear Nepal, Albania, Ecuador, Madagascar, Iraq, Mongolia, Saudi Arabia, Mauritius, Kuwait, Somalia, Yemen and Guatemala in general debate.

A panel of 12 jurors and four alternates was selected today amid rigid security measures at the opening session of a trial dealing with the murder here last Septemper of a Black Muslim minister, James McGregor Shabazz.

Foreign Minister Masayoshi Ohira said today that he was positive that Japan. could work, out new aviation agreements with China and Taiwan despite a threat by Taiwan to ban Japanese planes from its air space.

The Securities and Exchange Commission charged the American Ship Building Company today with making illegal political contributions and asked a Federal court here to require George M. Steinbrenner 3d, its chairman, to reimburse stockholders by more than $120,000.

President Nixon has received more than $47,000 in unsolicited cash and pledges to help him pay his back income taxes, but he has decided, to pay "every penny" himself, the White House said today.
A 75-year-old man was robbed of his life savings here over the weekend, $6,750 that he was carrying to pay for his and his wife's funerals.

Norman Mailer has sold the film rights to an unfinished novel tracing a family from ancient times to the future to Warner Bros. for a minimum of $250,000.

Secretary of State Kissinger pledged "a major effort" by the United States to assist developing countries, but he also cautioned them against resorting "to the politics of pressures and threats." Making a broad statement of American economic policy before a special United Nations General Assembly meeting, he warned commodity producers against organizing to raise prices along the lines of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting countries.
Thomas B. Congdon Jr., a Yale man who raises bees at his West Side apartment, has been named editor in chief of adult trade books at E. P. Dutton Co.
The Supreme Court refused today to review a decision that upheld President Nixon's right to bomb Cambodia without authorization from Congress. The vote was unanimous, and there was no opinion.
Evening and nighttime collection of garbage has been suspended for the duration of the warm weather, the city's Sanitation Department announced yesterday.

Associated Transport, Inc., said yesterday that it was unable to meet the conditions of a loan agreement with nine banks and that a total of $29million in long-term debt had therefore become current.

The Sun Oil Company said yesterday that it-had raised the price of its residual fuel oil by 5 cents a gallon, f.o.b. its Toledo, Ohio, refinery, and in the Detroit area. The new prices for the fuel, which is mainly for commercial use, range from 30.75 cents to 33.9 cents a gallon.

Times Square is the traditional heart of New York. Its magnetism continues to work in spite of sordid decay. A Nairobi used-car dealer, Joginder Singh, won the 22d East African safari auto rally today for the second time after a broken suspension on a Porsche Carrera eliminated Bjorn Waldegard of Sweden. Singh's unofficial margin was 28 penalty points in the 3,470-mile, five-day event. He drove a Colt Lancer GSR with David Doing of Kenya. Singh also won in 1965.

The Treasury Department has imposed a ban against melting or exporting copper pennies in an attempt to head off hoarding and destruction of pennies for their copper content. Any person convicted of melting or exporting pennies will be subject to a maximum penalty of $10,000 and five years in prison, the Treasury Department said today.

On a recent weekday afternoon, the swimming pool at the Ridgewood Young Men's Christian Association was filled with about 30 boys, all members of the swim team, nearing the end of a two-hour practice. Matt Clark, after completing a series of laps, walked over to the team's coach, Frank McElroy, and after a few words returned to the edge of the pool and sprinted 50 yards in 23.5 seconds, concluding an extensive workout.

Three of the Legislature's four party leaders received Governor Wilson's campaign-reform proposal with criticism today and the fourth hesitated noncommitally as talk of a compromise - began.

The Watergate special prosecutor, Leon Jaworski, asked the United States District Court here today to issue a subpoena directing President Nixon to turn over tape recordings and other documents relating to 64 conversations between Mr. Nixon and four of his former top aides.

The Maryland National Bank, the state's largest bank, has acquired the Eutaw Savings Bank of Baltimore in an emergency move to prevent a failure of the $138.8-million mutual savings bank, the third largest in Maryland.

The Legislature at Albany has a far-reaching opportunity this session to set in motion an orderly reform of the state's banking institutions, aimed at opening up sheltered and often anachronistic preserves to a more healthy competition from which savers and borrowers alike could benefit.

A member of the House Judiciary Committee urged today that House rules be changed to permit television coverage of current business meetings of the committee's impeachment inquiry.

Miss Alice Anne Kleeman and Thomas C. Keller, both of Woodside, Calif., were married yesterday morning. Judge Roy W. Seagraves of the San Mateo Municipal Court in Redwood City, Calif., performed the ceremony in his chambers. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Richard. P. Kleeman of Washington and Mr. and Mrs. Howard H. Keller of Franklin Lakes, N.J.

The search for 4-year-old Brenda Probasco was called off by the police today, six days after the blue-eyed, brownhaired girl disappeared. Her family. and friends, and many others here,- however, have pledged to continue the hunt in Woodbury Creek and the swamps and woods around this sprawling township south of Camden.

Housing starts in March dropped back to their January level after a spurt in February that apparently was a fluke, the Commerce Department reported today. Starts in March were at an annual rate of 1,460,000, about the same as in January but above December's 1,403,000, the lowest level reached last year.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that Donald D. DeFreeze, an escaped convict, was among the band of terrorists it believes may have forced Patricia Hearst to take part in a daring bank robbery here yesterday. New York football's new coaches will know immediately just how good their teams are.

Ben Bradlee, executive editor of The Washington Post, said today that a Nixon Administration bill making it a crime to disclose classified information would emasculate freedom of the press and prevent disclosure of scandals such as Watergate.

An audit of the Shubert Foundation shows a connection between a paint supply company owned by Irving Goldman, president of the foundation, and a painting company that the State Attorney General has charged received "excessive" and "unjustified" fees from the foundation.

The oil crisis is over. But the serious and worsening energy problem remains. The United States like other industrialized countries has been living beyond its means, ecologically speaking. It is not only importing oil, a dwindling resource, but it is also increasing its use of energy in its various forms by roughly 5 per cent a year.

The United Auto Workers and the Bendix Corporation announced agreement today on a new three-year agreement covering 8,500 workers at 10 auto and aero space parts divisions, The settlement averted a strike threatened by the union for 10 A.M. today.

Arthur Ashe, with a 6-4, 6-4 victory over Adriano Panatta of Ifaly, advanced today to the second round of the 40th River Oaks tournament, / a World Championship Tennis event. Bjorn Borg and Rod Laver also won, but Jan Kodes and Ion Tiriac were upset.

Thomas Pynchon's novel "Gravity's Rainbow" and Isaac Bashevis, Singer's collection of short stories "A Crown of Feathers" have been chosen to share the prize for fiction in the 1974 National Book Awards. Formal announcement of the 25th anniversary awards of the National Book Committee is not scheduled until tomorrow,

Abbie Hoffman was declared a fugitive yesterday after he failed to appear for the third time at a court hearing in connection with his indictment on charges of selling cocaine. The police and the Federal Bureau of Investigation have made Mr. Hoffman the object of a nationwide search.

Merrill Lynch Co., holding company for the big brokerage firm, Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., reported yesterday a 33 per cent decline in net earnings for the first quarter of 1974 to $7.1-million, or 22 cents a share, from $10.8million, or 34 cents a year ago. Reflecting the stock market's sluggish volume of the period, revenues also slipped, from $188.9-million in the 1973 first quarter to $181.4-million this year.

Higher oil prices and other economic events since last year have added more than $9-billion to the needs of the less-developed countries for aid and other outside capital. to maintain progress in development in 1974 and 1975, a new analysis by the World Bank concluded today.

George Godfrey, a retired casting director of Columbia Pictures in Hollywood and former general manager of the Orpheum circuit during vaudeville days, died Monday at the Ankara Hotel in Miami Beach, where he lived. He was 88 years old.

C. Shelby Carter, a retired adviser in corporate reorganizations, died Monday at Midtown Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived at the Seville Hotel, Madison Avenue and 29th Street. Mr. Carter represented the Mutual Security Agency,

Curt Conway, who made his debut as an actor here with the Group theater in 1835, died last Thursday of a heart at tack in Los Angeles. Mr. Conway had been teaching on the West Coast in the Civic Light Opera's Musical Theater Workshop and had been on the faculty of the California Institute of Arts.

The Houston States Gas Corporation, announced yesterday that it had acquired about a .50 per cent interest in two foreign companies that own or control contracts for the construction of two large crude oil tankers. The names of the companies were not disclosed.

State Senator John Marchi has introduced a bill which would ban the use of student activities fees for the operation of undergraduate newspapers on the campuses of the state's public colleges and universities. The explanation offered for this prohibition is that it would safeguard the civil liberties of students so that their contributions are not used to subsidize causes with which they differ and which are advocated without regard to their approval or disapproval.

A study conducted by the Stanford Research Institute, just released, forecasts rapid growth and a prosperous future for pay-television as a companion medium to "free" television, envisioning revenues approaching $4-billion annually by 1985. The report projects a growth of pay-television households from 1.5 million in 1976 to more than 25 million--or 30 percent of all television house households--by 1985.

The leadership of Israel's ruling Labor party decided tonight not to move for new elections. It resolved instead to try to set up a new coalition Cabinet to replace the Government of Premier Golda Meir, who resigned last week. The prospects, however, were acknowledged to' be uncertain. The decisions were made at a caucus of the party's executive and its representatives in Parliament.

Charles H. McLaughlin a retired executive in the aviation field who edited the 1959 "Space Age Dictionary," died Saturday at his home in Newtown, Conn. He was 70 years Mr. McLaughlin, who attended New York University, was chairman of McLaughlin Research-Corporation, with offices here and in Washington.
The Pentagon has told a Senate committee that it has found $266-million extra for military aid to South Vietnam this year--funds that military officials said they did not know they had.

Carl Bernstein and Bob Woodward, TV Washington Post investigative reporters, have sold paperback rights ot their book about Watergate, "All the President's Men," for $1-million. Their share in the gale is about half the full amount, with their hardcover publisher, Si-, mon and Shuster, receiving an equal share.
Randolph E. Evans, the architect who designed the buildings that make up the Brooklyn College campus, died of a respiratory illness yesterday at his home, 50 Park Avenue. He was 72 years old.

Canada is considering a $20billion crash program to develop her Athabasca tar sands, which contain one of the world's largest deposits of oil. Under the plan, 20 huge plants would be built to extract oil from the sticky black sand along the Athabasca River in northern Alberta, yielding some 2.5 million barrels of oil a day,

The A.E.G. Telefunken Corporation, West Germany, Europe's largest conglomerate, will build its first American-based manufacturing facility in the Norwich Industrial Park, in Norwich, Conn. The announcement was made here by Oscar Stuhlweissenburg, president of the company's American subsidiary in New York City,

New York football's new coaches will know immediately just how good their teams are. Although there are five months to go, the National League issued its schedule yesterday, and it shows the Giants opening against the. Washington Redskins at New Haven, while the Jets face the Chiefs at Kansas City.

John B. Connally, spoken of as one of the most possible Republican candidates for President in 1976, is being pulled, a bit at a time, into the Watergate backwash. No charges have been brought against the former Texas Governor who served as President Nixon's Secretary of the Treasury.

In 1960, at the first Funorama on Ice, Don Jackson of Canada, a future world figureskating champion, and Carol Noir Wick of East Orange, a future United States junior champion, were two of the featured performers.

The city of Philadelphia told a Federal court today that it would not enforce a city ordinance forbidding massages by persons to those of the opposite sex. The Velvet . Touch massage parlor filed a suit in United States District Court after several of its. masseuses had been arrested for violating the ordinance.

The city government's biweekly food-purchase bill has gone down 5.6 per cent for the April 15-to-28 period, reversing a pre-Easter increase and contrary to the city's earlier gloomier expectations. Purchase Commissioner Robert I. Cohen said yesterday that the sharpest decline was a 22 per cent decrease in the price of Grade A medium eggs, from 50.40 cents a dozen for deliveries starting, April 1 to 39.30 cents for supplies for the current period.
India's Prime Minister, Indira Gandhi, denied today that she had ever told former Vice President Hubert H. Humprey that it was absolutely essential for United States troops to be in Vietnam. tnam.

DROP-IN Drop-outs, come home. There's an "arts dropin" from today through Friday, sponsored on campus by the Columbia University School of the Arts. Today at 4:30 P.M., a "Cinema Colloquium" unfolds in the Low Library Faculty Room, in mid-campus at 116th Street (near Broadway).

The files of The New York Herald Tribune have been offered to the city for inclusion in the municipal archives. City Council President Paul O'Dwyer, who has been negotiating with the Whitney Foundation, trustee of the collection of clippings, announced the offer yesterday,

James Rochford, superindent of police, announced massive changes today in the Chicago Police Department's leadership, switching all but two of the present district commanders and naming a new deputy superintendent.

Paul Pawlak Jr., an assistant football coach at Cornell for the last eight seasons, will be the 20th head coach at Tufts University, officials at Medford, Mass., school announced yesterday. Pawlak, 33 years old,

The Boston Celtics gave Don Nelson a second chance nine years ago and he has been paying them back ever since, only more than ever this season. Only 28 days short of his 34th birthday, the deep-chested Nelson; who looks like a football player land shoots free throws like a shot-putter, helped bury the Knicks, 111-99, last night at Madison Square Garden.

A class action lawsuit against Pennzoil United, Inc., was filed yesterday by a bondholder in the United States District Court in St. Louis, Mo. The suit, against the defendant, which, since June 1, 1972, has been known as the Pennzoil Company, alleges fraud, breach of contract and violation of anti-trust laws, securities acts, and the Trust Indenture ture Act.

Two major promotions were announced yesterday by the World Bank Group, which consists of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (the World Bank), the International Development Association and the International Finance Corporation. All three institutions are headed by Robert S. McNamara.

Socialervice organizations today resseda their complaint that, despite proposed increases in emergency state aid for the ged, blind and disabled receiving Federal Supplementary Seurity Income payments, thouands of these individuals still ace hunger and deprivation.

Mayor Beame retreated yesterday from his election-campaign pledge to hire 3,000 extra policemen this year, and he argued that a one-penny increase in the sales tax here, to 8 per cent, would hurt New Yorkers less than a rise in their income tax.

New floods in northeastern Brazil have left 70,000 people homeless and caused 12 deaths, according to state government reports today. Less than two weeks after the worst floods in Brazilian history resulted in 300,000 refugees and a death toll estimated at several thousand, rivers in the northeast have once more broken their banks.

Mike Anderson's tworun double and Dave Cash's third run batted in highlighted a five-run sixth inning and led the Philadelphia Phillies to a 10-3 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals tonight. It was the Phils' fifth consecutive National League victory.

NASHVILLE--America is experiencing an antibusiness binge in which every corporate mistake or imperfection, from a defective can of tun to a single oil spill off the California coast, becomes an excuse for slowing technological development, proposing new economic controls and urging nationalization or private enterprise.

Mrs. DeWitt Wallace, also founder of Reader's Digest and a frequent contributor to cultural causes, has given the Metropolitan Opera $650.000 to finance two new productions next season. Her donation is expected to cover costs of staging Janacek's "Jenufa" and Mussorgsky's "Boris Godunov,"

Brokerage houses that began offering discounts on certain small trades two weeks ago say the new commissions are working fine. Firms that have ignored them say they're meaningless In any event, unless the discounters are skinning their competitors' hides, the special rates have had little influence on the small investors' vestors' apathy.

In his middle age, Robert Melrose is the sort of man on whom practical jokes are played. He can always be depended upon to go along with the gag-not because he is taken in, but because playing the fool is better than being left out altogether. To be laughed at is not so bad as being ignored.

You say you've got a kid in college interested in an ad agency career? Suggest he try plumbing You say he's a she? Tell her to try the cops. Or in the words of John Del Mar of the American Association of Advertising Agencies, "The Job market is closed tighter than a drum."

American Airlines announced yesterday that six of the seven Boeing 747 jumbo jets it put in mothballs in the midst of the fuel emergency early this year would be back in the air June 15. The airline said the return of these jumbos, part of a total fleet of 14 of the 747's, had been made possible by "a more favorable fuel outlook and expected seasonal increases in traffic."

There was Kenny Noe Jr., the racing secretary at Aqueduct, commenting in his office yesterday about the topheavy list of candidates for Saturday's Wood Memorial at the Big A when along came word there was another possible starter -- Eugene Grandon's Be A Native.

Directors of the Guaranty Bank in Dallas has approved an agreement in principle to merge that bank into the Houston-based Allied Banchshares, a multi-bank holding company. As part of the concept of expanding its service capability through the merger with Allied,

The Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that Donald D. DeFreeze, an escaped convict, was among the band of terrorists it believes may have forced Patricia Hearst to take part in a daring bank robbery here yesterday. Mr. DeFreeze, who calls himself General Field Marshal Clnque and who escaped from Soledad Prison 13 months ago,

Seven undercover narcotics agents were cleared yesterday of charges of perjury and conspiracy to obstruct justice in connection with mistaken drug raids at six homes in southern Illinois last spring. Federal District Court Judge Omer Poos signed an order dismissing the charges at the request of the Justice Department.

"Rex," a musical about King Henry VIII with music by Richard Rodgers and lyrics by Sheldon Harn ick, will be produced here next season by Richard Adler. The musical, which is expected to cost more than $500,000, will have a book by Jerome Lawrence and Robert E. Lee, authors of "Inherit the Wind" and "Mame."

With tantalizing deliberation, Middle Eastern oilproducing countries are gradually awakening to the wisdom and the necessity of spreading some of their windfall riches among their less-blessed third world partners. Regrettably the amounts of new development capital now under discussion still represent only a fraction of the anticipated need.

A 31-year-old former leader of the anti-Castro movement among Cuban exiles was found shot to death in his Washington Heights apartment yesterday afternoon, the police reported. The body of Arturo Rodriguez Vives was found by his wife, Josephine, at 3:15 P.M. in their apartment at 2304 Amsterdam Avenue, near 171st they said.
Rabbi Meir Kahane of New York, founder and chairman of the Jewish Defense League, said today that he was resigning as head of its militant arm, but would continue as its spiritual leader.

The Supreme Court cleared the ay today for resolution of a long and heated national controversy over whether striking workers should be eligible for welfare benefits. In the past, a number of court have refused to rule on the issue on the ground that it had reached them after the strike was over and thus there was no live dispute to demand the court's attention.

To the Editor: I am astonished at your garbled editorial of April 11 in which you attempt to rewrite history and dilute my predecessor's responsibility for leaving me with a budget deficit of record proportions.

Like the man who came to dinner, the Yankees nestled into Shea Stadium yesterday and won their fourth straight game in the home of the Mets by edging the Boston Red Sox, 2-1. It's not the most convenient place in the world for the Yankees because most of their players used to rent houses in New Jersey when they played in Yankee Stadium.

Scores of parents, teachers and others -- even 4-year-old Leon Garrido, who will-enter kindergarten next fall - appealed to the Board of Education last night to help ease school crowding in the Crown Heights and East Flatbush sections of Brooklyn.

The Government said today that the new Regional Rail Reorganization Act made it unnecessary for the Federal District Court here to end rail operations of the bankrupt Penn Central Railroad to protect creditors. The Government took this position in a brief filed with District Judge John P. Fullam,

The Soviet Union and Syria jointly asserted today that any disengagement of Syrian and Israeli forces in the Golan Heights "must be part and parcel" of an over-all Middle East peace settlement. The assertion, which appeared intended as a rebuff to the peace-making efforts of Secretary of State Kissinger,

In an annual Mother's Day proclamation, President Nixon called today for diligent efforts to continue removing "barriers to equal opportunity for women." Designating May 12 as Mother's Day, Mr. Nixon also hailed motherhood as a career in itself, saying "there is no undertaking more challenging, no responsibility more awesome."

Francis G. Wilson, a radio and television writer and a novelist, died yesterday in the Le Roy Hospital, 40 East 61st Street. He was 68 years old and lived at 67 Park Avenue. In the early nineteen-forties, Mr. Wilson worked. for major advertising agencies,

In a large room near Times Square, Arthur Miller was rehearsing his first musical, "Up From Paradise" (book lyrics, direction and narration by Mr. Miller, music by Stanley Silverman). Sitting at a table, Mr. Miller silently mouthed all the dialogue and lyrics along with his actors, savoring the lines and smiling at the jokes.

China called on the Security Council.. today to "sternly condemn Israeli Zionist aggression," and the Soviet Union demanded that the United States stop using its veto power to prevent the Council from taking "effective measures" against Israel. These statements came in the second day of a session convened at Lebanon's request following Israeli raids against six Lebanese villages Friday.

The search for 4-year-old Brenda Probasco was called off by the police today, six days after the blue-eyed, brownhaired girl disappeared. Her family and friends, and many others here, however, have pledged to continue the hunt in Woodbury Creek and the swamps and woods around this sprawling township south of Camden.

Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and Iraq, three of the world's top oil producers, told the special Gneral Assembly on raw materials and development today that their Governments had given generously to help poorer countries. They insisted that the advanced industrial nations should shoulder the primary responsibility for aiding these countries.

The White House is preparing to turn over to, the House Judiciary Committee those portions of the subsubpoenaedtape recordings that the President's lawyers believe would serve as evidence in the committee's impeachment, inquiry, according to Administration sources.

Three days before he was found murdered, an Irishman told a civilliberties lawyer a story of intrigue and deception by Scotland Yard in its fight against Irish terrorists. The Irishman, Kenneth Lennon, was found shot to death Saturday in the Surrey countryside. Saying he was in fear of his life,

Governor, Byrne, in what legislative leaders regard as .a major political retrenchment, has withdrawn his opposition to a statewide referendum on a constitutional amendment that would permit legalized casino gambling in New Jersey, a spokesman for. the Governor said today.

American auto makers reported to-day sales of 230,375 cars in the first 10 days of April, down 15.4 per cent from a year earlier but up 42 per cent from the first 10 days of March. Auto executives said the sales of this month, although lower, indicated a slightly stronger new-car market.

Two mental patients were beaten to death after the quelling of a riot in a mental hospital in the Soviet Far East, dissident sources said today. The riot, it was reported, occurred recently in the Amur

Gary Player, the Masters winner, was favored to take the 48th Spanish open golf tournament, which starts tomorrow with a field of 130. The South African was familiar with the 6,855yard La.Manga course. He is the titular pro at the club. The field includes Tony Jacklin, Maurice Bembridge and Jerry Heard. The first prize in the $65,000 event is $8,500.

Six years have, passed since Marcus Thompson made his viola debut here under the sponsorship of Young Concert Artists. They have obviously been years of growth, for in his recital in the Hunter College Playhouse on Monday night, again under the same sponsorship, he played with the authority of a mature artist.
