The Saigon Government's announcement that is was suspending the political talks outside Paris with the Vietcong was seen by some diplomats here today as an attempt to heighten tension while a military appropriations bill for South Vietnam is working its way through the American Congress.

The following table, based on Board of Education projections for next fall, gives the capacity, estimated enrollment, building utilization rate and student ethnic composition of zoned academic high schools in the Bronx.

Why are such shows as "Words and Music" simple and enchanting, and other shows complex and morose? "Words and Music" opened last night at the John Golden Theater. I adored it, and so did Sammy Cahn. He wrote the words and his friends wrote the music.

Is breaking the 10 per cent prime like breaking the 4-minute mile? The North Carolina National Bank and the Bank of California have now lifted the interest rate they charge their best corporate customers to a record 10.25 percent,

A proposal to repeal a bistate bond covenant that precludes the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey from undertaking mass - transportation projects that could lose money cleared a key State Senate committee expeditiously today. Democratic Senate leaders said the repeal measure would win final legislative approval overwhelmingly next week, with unusual swiftness,

The Newark Pre-School Council said yesterday that it might be forced soon to close its 60 Head Start centers that serve 1,900 4-year-old children and their families in the city unless the council's annual budget of $2.3-million was met through a grant from the Office of Child Development, Department of Health, Education and Welfare.

The United States volunteer forces, nine months after the end of the draft, are in a period of transition marked by manifold problems and some encouraging successes. The long-term problem facing all the services, particularly the Army, is recruiting,

The Houston Lighting and Power Company has given a letter of intent to the Habcock Wilcox Company for two multifuel boilers to provide steam for two 660-megawatt generators to be constructed in Fort Bend County, Tex.

J. Bob Traxler, a 42-year-old member of the Michigan House of Representatives, yesterday became the first Democrat to. be elected to Congress from Michigan's Eighth District since 1932. He defeated James M. Sparling Jr., the Republican candidate, by campaigning against President Nixon and attempting to: cast the election as a referendum on the President's performance in office.

A bill that provides for broad state regulation of automobile repairs received final passage in the Assembly today and was sent to the Governor for his signature. Hailed by its supporters as a major piece of consumer legislation, the bill requires repair shops to provide customer with invoices dealing all work performed and past supplied,

The Administration's decision to end wage-price controls over supermarkets and other food distributors makes it plain that there will be few sectors of the economy left to decontrol by the time the Economic Stabilization Act expires less than two weeks hence.

Fourteen persons were arrested today when the police raided a home occupied by members of the Black Panther party in response to a complaint from a young man who said he had been beaten with a pistol and baseball bat.

The General Telephone and Electronics Corporation reported yesterday record firstquarter profits of $86.7-million, or 69 cents a share--a 10.4 per cent gain from the year-earlier period. The company, which operates the country's second largest telephone system and also manufactures electrical,

The Supreme Court ruled today that a Federal' agency could discharge a Civil Service worker without a hearing on the ground that bribery charges he made against his superiors had not promoted "the efficiency of the service." With the Court dividing four ways over the controversial case of a former poverty worker, only three Justices subscribed to the "majority" opinion.

President Nixon is considering nominating John Sherman Cooper as the first United States ambassador to East Germany high American officials said today. Mr. Cooper who will be 73 years old in August served three terms as Republican Senator from Kentucky and was ambassador to India and Nepal in 1955 and 1956.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art, which in 1969 with great fanfare upgraded its education department by creating the post of vice director of education, has abolished the post and will merge educational with cura torial activities.

PARIS -- The arithmetic of French politics is such that Francois Mitterrand's best chance of winning the imminent presidential election--caused by Georges Pompidou's death--lies in the possibility of gaining a first-round triumph over the divided Gaullist coalition.

The 73-year-old Sprague , a king-sized sternwheeler that gained fame on her Mississippi River runs, has been destroyer by a fire at her Vicksburg mooring. The boat, used as a theater since her retirement in 1948, was empty when the fire started last night.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said today it would Immediately arrange to disconnect the net-work of private long-distance facilities used by customers of MCI Communications Inc. MCI called A.T.'s decision "arrogant behavior toward communications users" in definance of Federal Communications Commission orders and vowed to continue to serve its customers.
The Vatican's relations with Portugal have apparently worsened since the expulsion of a Roman Catholic Bishop and a group of missionaries from Mozambique.

Gene McCarthy ran his anchor one-mile leg in 4 minutes 15.1 seconds yesterday to lead All Hallows to victory in the distance medley relay in the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association New York Diocese Relay Carnival at the Mount St. Michael track in the Bronx.

"Phone jokes? I got no phone jokes. Wait a minute, I'll give you a phone joke Feller calls his broker on the phone. Any new dope on the market?" Broker says. 'Yeah, my son.'" This is Henny Youngman, drawing from his venerable bag of gags to please a reporter inquiring about his Dial-a-Joke recordings for the New York Telephone Company.

The State Health Department warned today that pet hamsters might be causing illness among humans. Dr. William J. Dougherty, the Acting Health Commissioner, said four cases of a virus caused by infected hamsters had been reported in the state. There have been 89 other cases reported in six other states.

Last week's rise in Japan's hitherto relatively low national wage bill is not likely to lead to a substantial decline in Japan's competitive power in export markets soon, according to Japan's official Economic Planning Agency. The wage bill soared 30 per cent in the week after the country was paralyzed by a national strike.

On the first day of the new baseball season, a righthanded batter named Mike Schmidt hit a home run off left-handed Tug McGraw in Philadelphia and the New York Mets lost. Just about that time, maybe the same day, a book arrived from Houghton Mifflin Company entitled "Screwball." It is a beautiful book about a beautiful guy,

The Milwaukee Bucks, with a tough defense, trounced the Chicago Bulls tonight, 10185, in the first game of the National Basketball Association Western Conference final playoff. Kareem Abdul-Jabbar and Bob Dandridge paced the attack with 25 points apiece.

Taking its cultural mission as seriously as ever, the French Government has again helped to send us Le Treteau de Paris, a state-subsidized drama troupe that has toured the United States since 1958 with French-language productions of the classics and the Parisian avant-garde.

The indictment of five city correction officers on charges of criminal possession and sale of dangerous drugs was announced yesterday. They were immediately suspended by Correction Commissioner Benjamin J. Malcolm. The indictments, which were handed up by Brooklyn, Manhattan and Bronx Countygrand juries, were disclosed by-Special State Prosecutor Maurice H. Nadjari.

A sharp warning on the dangers of raising the already high tax burdens of middleincome and upper-income New workers is made in a new study of the region's economy by the First National City Bank. After noting the findings of a survey showing that the tax burden on New York City families exceeds a 30-city average by 41 to 71 per cent,

After tying the game in the last 16 seconds tonight in the Forum, the New York' Rangers beat the Montreal Canadiens in overtime, 3-2, and took the lead in their National Hockey League playoff series, 3 games to 2. Ron Harris scored the sudden-death winner at 4:07 of the first extra period, while Bruce MacGregor got the allimportant tying goal,

George Meany, declaring that "the plight of farm workers is of vital importance to the entire labor movement," acted to-day to mobilize the nationwide network of A.F.L.-C.O. uions to support the boycott of grapes and lettuce organized by the United Farm Workers of America.

MONTGOMERY, Ala. -- During the three months before President Nixon's State of the Union Message in January, in which he proclaimed our national prosperity at an all-time high, I had been talking to hundreds of poor people in Alabama, Florida, Mississippi and Georgia.

A 65-year-old cowboy from Rhode Island has won a court judgment against the Columbia Broadcasting System on his charge that he, and not C.B.S., created the character Paladin and essential ideas used in the popular television series, "Have Gun, Will Travel."

Two gunmen forced their way into a Harlem church during a choir rehearsal last night and robbed 30 choir members of $600 in cash and $2,000 worth of jewelry, the police reported. The police said the two men entered the Emanuel A.M.E. Church at 37 West 119th Street at 9:15 P.M.

The Food and Drug Administration has licensed two new products that are expected to help reduce the risk of transmitting a potentially dangerous hepatitis virus through blood transfusion. The problem of post-transfusion hepatitis is widely believed to be the most important risk in the medical use of blood.

BEECHER--William, devoted husband of Belty. Father of Stanley. Brother of Reggle Brecher and Jeanne Gadd and dear uncle. Service Wednesday, 2 P.M. at Schwartz Brothers "Forest Park Chapels," Queens Blvd. and 76th Rd., Forest Hills.

The United Nations Children's Fund announced plans today for aid to North Vietnam and to areas held by the Vietcong in the South. The three-year program was described in a report by Henry Labouisse, the fund's director,

Maurice H. Nadjari spoke at the City Club the other night, and he spoke with the strength of ten because he knew his heart was pure. "We search for stars in the eyes of the people we hire," he said, and then he said that his office had hired 40 lawyers, and that they all had those stars.

The New York Mets continued their generosity in helping the Montreal Expos open their. home baseball season today. The Mets lost here in 1971 and '72, and history repeated itself in windy, cold Jarry Park this afternoon when the Expos rallied for a 4-1 victory.

Saying that the United States Tariff Commission was provoking higher lead prices, Treasury Secretary George P. Shultz bowed today, to the commission's judgment that lead Imports from Australia and Canada were hurting American industry. He issued a finding that imports of primary lead metal from Australia and Canada were being dumped in the United States at low prices and were subject to special import duties if the price remained low..

Prices swung widely yesterday in heavy trading of silver futures on the Commodity Exchange. The metal, which underwent a sharp decline in price in recent weeks, rallied Monday and prices continued to move up early today. Analysts called the reaction "technical" after a period of declining prices.

Rates on Treasury bills, which on Monday tumbled as much as one-quarter of a point, reversed course yesterday and moved higher, despite forecasts by some economists that credit rates may have reached a crest and should be sharply lower this summer.

In a gray, cavernous garage on Broome Street yesterday, some of the best--and, decidedly, worst--bargains in town could be had at auction.. It was the Police Department's monthly auction of the cars, trucks and motorcycles it had accumulated. Some were stolen vehicles whose owners had never been located.
Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson unveiled a $6.2-million plan today to create the largest municipal park system in the state, and he predicted the pride of residents would save it from vandalism.

Throughout her astonishing career, Maria Callas has attracted two invaluable types of admirers: first, dismally unmusical people who can't tell how precarious her vocal state has been for most of the last 20 years, and second, highly musical listeners who know, but don't believe it really matters.

Philip E. Coates, a career Government official who has served with the Internal Revenue Service for more than 20 years, was sworn in yesterday as director of the Manhattan district of the I.R.S. The 'oath was administered' by Elliot H. Gray, whom he succeeds, at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

A profit improvement, larger new stores and generally better sales in existing stores brightened the results of Safeway Stores, Inc., for its first fiscal quarter ended March 23. Safeway, the country's second largest supermarket chain to A. P. in domestic sales, reported yesterday a 33 per cent rise in net income in the quarter on a gain of 18 per cent in sales.

Six men working diligently in unison, playing near the top of their form, was all the Boston Celtics needed last night to maintain their current playoff mastery of the Knicks. Requiring almost no help from the bench, the Celtics ran away from the Knicks in the third quarter and didn't stop until they had achieved a 1ll-99 victory before a dismayed capacity crowd at Madison Square Garden.

Walter G. Bunzl, retired president of the prometheus Electric Company which manufactured hospital supplies in New Rochelle, N.Y., died-gesterday in Scottsdale, Ariz., where he had been living. He was 79 years old.

An Associated Press photographer told a Federal judge yesterday that he gave information to F.B.I. agents on one occasion during the 71-day occupation of Wounded Knee, S.D., last year. James Mone, a photographer in the A.P.'s Minneapolis bureau, testified at an evidentiary hearing that has interrupted the trial of two leaders of the American Indian Movement.

The major oil companies apparently are telling the truth about their supplies, based on audits by the Federal Energy Office, according to the office's chief, William E. Simon. Mr. Simon said that Energy Office audits of refineries had turned up no evidence that oil companies were lying about their inventories.

The State Department expressed its full confidence today in Graham A. Martin, the Ambassador to South Vietnam. Mr. Martin had charged a leading American churchman with implicit responsibility for the deaths of 32 South Vietnamese children in a mortar attack last month.

The official radio in neighboring Niger today broadcast numerous messages of praise for the military rulers who seized power yesterday, but remained silent on the fate of the deposed President and his family. It said the messages had been sent by individuals and organizations.

The South Vietnamese Government said today that a member of the Polish delegation to the International Commission of Control and Supervision had asked for asylum in South Vietnam. The Polish delegation had no comment on the announcement.

A Bronx Civil Court judge who was indicted last December on charges of conspiracy to fix a murder case has defeated a civil action to have him removed from the bench on the ground that he does not live in the judicial district. The Louvre has indefinitely postponed an exhibition of paintings from Pablo Picasso's private collection, and art experts say the reason is that several works may be fakes and others only of minor interest. "The Louvre is terribly embarrassed," Raymond Cogniat, a critic and former High Commissioner for Fine Arts, said in an interview.

First-quarter net income dropped despite a rise in revenues, the Long Island Lighting Company reported after its annual meeting today. Profits fell to $17.1-million, or 63 cents a share, from $18.7million, or 74 cents a share, in the three months ended March 31, 1973, in spite of a rise in revenues to $138.7million from $112.2-million.

The bribery conviction of a former Queens assistant district attorney has been appealed on the ground that the presiding judge,State Supreme Cqurt Justice John M. Murtagh, held an improper conference with Maurice H. Nadjari, the special state prosecutor, in the case the day before it went to trial last October.

Secretary of Agriculture Earl Butz assured today Japan's Premier, Kakuei Tanaka, that the United States would not restrict exports of wheat, soybeans or raw cotton this year, Japanese sources said. Mr. Butz told the Japanese Premier that a 22 per cent increase was expected in the United States wheat crop this year,

The Atlantic Richfield Company announced yesterday that it had reduced its wholesale prices for gasoline by 1 cent a gallon in all of the company's marketing areas in the country. The reductions became effective yesterday.

The Massachusetts Supreme Court ruled today that a proposed binding referendum on planned busing to achieve racial balance in Boston schools would be unconstitutional. The high tribunal said, however, that there was no constitutional prohibition against a nonbinding referendum on the subject, which it described as an "opinion poll."

Arthur G. Hessel, for many years an executive of the Continental Baking Company, died yesterday in Sarasota Memorial Hospital in Florida, He was 74 years old. Mr. Hessel, since his retirement in 1965, had been board chairman of his own concern, Hessel Associates,

Paul Pawlak Jr., an assistant football coach at Cornell for the last eight seasons, will be the 20th head coach at Tufts University, officials at Medford, Mass., school announced yesterday.

The stock market made its best advance in six weeks yesterday, buoyed by investor hopes that interest rates would soon decline. The buying spree on the New York Stock Exchange was broad-based and was primarily touched off by the First National City Bank's forecast that short-term interest rates would turn downward in the next few months.

The Sun Oil Company reported yesterday that its profits in the first quarter of this year were 85 per cent higher than in the ?irst quarter of 1973. Sun was the first of the big oil companies to announce first-quarter results, and Its figures showed a steady and sharp uptrend in the company's year-to-year gains.

TOKYO--People in Tokyo rarely cross the street against a red light. They do not scrawl graffiti on subway walls. And they do not commit many murders either. Indeed, the worlds' most populous city--11.6 million people--has the lowest crime rate.

A strike threatened for last midnight by 16 Long Island Rail Road unions was postponed w en the unions de; cided to meet tomorrow in Washington to submit their pension dispute to an impartial panel. The decision spared 90,000 commuters from an imminent shutdown of the railroad.

SEOUL, South Korea-Lee Hu Rak and Kim Dae Jung, once political adversaries, have a lot in common today. They both left South Korea to escape the wrath of President Park Chung Hee Each was forced to return under strange circumstances. Both are still out of favor with the President and are virtual prisoners. But each hopes, though in a different way, to resume a political role.
The Animal Medical Center of New York was told today that Connecticut would welcome its 80-horse research project into equine-infectious anemia, now based in nearby Hillsborough.

One of the most common complaints of car owners today is that auto body shops are extremely expensive and. that damages, even those resulting from low-speed collisions, are costly to repair. To make matters worse for many car owners, auto insurers generally encourage policyholders to pick up the cost of the first $50 or $100 of damage.

Fans of Poulene's "Les Mamelles de Tiresias"-and there are more than you might guess from the dearth of performances around here -will be delighted to learn that a snappy new production of the effervescent work has been mounted by the Manhattan Theater Club and will be on view through April 27.

John D. Ehrlichman publicly pledged today his allegiance to President Nixon and the Administration in an attempt, sources close to Mr. Ehrlichman said, to put and end to repeated speculation about his loyalty in the face of at least three pending criminal trials.

Basketball is still king at Seton Hall University, which has a long tradition in athletics. In recent balloting for the Pirates' Athletic Hall of Fame, which will have its second induction ceremonies at the Student Center Friday night, five of 11 new inductees earned the honor through basketball.

The American Petroleum Institute reported today that estimated gasoline production, aviation and motor, for the latest week amounted to 6,289,000 barrels a day, compared with 6,035,000 barrels in the previous week and 6,321,000 a year ago.

William E. Simon, a former Wall Street bond dealer who came to national-notice as the Federal energy "czar," has been chosen by President Nixon as his fourth Secretary of the Treasury. Perhaps the most significant element about the appointment, however, was that its announcement was made not by the President himself but by his deputy. press secretary, a familiar technique of Presidents unwilling to invest an appointment with undue importance.

Abraham Robinson, Sterling Professor of Mathematics at Yale University, died last Thursday. He was 55 years old. A member of the Yale faculty since 1967, Professor Robinson was noted for his pioneering work in mathematical logic.

CHARLESTON, S. C.-For years, Vietnam was front-page news, a major political issue, and an emotional experience for the nation, Now this has changed: Casualties have been stopped, prisoners released and the controversy eclipsed by matters closer to home.

The critical debate on both sides of the Atlantic over the future relationship between the United States and a uniting West Europe has subsided under the uncertainties of the French presidential election. But, whatever the election's outcome, the shape of this relationship is more likely to be determined by the weight of opinion in the other eight nations of the Common Market, where resistance to French advocacy of a super-independent Europe has stiffened.
Argentina has set compensation sums to be paid to foreign banks for holdings here expropriated on March 25, a Presidential decree said today.

HELSINKI, Finland, April 18 The Soviet Union rallied with three goals in the second period to defeat Czechoslovakia, 3-1, today and took sole possession of first place in the world ice hockey championships. Both teams have one more game to play Saturday. Should Sweden beat the Russians, along with Czechoslovakia beating Finland, the title would be decided on the goal average for the two Soviet.Czechoslovak games and Czechoslovakia would win.

Yielding to opposition, the Navy has suspended development of Project Sanguine, a vast underground system for sending emergency messages to missile-firing submarines. The Navy announced today that research and development work on project Sanguine will be suspended for the last 21/2 months of the 1974 fiscal year, which ends June 30.

WASHINGTON, April 18-The Federal Home Loan Bank Board rescinded today an earlier order that would have increased the "liquidity ratio" of savings and loan associations effective June 1.

HOUSTON, April 10 Fourteen American companies have formed a venture to build a coal gasification pilot plan at Westfield, Scotland, at a cost of $10-million, it was announced today. The venture will test the new British high pressure slagging process ol gasifying coal.

DETROIT, April 18--The General Motors Corporation disclosed today that its chairman, Richard C. Gerstenberg, received a 5.5 per cent raise last year, lifting his total compensation by $48,037 to $923,000 and keeping him well in the lead as the highest paid executive in the country.

LISBON, April 18-A dozen members of the left-wing political opposition, some of them journalists, were arrested by the police today as the Portuguese Government continued to show a tough attitude toward those who oppose its war policy in the nation's African territories.

CAIRO, April 18-President Anwar el-Sadat announced today that Egypt had decided to end more than 18 years of exclusive reliance on Soviet arms supplies and to seek armaments from other sources.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, April 18 (Reuters)-Ethiopia's Premier, Endalkachew Makonnen, announced today that security forces had been ordered to place Cabinet ministers of the former Government under house arrest.

TRENTON, April 18--Governor Byrne today proposed extending to primary campaigns his controversial suggestion that the election campaigns of nominees for Governor of New Jersey be financed in part with public funds. His move forces a major legislative confrontation between the advocates of election reform and the vested interests of the major political parties.

The Aluminum Company of America -- the world's largest aluminum producer - reported yesterday that Its profits in the first, quarter of the year were 115 per cent higher than a year ago. It was the company's largest quarterly gain in two years.

The Standard Oil Company (Ohio), one of only two large oil companies that had a drop in profits in the last quarter of 1973, announced a 29 per cent increase in earnings for the first three months compared with the same period in 1973.
The Government set out yesterday to destroy the credibility of Maurice H. Stans, the former Secretary of Commerce, in a cross-examination that lasted nearly all day and will continue today.

Under the impact of 154 unfilled sell orders remaining from Wednesday's trading session, May potato futures dropped the 50-point limit yesterday to close at 17 cents a pound. The preceding day's close on the New-York Mercantile Exchange was 17.50.

Spring turkey. hunting might jar the sensibilities of those who think of an early settler, trudging' through a pre-Thanksgiving snow witha handsome gobbler over his shoulder, but it is perhaps the loveliest time of year to hunt this country's wiliest game bird.

The tax bill passed by Congress in 1971 provided for a tax device known as the Domestic International Sales Corporation (or DISC) aimed at spurring exports. Any American company selling some of its products abroad could set up a DISC, export through it and defer indefinitely the taxes on half of its export-related profits. Even before the DISC tax gimmick was enacted, critics warned that it would be expensive, and wasteful.

The Kraftco Corporation announced yesterday that it was increasing its quarterly dividend to 48 cents a share from 44.2 cents, a rise of 3.8 cents.

Trans World Airlines reported yesterday a corporate net loss of $47.3-million for the first quarter of the year, and a loss for the airline alone of $62.6million. The preliminary figures, Which are subject to final audit, were believed to be the worst in the airline's history, a spokesman said.
Attorneys for the Summa Corporation contended today that Robert A. Maheu has spent $149,338 of Howard R. Hughes's money to pay people who worked in Mr. Maheau's business.

John Henry, Lewis, lightheavyweight boxing champion of the world from 1935 to 1939, died here Sunday after a long illness. He held the 175-pound title through five successful defenses. He was 59 years old.

PARIS, April 18--Marcel Pagnol, the film director and playwright, died today of a long illness at his Paris mansion on the Avnue Foch. He was 79 years old.
Gertrude Marvin Williams, a writer and educator, who had been a reporter on The New York Evening Sun, died Tuesday at Stapeley Hall, a home in Philadelphia. She was 89 years old.

Dr. William J. Ronan was unanimouslyy elected chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey yesterlay, and the prosperous bistate agency simultaneously announced its "dedication" to improve mass transit in the retion.
Syrian and Israeli forces battling for control of Mount Hermon today sent jet planes into action against each other. The Syrian command said it was its first use of aircraft since the October war.

When George Medich pitched in Cleveland last Saturday, he had Whitey Ford confused. "We couldn't tell from the bench if he was throwing his last curve or his slow curve," Ford, the Yankee pitching coach , related yesterday.
Stanley M. Ward, a retired architect, who had been with Ferrenz Taylor here, died yesterday in St. Mary's Hospital, Orange, N. J. He was 80 years old and lived in East Orange.

The free-for-all guessing game about Patricia Hearst's battles may be inevitable in a case that has aroused popular outrage as well as morbid curiosity. Such futile theorizing, nevertheless, contributes nothing to the chances of Miss Hearst's liberation either from her captors or from her hallucinations, whichever may be holding her in thrall. Nor are these amateur excursions into criminal psychology likely to facilitate apprehension of the terrorists.
